Title: In re Kwok
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Bankruptcy trustee plausibly stated alter ego claim under Delaware law, in adversary proceeding against entities seeking turnover of assets, on allegations individual Chapter 11 debtor controlled entities, entity that owned 99.9999% of defendant entities was wholly owned by individual debtor's female employee and assistant, who worked with individual debtor at debtor's adjudged alter ego, remaining 0.0001% of each entity was owned by male employee and assistant, who worked with individual debtor in his media business, individual debtor invoked his Fifth Amendment rights against self-incrimination regarding his control over both employees and assistants, and female employee was indicted on charges relating to alleged fraud perpetrated by, among others, principally individual debtor and involving entities, and other employees of individual debtor's adjudged alter ego worked at entities. U.S. Const. Amend. 5; 11 U.S.C.A. §§ 541, 542, 544.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Chapter 11 bankruptcy trustee had standing to bring turnover claim on behalf of creditors at large.

Title: In re Kwok
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Bankruptcy trustee plausibly stated alter ego under Delaware law, in adversary proceeding against entities seeking turnover of assets, on allegations individual Chapter 11 debtor used entities for his own purposes, entities were affiliates of other entities that court ruled were part of individual debtor's media operations and were indirectly owned by individual debtor, as stated by entities' outside accountant, entities were used by entities related to individual debtor to transfer liquid assets, including making payments to maintain pleasure yacht that court had determined was beneficially owned by individual debtor, maintain aircraft that court had determined was beneficially owned by individual debtor, and purchase another aircraft that was individual debtor's airplane, and entity made numerous payments to entities and individuals associated with and who performed work for individual debtor. 11 U.S.C.A. §§ 541, 542, 544.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Chapter 11 bankruptcy trustee had standing to bring turnover claim on behalf of creditors at large.

Title: In re Kwok
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Bankruptcy trustee plausibly stated entities were financed by individual Chapter 11 debtor, supporting alter ego claim under Delaware law in adversary proceeding against entities seeking turnover of assets, on allegations that entity was funded by entities associated with individual debtor, including his adjudged alter ego and other entities courts had found were controlled by individual debtor and other defendant entities were funded by followers and associates of individual debtor. 11 U.S.C.A. §§ 541, 542, 544.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Chapter 11 bankruptcy trustee had standing to bring turnover claim on behalf of creditors at large.

Title: In re Kwok
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Bankruptcy trustee plausibly stated individual Chapter 11 debtor had pattern of using shell companies to shelter his assets from his creditors, supporting alter ego claim under Delaware law in adversary proceeding against entities seeking turnover of assets, where complaint made specific allegations regarding individual debtor's alleged "shell game," complaint referred to prior judicial findings regarding other entities, which effected that purpose, as well as prior citations for contempt regarding turnover of assets in judgment collection proceedings, complaint referred to declaration filed in individual debtor's Chapter 11 case by alleged witness, and individual debtor invoked his Fifth Amendment rights against self-incrimination regarding subject matter of adversary proceeding. U.S. Const. Amend. 5; 11 U.S.C.A. §§ 541, 542, 544.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Chapter 11 bankruptcy trustee had standing to bring turnover claim on behalf of creditors at large.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Kwok
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Bankruptcy trustee sufficiently pleaded alter ego under Delaware law, supporting trustee's alter ego claim under Delaware law in adversary proceeding against entities seeking turnover of assets, on plausible allegations entities did not observe corporate formalities but rather had porous border with other entities associated with individual Chapter 11 debtor and their assets were used by individual debtor, his family and associates, and other entities related to individual debtor, individual debtor siphoned entities' assets for his personal benefit, entities operated as single unit with individual debtor and were undercapitalized, entities served as façade for individual debtor, and corporate forms of entities caused fraud or similar injustice. 11 U.S.C.A. §§ 541, 542, 544.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Chapter 11 bankruptcy trustee had standing to bring turnover claim on behalf of creditors at large.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Cameo
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Chapter 7 debtor was liable for the indebtedness owed by his wholly owned camera company to creditor, an online marketplace which debtor's company allegedly used to defraud thousands of company's customers, to whom creditor then issued refunds; debtor was the person who perpetrated the subject "hit-and-run" fraud, a type of abusive selling pattern whereby his company accepted money from customers, failed to fulfill customer orders, and then disappeared with customers' money, as debtor, who was company's only shareholder, officer, director, and employee, as well as the sole signatory for its bank account, solely controlled company, and, except for packages allegedly packed and shipped by agency workers, debtor performed all day-to-day activities for company. 11 U.S.C.A. § 523(a)(2)(A).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debt to online marketplace arising from hit-and-run fraud in which debtor's company allegedly engaged fell within the fraud discharge exception.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: 138-77 Queens Blvd LLC v. Silver
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, the diversion of funds to make a corporation judgment-proof constitutes a wrong for the purposes of determining whether the corporate veil should be pierced.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Landlord plausibly alleged that father of personal guarantor of its commercial tenant exercised complete control and domination over tenant as required to pierce corporate veil as to father.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: McCallan v. Wilkins
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Alabama, Northern Division.
Headnote: Bankruptcy Court's finding, that seven non-party entities were Chapter 7 debtor's alter egos under Alabama law, such that the Court did not violate their due process rights when, in trustee's adversary proceeding against debtor's wife, the Court avoided their conveyances to her as fraudulent transfers, was supported by evidence that debtor wholly owned five of the entities, that debtor wholly owned sixth entity before he transferred ownership to wife, that debtor owned 95% of seventh entity through an intermediary trust, with wife owning the remaining 5%, that debtor dominated and controlled the entities, and that entities did not observe the corporate form, but intermingled personal and corporate funds among them and in making transfers to wife, thus draining funds from entities. U.S. Const. Amend. 5; 11 U.S.C.A. §§ 544, 548.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Professionals. Bankruptcy Court did not abuse its discretion in denying recusal motion that was based in part on objectionable email sent by party's former counsel.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: McCallan v. Wilkins
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Alabama, Northern Division.
Headnote: Record did not support Bankruptcy Court's finding that, under Alabama law, three non-party entities were Chapter 7 debtor's alter egos, for purposes of determining whether the Court violated their due process rights when, in trustee's adversary proceeding against debtor's wife, it avoided their conveyances to her as fraudulent transfers; debtor did not own first entity, but performed consulting work for it and directed that his fees be paid to his wife, debtor had similar payment arrangements with second entity and third entity, and there was no suggestion that debtor dominated and controlled any of the entities. U.S. Const. Amend. 5; 11 U.S.C.A. §§ 544, 548.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Professionals. Bankruptcy Court did not abuse its discretion in denying recusal motion that was based in part on objectionable email sent by party's former counsel.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Wolf
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Bankruptcy trustee is empowered by the Bankruptcy Code's strong-arm provision to assert a reverse veil-piercing claim on behalf of creditors generally, though reverse piercing of the corporate veil is a rarity, and even more so in bankruptcy. 11 U.S.C.A. § 544(a).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Court properly granted Chapter 7 trustee's claim for outside reverse veil-piercing, so as to use corporate assets to satisfy debtor's personal debts.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Wolf
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Bankruptcy Court did not misapply Illinois law by granting Chapter 7 trustee's claim for outside reverse veil-piercing, so as to use the assets of debtor's wholly owned corporation to satisfy debtor's personal debts; Illinois, as predicted by District Court, recognized the doctrine, debtor did not challenge Bankruptcy Court's finding that corporation was debtor's alter ego, nor did he take issue with any of the equitable considerations relied upon by Bankruptcy Court in granting the claim, and though debtor argued that innocent shareholders and creditors of corporation would be prejudiced by use of corporate assets to satisfy his personal debts, debtor was corporation's sole shareholder, so there were no innocent shareholders to speak of, and any innocent creditors could protect their interests in bankruptcy court along with the rest of debtor's creditors.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Court properly granted Chapter 7 trustee's claim for outside reverse veil-piercing, so as to use corporate assets to satisfy debtor's personal debts.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Shakir
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Illinois law did not bar Chapter 7 trustee from reverse piercing veil of Illinois company, i.e., asset-recovery powers that Bankruptcy Code conferred upon trustee empowered him to prosecute such claims on behalf of all of creditors of bankruptcy estate, since bankruptcy trustee did not become involved until after alleged alter ego companies had been formed, and therefore he did not have any role in forming them, and trustee brought veil-piercing claims for estate's benefit, not for benefit of debtor corporation or its officers and directors.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Chapter 7 trustee had standing to prosecute alter ego claims in adversary proceeding.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Gordos Restaurant Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Although Chapter 7 trustee established that debtor, the operator of a restaurant that had closed, after which its principal's wife and a partner formed new corporation to operate similar restaurant nearby, engaged in an avoidable unauthorized postpetition transfer when its restaurant's trade name and associated goodwill were transferred to the new entity without notice or approval and for no compensation, the new entity, and the new entity alone, was the "initial transferee" of the avoided transfer, for purposes of determining trustee's remedy; trustee failed to show that the section of the Bankruptcy Code governing liability of transferee of avoided transfer also applied to new entity's shareholders, subject to a single satisfaction, nor did he establish that the corporate veil between new entity and its shareholders should be pierced or that, separate and apart from their status as shareholders, they benefited from the transaction. 11 U.S.C.A. §§ 549, 550(a).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Turnover of trade name and associated goodwill of Chapter 7 debtor's restaurant ordered as remedy for principal's unauthorized postpetition transfer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Maxus Energy Corporation
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Parent and grandparent corporations ultimately could be held liable to liquidating trust, which was successor-in-interest to Chapter 11 debtors, for alleged asset stripping strategy upon which liquidating trust based its alter ego claim under Delaware law only for harm Chapter 11 estate suffered as result of that strategy.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Parent corporation ultimately could be held liable for alleged asset stripping strategy upon which liquidating trust based its alter ego claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Maxus Energy Corporation
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Liquidating trust, which was successor-in-interest to Chapter 11 debtors, seeking to avoid fraudulent transfer, did not have to sequentially prove in adversary proceeding that each corporate layer in organizational chart should be pierced to pierce corporate veil of grandparent corporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Parent corporation ultimately could be held liable for alleged asset stripping strategy upon which liquidating trust based its alter ego claim.

Title: In re Daniels
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Ohio, Western Division.
Headnote: Evidence that Chapter 7 debtor diverted company funds for his personal use was not sufficient to consider debtor alter ego of company under Ohio law; although business records debtor provided to trustee were inadequate for purposes bankruptcy discharge exception, records were not completely absent.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debtor failed to maintain records from which his financial condition could be ascertained, and therefore discharge exception applied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Thomas v. Hughes
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Requirement for corporate veil-piercing under Texas law, that fraudulent transfer was for direct personal benefit of corporation's holder, beneficial owner, subscriber, or affiliate, is met where the evidence shows that funds derived from the corporation's allegedly fraudulent conduct were pocketed by or diverted to the individual defendant. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Trade Secrets. Evidence supported finding of fraud as basis for exemplary damages for misappropriation of trade secrets for probiotic supplements for livestock.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Thomas v. Hughes
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to support finding that owner of licensee, which was both a corporation and licensor's judgment debtor, perpetuated a fraudulent transfer under Texas law for her direct personal benefit, thus allowing licensor and licensee's bankruptcy trustee to pierce corporate veils of licensee and owner's limited liability company (LLC), which was licensee's transferee, to hold owner personally liable for misappropriation of licensor's trade secrets; there was evidence that owner received hundreds of thousands of dollars in compensation, that licensee could have used those funds to satisfy the pre-bankruptcy state-court judgment if licensee had retained its assets and continued to operate, and that owner began taking steps to operate through LLC just days after adverse jury verdict. Tex. Bus. & C. Code § 24.005(a)(1); Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Trade Secrets. Evidence supported finding of fraud as basis for exemplary damages for misappropriation of trade secrets for probiotic supplements for livestock.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Melilli
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Utah, Central Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, Chapter 7 trustee was not entitled to reverse veil-piercing of business entities owned in whole or in part by debtor's non-filing wife, absent a showing that the entities were used fraudulently or for an improper purpose, or that the entities failed to comply with corporate formalities by failing to file yearly tax returns, to maintain separate books and records, to use corporate bank accounts, or the like.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Chapter 7 trustee was not entitled to recover from debtor's non-filing spouse or her business entities, based on theory of unjust enrichment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Palmerone v. Staples
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Owner of intermediary company abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form, supporting holding owner individually liable to property owners for fraudulent conveyances of real property to elude debt arising from a prior judgment, where owner was the sole owner of intermediary company, exercised complete domination of it, and used that domination to commit a fraud or wrong against property owners.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Fraudulent Conveyances. Property owners made a prima facie showing that they were entitled to summary judgment on causes of action alleging fraudulent transfer of parcels.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Manichaean Capital, LLC v. Exela Technologies, Inc.
Court: Court of Chancery of Delaware.
Headnote: Insolvency is adequately pled, as required to pierce corporate veil, if a plaintiff's allegations allow a reasonable inference of either: (1) a deficiency of assets below liabilities with no reasonable prospect that the business can be successfully continued in the face thereof; or (2) an inability to meet maturing obligations as they fall due in the ordinary course of business.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Reverse piercing of corporate veil was appropriate to hold subsidiaries liable for payments to company's shareholders under appraisal judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Manichaean Capital, LLC v. Exela Technologies, Inc.
Court: Court of Chancery of Delaware.
Headnote: Allegations that funds that once flowed from company's subsidiaries to company as matter of course were bypassing company and flowing directly to acquirer, that arrangement was put in place by acquirer while likelihood that company would face a substantial appraisal judgment was well known to all who entered into accounts receivable securitization facility, that acquirer knew dissenting shareholders would be entitled to fair value of their shares, and that company was unable to meet its obligations as they became due because it had no funds and no prospect of securing funds were sufficient for company's former stockholders, as judgment creditors, to state that company was insolvent due to acquirer's undercapitalization, as required to pierce corporate veil and hold acquirer liable for payments due under appraisal judgment. 8 Del. Code § 262.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Reverse piercing of corporate veil was appropriate to hold subsidiaries liable for payments to company's shareholders under appraisal judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Belliveau v. Barco, Incorporated
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Extremely insufficient consideration may provide, at least in the fraudulent transfer context, evidence of actual fraud supporting piercing the corporate veil under Texas law. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Licensor was not entitled to pierce the corporate veil to hold shareholder liable for corporation's alleged breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re All Terrain, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Idaho.
Headnote: Veil-piercing and substantive consolidation as applied in bankruptcy context are both equitable doctrines, and both utilize generally the same factors.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Proof of claim could not be allowed on single business enterprise theory of veil-piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Cambridge Valley Machining, Inc. v. Hudson MFG LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Establishing that a transfer is fraudulent under the actual fraud prong of the Texas Uniform Fraudulent Transfer Act is sufficient to satisfy the actual fraud requirement of veil-piercing, because a transfer that is made "with the actual intent to hinder, delay, or defraud any creditor" necessarily involves dishonesty of purpose or intent to deceive. Tex. Bus. & C. Code § 24.005(a)(1); Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(b).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Sales. Manufacturer's purported repudiation of contract to provide firearm components did not excuse buyer's performance.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Horizon Group Management, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Reverse piercing of the corporate veil is a rarity, and is rarer yet in bankruptcy.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Tax payments on third part debt were received by the IRS in good faith.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re CC Operations, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Kentucky, Louisville Division.
Headnote: Kentucky law does not permit veil-piercing as means of consolidating entities to try and create assets for distribution in bankruptcy.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Limitations. Adverse domination doctrine did not apply to extend time for trustee to assert fraudulent transfer claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: General Fidelity Insurance Company v. WFT, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Transferee company and its director had complete domination and control over insurance company that transferred all of its assets and business to transferee in course of commission of constructive fraud against insurance company's creditor, and thus court assessing liability in creditor's claims could pierce corporate veil and extend liability to director and transferee company; director admitted that second company's only distinction from insurance company was its "name change," director was sole individual responsible for transferring business and assets, and director had full authority to do so unilaterally.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Insurance company was winding up when it transferred assets to second company, as necessary for transfer of assets to constitute constructive fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: United States v. Lax
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, liability of beneficiary of fraudulent conveyance is direct, not derivative, and thus once it has been established that defendant benefited from fraudulent conveyance, it is unnecessary to consider whether traditional prerequisites for veil-piercing are satisfied.
Document Preview: TAXATION  Collection. United States stated plausible personal liability claim against deceased taxpayer's widow.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Chatz v. World Wide Wagering, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Trustee of horse racing tracks, seeking Chapter 11 turnover of bankruptcy estate property on basis that directors of tracks, their family members, holding company that owned track, and other individuals and related corporate entities were alter egos of each other, sufficiently alleged defendants were alter egos of each other under Illinois, Ohio, and Delaware law, such that it could pierce corporate veil to hold directors liable for series of illegal payments made to enrich themselves and others before tracks ultimately filed for bankruptcy; trustee alleged single board of directors oversaw and controlled all entities, entities had no separate corporate offices, all entities shared board meetings, directors adopted "asset protection plan" to move assets from tracks in anticipation of large judgment in lawsuit, holding company purportedly existed solely to transfer funds between tracks and family members, and all defendants possessed unity of interest and ownership. 11 U.S.C.A. § 542.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Trustee stated breach of fiduciary duty claims against directors of horse racing tracks.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Trujillo
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Although Chapter 7 debtor dominated various Florida corporate entities that operated language schools as president or director of entities, irrespective of what formal corporate records might indicate, including by having the ultimate veto, there was no evidence that the entities were formed or used fraudulently or for an improper purpose, and thus, corporate veil of entities could not be pierced as alter egos of debtor under Florida law; the language schools were real companies, with employees, students, and a valid business purpose in which they were engaged, conducting business in various locations around the state.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Debtor was equitable owner of Panamanian foundation, such that assets of foundation were property of the bankruptcy estate subject to turnover.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Licking River Mining, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Kentucky, Ashland, London, and Lexington Divisions.
Headnote: Centralized cash management system which existed between corporate Chapter 7 debtor-parent and its debtor-subsidiaries did not permit Chapter 7 trustee to disregard corporate form and to avoid, as constructively fraudulent to creditors of debtor-subsidiaries, payments that were made by debtor-parent, absent any evidence that debtor-parent was acting as conduit between subsidiaries and lender in making these payments. 11 U.S.C.A. § 544(b)(1); Ky. Rev. Stat. Ann. § 378.020.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Claims could not be recharacterized as equity based on debtor's undercapitalization.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Knopf v. Sanford
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York.
Headnote: Under Chapter 7 of the Bankruptcy Code, corporations may not be discharged of their debts, and any successor or alter ego of these corporations will become liable for those obligations. 11 U.S.C.A. §§ 701 et seq.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Privileges. Wrongful-act exception applied to attorney-client communications made regarding sale of property in contravention of escrow order.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Falls Event Center LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Utah.
Headnote: When corporation is mere instrumentality or alter ego of bankrupt corporation with no independent existence of its own, equity favors disregarding the separate corporate entities, and it is proper to disregard their separate legal entities when such action is necessary to avoid fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Case Administration. Bankruptcy estates are substantively consolidated retroactive to date that corporate parent's Chapter 11 petition was filed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Shapow
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, C.D. California, San Fernando Valley Division.
Headnote: Even if California law were to permit outside reverse veil-piercing, creditor seeking to pierce the veil separating Chapter 7 debtor from corporate entities through which he offered physical therapy services, in order to deny debtor a discharge based on his alleged "false oaths" in failing to schedule accounts receivable belonging to corporate entities as assets on his bankruptcy schedules, did not satisfy burden of demonstrating grounds for veil-piercing; creditor presented no evidence that debtor's corporations diverted assets to detriment of creditors, commingled funds, or disregarded corporate formalities and failed to establish requisite unity of interest between debtor and corporations. 11 U.S.C.A. § 727(a)(4)(A).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Creditor failed to demonstrate any false oath in failing to schedules assets owned by debtor individually.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Fustolo
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Chapter 7 debtor's pervasive control over his closely-held, thinly-capitalized corporations, together with his intermingling of corporate and personal funds, was sufficient to permit application of alter ego doctrine, and to bring assets of corporations into bankruptcy estate, such that debtor's fraudulent postpetition transfer of corporate assets by conveying them to new entity for no consideration was sufficient to warrant denial of his discharge on fraudulent postpetition transfer theory. 11 U.S.C.A. § 727(a)(2)(B).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Cash-basis debtor, a CPA, is denied discharge based on inadequacy of his financial records.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Trujillo
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Chapter 7 trustee was not precluded from asserting alter ego claim under Florida law, based on allegations that debtor utilized various corporate entities and a Panamanian foundation to carry out fraudulent scheme intended to shield and conceal his assets from his creditors, even though debtor was not a shareholder of any of the corporate defendants; debtor and his wife were the only persons who ever received any distributions from foundation, notwithstanding debtor's transfer of his beneficial interest in foundation to his children.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Trustee was not barred from asserting alter ego claim under Florida law, even though debtor was not a shareholder of any of the corporate defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Wolf
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Alter ego claim asserted by Chapter 7 trustee in furtherance of a cause of action to avoid, as fraudulent transfer, a conveyance of assets not of debtor, but of wholly-owned corporation whose income he freely commingled with his own and used to pay his personal expenses, was asserted derivatively on behalf of debtor's ex-wife and other creditors injured by alleged fraudulent transfer, and not as successor in interest to debtor's prepetition causes of action; thus, trustee's claim, based on wholly-owned nature of corporation, on debtor's disregard of corporate formalities, and on debtor's alleged use of intercorporate transfers in attempt to defraud wife, was plausible under Illinois law and sufficient to support entry of default judgment in trustee's favor.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Debtor's son was, on fraudulent transfer or corporate waste theory, for full value of debtor's former 100% equity interest in company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Harrison v. Soroof International, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Recovery on former chief executive officer's (CEO) alter ego cause of action against parent company under Delaware law would benefit all of subsidiary's creditors, and thus such cause of action constituted general claim which was property of subsidiary's bankruptcy estate, since any finding that parent company was alter ego of subsidiary could have preclusive effect in future litigation and render parent company liable for any or all debts and obligations of subsidiary.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Former CEO's alter ego cause of action against parent company under Delaware law was property of subsidiary's bankruptcy estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Mongelluzzi
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division.
Headnote: Lender that accepted transfer of funds from Chapter 7 debtors' accounts in order to pay down loans of affiliated entities on which debtors were not liable, either as co-borrowers or guarantors, could not rely on veil-piercing theory in order to assert that debtors had received "reasonably equivalent value" for these funds transfers and to defend trustee's constructive fraudulent transfer claims, where lender failed to show that debtors' separate corporate existence was non-existent, that debtors were formed for improper purpose, or that debtors fraudulently or improperly used corporate form, and did not present evidence even of debtors' failure to observe corporate formalities. 11 U.S.C.A. § 544; Fla. Stat. Ann. § 726.106(1).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Fact issues regarding indirect benefit barred summary judgment on constructive fraudulent transfer claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: CBF Industria de Gusa S/A v. AMCI Holdings, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: As to the timing of insolvency on a veil piercing claim, the relevant inquiry for liability purposes is that of the transaction at issue.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Arbitration. Companies and individuals interrelated with buyer of pig iron were not deprived of full and fair opportunity to be heard.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Tegeler
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Chapter 7 debtors received direct personal benefits from transfers of their company's assets to another company, immediately after executing loan documents and despite express warranties to refrain from such transactions without first obtaining creditor's written consent, as required for debtors to be personally liable for company's debt to creditor under Texas veil-piercing statute; debtor-husband obtained 50% ownership interest in other company as a result of the transfers and became part of management of other company, and loan proceeds advanced by creditor to debtors' company ultimately ended up in other company's bank accounts and were used to pay other company's obligations. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debt arising from loan to Chapter 7 debtors' company, which debtors had personally guaranteed, was nondischargeable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Bernard L. Madoff Investment Securities LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Allegations in complaint filed by Securities Investment Protection Act (SIPA) trustee, regarding attorney's assumption of control over corporate investors in Ponzi scheme perpetrated by principal of bankrupt investment company at time when investors were inadequately capitalized, regarding his role as sole decisionmaker, who operated corporate investors for his personal benefit and freely used corporate funds to pay personal expenses, and regarding his knowledge of fraudulent nature of trading activity that generated the funds used for these payments, stated plausible claim to pierce corporate veil and to hold attorney personally liable in adversary proceeding brought by trustee to recover prepetition payments to these investors.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. SIPA trustee stated basis for inferring that investors in Madoff Ponzi scheme knew of the fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Cortlandt Street Recovery Corp. v. Bonderman
Court: Court of Appeals of New York.
Headnote: Indenture trustee's demand to pierce corporate veil under alter ego theory of liability was not duplicative of fraudulent conveyance claim against private equity firms that controlled parent company of issuers and guarantor of payment-in-kind (PIK) notes governed by indenture, in trustee's action alleging that firms and their individual partners used allegedly fraudulent conveyances that left issuers, guarantor, and parent company insolvent and unable to pay their creditors, including noteholders, since any argument to pierce corporate veil was not cause of action in itself, but was dependent on action against corporation, and trustee alleged existence of corporate debt and that debt was created by fraudulent conveyances that left issuers and guarantor insolvent.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Parties. Indenture conferred standing on trustee to bring action against private equity firms that controlled parent company of issuers and guarantor of notes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: City of Almaty v. Ablyazov
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Although New York law does not recognize creditor's remedy for money damages against parties who were neither transferees of assets nor beneficiaries of fraudulent conveyance, creditor may proceed against non-parties under corporate veil-piercing theory.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Fraudulent Transfers. Kazakh city sufficiently pled plausible veil-piercing theory of liability to preclude dismissal of fraudulent conveyance claims against former mayor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: City of Almaty v. Ablyazov
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, city in Kazakhstan and bank, as formerly state-owned institution based in Kazakhstan, sufficiently pled plausible veil-piercing theory of liability to preclude dismissal of their fraudulent conveyance claims against former mayor, his son, and former bank chairman by alleging that defendants formed special purpose vehicle to mask their efforts to invest in real estate opportunities in United States, that vehicle was controlled by their agent, that vehicle's investments were funded by defendants' ill-gotten gains, that vehicle was itself insolvent, and that vehicle executed assignments cited in fraudulent conveyance claims on roundly unfavorable, below-market terms. N.Y. Debt. and Cred. Law §§ 273, 273-a, 275, 276, 279.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Fraudulent Transfers. Kazakh city sufficiently pled plausible veil-piercing theory of liability to preclude dismissal of fraudulent conveyance claims against former mayor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Highland CDO Opportunity Master Fund, L.P. v. Citibank, N.A.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, constructive fraudulent transfers, even when made to debtor's owners, do not constitute per se wrong for veil-piercing purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Investment fund's management company was not liable under veil piercing theory for fund's breach of agreements governing credit default swaps.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Madeoy
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Maryland, at Greenbelt.
Headnote: Allegations in Chapter 7 trustee's complaint, that debtor had concocted scheme to make it appear that he had no assets by creating sham entities under names of his wife and longtime friend to hold his assets, entities which were all undercapitalized, ignored corporate formalities, failed to keep business records, and freely commingled business and personal assets at apparent direction of debtor's wife and friend, but with the debtor actually calling the shots and continuing to retain beneficial ownership of assets, stated alter ego claim that was plausible on its face as to these alleged sham entities, but not as to trust that was formed postpetition and operated under control of its trustee.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. No recovery for conspiring to commit fraudulent transfer by nontransferees and nonbeneficiaries.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Matter of Hilsman
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Georgia, Athens Division.
Headnote: Homeowner, which had filed complaint against Chapter 7 debtor for determination that debt arising out of construction of house by company of which debtor was sole officer, shareholder, and director was nondischargeable, failed to show that, under Georgia law, bankruptcy court should pierce company's corporate veil and hold debtor personally liable for the debt; there was no evidence that debtor abused the corporate form, as his company had its own bank account, its funds were not commingled with debtor's funds, debtor never used corporate funds to pay his separate personal expenses, and company had separate office, filed separate tax returns, and, until it was dissolved, maintained its registration with the state, and neither debtor's failure to remember exact location of corporate records, failure to hold annual corporate meetings, or failure to remember why he had written certain checks from corporate bank account justified piercing veil. 11 U.S.C.A. § 523(a)(2)(A).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debtor's promise that he would complete construction of house by specified date was not a false representation for nondischargeability purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Performance Food Group Company, LLC v. ARBA Care Center of Bloomington, LLC
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Third District.
Headnote: Just because two entities are alter egos does not make them both debtors entitled to an automatic stay in a bankruptcy proceeding, based on only one of them having filed a bankruptcy petition, but, rather, it simply means they are liable for each other's debts. 11 U.S.C.A. § 362.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Debtor Protections. LLCs were not included in scope of automatic stay created when alter ego LLCs, predecessors in interest to real properties, filed for bankruptcy.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Sigma–Tech Sales, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida, Fort Lauderdale Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, president was alter ego of Chapter 7 corporation, and thus was liable for its debts, where he dominated and controlled debtor to such an extent that it enjoyed no independent existence, president improperly diverted debtor's assets and revenue to successor entities that he had incorporated to avoid paying debtor's creditors, and continue supporting president's personal lifestyle.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Under Florida law, president was alter ego of Chapter 7 corporation, and thus was liable for its debts.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re LLS America LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate form could be disregarded pursuant to the alter ego doctrine under Washington law, in avoidance proceeding brought by Chapter 11 bankruptcy trustee against Canadian company that had funneled investors' funds into bankruptcy debtor's Ponzi scheme, given showing that the corporate form was intentionally used to violate or evade a duty and that disregarding the corporate form was necessary to prevent unjustified loss to the injured party. 11 U.S.C.A. § 548.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Company that funneled investors funds into Chapter 11 debtor's Ponzi scheme did not act in good faith.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Rutherlan Enterprises, Inc. v. Zettler Hardware
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporation was not insolvent when it sold computer system to purchaser, under Ohio law, for purposes of establishing alter ego theory in breach of contract action.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Plaintiff in breach of contract action failed to establish alter ego theory, under Ohio law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Coppaken
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Corporate veil which separated Chapter 7 debtor-husband from corporation in which he had 99% ownership interest, with the other 1% interest being held by silent investor, could be ignored, such that assets of corporation were also assets of estate, and corporation's sale of its sole ownership interest in limited liability company (LLC) to debtor's son was in nature of postpetition transfer of estate property by debtor, where debtor, following establishment of corporation, essentially operated it as sole proprietorship, did not bother to adhere to corporate formalities when filing reports with appropriate authorities, and took all of proceeds from son's purchase of LLC for his and his wife's sole benefit, with no sales proceeds being paid over to corporation or to this silent 1% investor. 11 U.S.C.A. §§ 541(a)(1), 727(a)(2)(B).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Conversion of nonexempt asset into exempt homestead warranted limitation on state law homestead exemption.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Ritz
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Chapter 7 debtor's fraudulent transfers of $1,161,279.90 out of company he financially controlled, which had purchased electronic device components from creditor, and into the accounts of other entities that debtor controlled were made primarily for debtor's personal benefit, as required for debtor to be personally liable for company's debt to creditor under Texas's veil-piercing statute; debtor admitted under oath that he received a personal benefit from the transfers that he orchestrated, and once the funds were transferred, debtor put himself in a much better position, as one debtor-controlled entity had much more cash to pay off a $1 million loan that debtor had personally guaranteed, while resulting in company not paying the debt it owed to creditor, which debtor had not personally guaranteed. 11 U.S.C.A. § 523(a)(2)(A); Tex. Bus. & C. Code §§ 21.223(b), 24.005(b).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debtor's transfers out of company he financially controlled were made with actual intent to hinder, delay, or defraud creditor under TUFTA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Ritz
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Chapter 7 debtor's personal liability under Texas veil-piercing statute for debt arising from transfers of $1,161,279.90 out of company he financially controlled, which had purchased electronic device components from creditor, and into the accounts of other entities that debtor controlled, fell within discharge exception for false pretenses, a false representation, or actual fraud, even though debtor himself did not personally receive the funds that he transferred out of company's account. 11 U.S.C.A. § 523(a)(2)(A).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debtor's transfers out of company he financially controlled were made with actual intent to hinder, delay, or defraud creditor under TUFTA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Cohen v. Schroeder
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, mere insolvency is not enough to allow piercing of the corporate veil, since if creditors could enter judgments against shareholders every time that a corporation becomes unable to pay its debts as they become due, the limited liability characteristic of the corporate form would be meaningless.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing the corporate veil to impose personal liability on majority owner in small, privately-held Delaware corporation was unwarranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Cohen v. Schroeder
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In a veil piercing case under Delaware law, insolvency and undercapitalization are factors to be considered in determining whether the corporation engaged in conduct that unjustly shields its assets from its creditors.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing the corporate veil to impose personal liability on majority owner in small, privately-held Delaware corporation was unwarranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Ryan Racing, LLC v. Gentilozzi
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Judgment debtor was undercapitalized and unable to pay its creditors without funding from its owner, weighing in favor of piercing corporate veil, under Michigan law, so as to permit judgment creditor to collect from owner judgment it obtained in breach of contract action, where judgment debtor was insolvent until it transferred its assets to owner's new company, its liabilities substantially exceeded its assets for years, there were no capital contributions to judgment debtor after year it was incorporated, judgment debtor consistently relied upon loans from owner to fund its business, and, because it was insolvent, it was able to pick and choose which creditors to pay.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment debtor was undercapitalized, weighing in favor of piercing corporate veil to permit judgment creditor to collect judgment from judgment debtor's owner.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Stillwater Asset Backed Offshore Fund Ltd.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Limited liability company (LLC) created by debtor investment fund and others to liquidate their assets could not use alter ego theory to permit another of debtor's corporate parent's other funds to assert fraudulent transfer claims in debtor's Chapter 11 case without pooling other assets or liabilities and without combining creditor groups, even if funds commingled assets and had common manager, where there was recognition of corporate formalities and corporate separateness in executions of participation agreements and in formation of separate companies to hold particular loans or properties. 11 U.S.C.A. § 544.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Real Property. Debtor that had owned participation interests in mortgage loans made by third party had no property interest in mortgaged properties.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Pocius
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Neither the control that individual exercised over limited liability company (LLC) that was initial recipient of fraudulent transfer of property of Chapter 7 debtor nor any general, amorphous benefit that he realized as result of transfer, which was basically indistinguishable from ordinary benefits of equity ownership, were sufficient to support alter ego claim under Pennsylvania law and to permit holding him strictly liable as initial transferee on fraudulent transfer. 11 U.S.C.A. §§ 548, 550(a)(1).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. LLC's manager was not liable as initial transferee or entity for whose benefit fraudulent transfer to LLC was made.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Dieffenbacher
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: In order to include a corporation's assets in its shareholder's bankruptcy estate, it is necessary to reverse pierce the corporate veil. 11 U.S.C.A. § 541(a).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Contempt. Contempt sanction could not be calculated merely by multiplying daily fine by days of noncompliance.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re: Aéropostale, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Chapter 11 debtor retailer of casual apparel and accessories failed to demonstrate that one of its largest merchandise suppliers was the alter ego of lenders, as would justify piercing the corporate veil under Delaware law for debtors to seek relief against lenders for alleged inequitable conduct by supplier; while supplier had a management services contract with an affiliate of one of the lenders, supplier had its own offices, phone numbers, technology systems, bank accounts, and e-mail addresses, separate from those of lender, as well as had financing in its own name.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Creditor's claim would not be equitable subordinated based on allegations that creditor breached sourcing agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Matter of Ritz
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, as predicted by the Court of Appeals, a fraudulent transfer under the Texas Uniform Fraudulent Transfer Act (TUFTA), if made with the actual intent to hinder, delay, or defraud, is sufficient to satisfy the "actual fraud" requirement of the Texas veil-piercing statute. Tex. Bus. Org. Code §§ 21.223(b), 24.005.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Establishing that a transfer is fraudulent under TUFTA's actual fraud prong is sufficient to satisfy the actual fraud requirement for veil-piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Crabtree
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: As general rule, "property of the estate" does not include assets owned by corporation in which debtor holds an interest; however, court may, under appropriate circumstances, pierce the corporate veil when determining whether corporate property constitutes "property of the estate." 11 U.S.C.A. § 541(a).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Conversion of nonexempt assets to homestead triggers limitation on exemption rights.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Crabtree
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Corporate property can be treated as property of individual debtor's bankruptcy estate pursuant to an alter ego doctrine. 11 U.S.C.A. § 541(a).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Conversion of nonexempt assets to homestead triggers limitation on exemption rights.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Crabtree
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: If veil is pierced that separates individual debtor from corporation, corporate property becomes "property of the estate." 11 U.S.C.A. § 541(a).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Conversion of nonexempt assets to homestead triggers limitation on exemption rights.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Crabtree
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Veil separating Chapter 7 debtors from family-owned corporation could be pierced, such that gratuitous prepetition transfer of corporate assets to debtors' children and debtors' church could be regarded as transfers of debtors' own assets, of kind potentially sufficient to support denial of their discharge on fraudulent prepetition transfer theory, given debtors' use of corporate accounts to pay host of personal expenses, lack of corporate records, and debtors' failure to observe corporate formalities; corporation was merely a facade, that served as alter ego of debtors. 11 U.S.C.A. § 727(a)(2)(A).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Conversion of nonexempt assets to homestead triggers limitation on exemption rights.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re DBSI, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Idaho.
Headnote: Reverse piercing of the corporate veil is a rarity, and it is rarer yet in bankruptcy.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. LLC's fraudulent transfers of money to satisfy income tax liabilities of its owner-members were not received by IRS for reasonably equivalent value.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Carroll
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Creditor failed to establish that Chapter 7 debtor should be liable for his company's debt on an alter ego theory under California law, given that creditor presented no evidence that debtor and his company lacked the corporate separation that would permit employment of the doctrine.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debt from debtor's failure to disclose during course of renovation project that certain subcontractors were not paid was nondischargeable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Lim v. Miller Parking Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Corporate entities which, while owned by members of same family, had separate historical roots, kept separate books and observed adequate corporate formalities, were not alter egos, and veil that separated them could not be pierced at request of trustee of bankruptcy estate of first company, especially where, to extent that there had been flow of cash between companies, it generally flowed from second company to the first, in form of loans that shareholders of second corporation, the children of long-time principal of the first, had made to support their father's lavish spending; if first corporation wound up penniless, it was because its principal took everything it had, and more, for himself, and while second company's support may have allowed this bloodletting to continue longer than it otherwise could have, this did not amount to evidence of fraud or support veil-piercing.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Transfers did not support piercing veil that separated debtor from related company.

Title: Continental Cas. Co. v. Symons
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Indiana law, evidence supported decision to pierce corporate veil and hold shareholders liable for crop insurance business buyers' fraudulent transfer of resale proceeds to related corporations to seller's detriment, even though seller was sophisticated market actor and the corporations had different names, different directors and officers, different business purposes, and different locations; family of shareholders controlled the corporations and operated them as their mere instrumentality to enrich themselves at seller's expense, they gave same address to regulators, corporate formalities were both cosmetic and ignored, the corporations all seem to have raided one another with some degree of impunity, and assets were commingled.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Court could pierce veil and hold shareholders liable for crop insurance business buyers' fraudulent transfer of resale proceeds to related corporations.

Title: Continental Cas. Co. v. Symons
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Indiana law, heavily regulated nature of insurance industry did not preclude piercing corporate veil of insurance companies involved in purchase of crop insurance business, resale of it, and fraudulent transfer of resale proceeds to seller's detriment.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Court could pierce veil and hold shareholders liable for crop insurance business buyers' fraudulent transfer of resale proceeds to related corporations.

Title: In re Tolomeo
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Bankruptcy court would recommend that district court find, under Illinois law, that corporations owned solely by Chapter 7 debtor's spouse were the alter egos of debtor and that their corporate veils should be pierced; debtor controlled the corporations with no input from other directors and without arm's length relationships among related entities, assets and funds were considerably commingled, and corporate records and formalities were not maintained, and failure to pierce the corporate veil under the circumstances would allow debtor to shield assets from administration and distribution in the bankruptcy case.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Bankruptcy court would recommend that district court find corporations were alter egos of debtor and that their corporate veils should be pierced.

Title: Carney v. Horion Investments Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Receiver, appointed in proceeding ancillary to Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) civil enforcement proceeding to recover property for victims of alleged Ponzi scheme, made prima facie case for piercing corporate veil of company that allegedly received fraudulent transfers from Ponzi scheme operator, allowing discovery into ownership and control of the company to determine whether service on its owner was legally sufficient; receiver alleged that owner was managing or general agent of both companies, that neither company had separate corporate identify but that they were alter egos for owner, and that companies were sham entities formed for the purpose of receiving fraudulent transfers. Fed.Rules Civ.Proc.Rule 4(h)(1)(B), 28 U.S.C.A.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Parties. Receiver had standing under CUFTA to bring claims on behalf of receivership entities to recovery property for victims of Ponzi scheme.

Title: In re Opus East, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Insolvency alone is not sufficient basis for piercing veil that separates insolvent company from its owners.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Veil could not be pierced to augment estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re LLS America, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Washington.
Headnote: Owner of company, a lender that received payments from debtor operating a Ponzi scheme, used the company as an alter ego, warranting corporate-veil piercing under Washington law to hold owner liable for any judgment imposed against lender in Chapter 11 trustee's action against lender, where company's banking records indicated that owner used the company's coffers as an extension of her personal account, including multiple months during which funds were transferred from an account in owner's name into company's account with the exact same amounts withdrawn again shortly thereafter, and transfers from debtor frequently were transferred or withdrawn from company shortly after checks from debtor had been deposited, and such practices often left only a small amount of funds in company's account, which at times contained less than $50.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Owner of company, a lender that received payments from debtor operating a Ponzi scheme, used company as alter ego, warranting corporate-veil piercing under Washington law to hold owner liable for any judgment imposed against lender in Chapter 11 trustee's action against lender.

Title: In re McCauley
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Utah.
Headnote: Chapter 7 trustee failed to establish that limited liability company (LLC) belonged to debtor based on alter ego theory under Utah law; although debtor was permitted by manager of LLC to live on real property owned by LLC and was given unfettered access to LLC account to pay costs associated with occupancy and maintenance of the property, there was little or no evidence that debtor conducted his and LLC's business on an interchangeable or joint basis as if they were one.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Trustee failed to establish that limited liability company (LLC) belonged to debtor based on alter ego theory under Utah law.
