Title: In re Joseph Walker & Company, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. South Carolina.
Headnote: Piercing of Chapter 7 debtor's corporate veil was not appropriate under South Carolina law, in action against debtor's parent company and dual directors brought by cotton gins that had entered into prepetition contracts with debtor; under first prong of DeWitt test, even when viewed in light most favorable to plaintiffs, evidence was insufficient to show that debtor was merely a facade for parent company's operations, given ample evidence showing debtor's adherence to corporate formalities, including properly conducted board meetings complete with official minutes, maintenance of books and records, and the existence of bank accounts and lines of credit owned and controlled exclusively by debtor and not its individual members, as well as report of defendants' solvency expert showed that, during the relevant time, debtor was not grossly undercapitalized and was capable of paying its operating expenses.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Representations made by debtor's dual director concerning debtor's ability to perform contract did not rise to level of actionable fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Joseph Walker & Company, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. South Carolina.
Headnote: Evidence showing that Chapter 7 debtor paid its parent company management fees for the advice and experience of its directors, received loans from parent for the purpose of meeting margin calls, employed as directors several individuals who also served as directors for parent, and participated in business cooperatives with parent, without more, was insufficient to demonstrate the "total domination and control" necessary for application of the alter ego doctrine under South Carolina law, given evidence that debtor maintained separate bank accounts, obtained credit lines based solely upon its own assets and liabilities, obtained and possessed its own federal tax identification number and accordingly paid taxes when they became due, employed legal counsel and accounting firms separate of those used by parent, and maintained the same general management and employee structure both before and after parent became its majority shareholder.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Representations made by debtor's dual director concerning debtor's ability to perform contract did not rise to level of actionable fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Joseph Walker & Company, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. South Carolina.
Headnote: Under South Carolina law, majority shareholder of Chapter 7 debtor could not be held liable for breach of contract for any alleged repudiation of debtor's prepetition "ginner contracts" with cotton gins; absent a finding that parent company functioned as the alter ego of debtor, parent stood in the position of a third-party to the ginner contracts, and the mere presence of dual directors on both entities' boards did not provide a basis for imposition of liability.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Representations made by debtor's dual director concerning debtor's ability to perform contract did not rise to level of actionable fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Joseph Walker & Company, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. South Carolina.
Headnote: Under South Carolina law, Chapter 7 debtor did not function as the agent of its parent company and two individuals who were dual directors of the two entities and, thus, parent and directors did not ratify debtor's prepetition ginning contracts with cotton gins and could not be held vicariously liable for the contracts' alleged breach; mere fact that parent at times loaned debtor money to meet margin calls did not, in and of itself, signal financial dependence, the evidence showed instead that debtor functioned independent of parent, given evidence of debtor's adherence to corporate formalities, independent employee and management structure, and autonomous execution of contracts and lending agreements separate and apart from the control of parent and the dual directors, and so cotton gins failed to establish an agency relationship between debtor on the one hand and parent and dual directors on the other.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Representations made by debtor's dual director concerning debtor's ability to perform contract did not rise to level of actionable fraud.

Title: Ng v. Adler
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Bankruptcy court did not err in piercing corporate veil under New York law and finding Chapter 7 debtor, who was sole shareholder, officer, and director of five corporations, could be held liable for debts of the corporations; corporations failed to exercise even most basic corporate formalities, corporations were inadequately capitalized and likely insolvent at all times, debtor used his wife's credit for corporate purposes and repaid her from corporate funds for his benefit, debtor created network of entities that were not intended to be independent profit centers, and corporations, at debtor's direction, entered into transactions with creditors which debtor knew or should have known that corporations could not honor.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Bankruptcy Court did not err in piercing corporate veil and holding debtor liable for debts of corporations.

Title: Flame S.A. v. Industrial Carriers, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Norfolk Division.
Headnote: Under Virginia law, a shipping company fraudulently transferred a shipping vessel to an alter ego corporate entity with intent to hinder or delay the shipping company's judgment creditors, where the transfer was not supported by any consideration, but resulted in a substantial profit for the alter ego entity, and the shipping company immediately attempted to file for bankruptcy after the transfer. West's V.C.A. § 55–80.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Attachment. Defendants lacked minimum contacts with forum for exercise of personal jurisdiction in admiralty action involving attachment of a vessel.

Title: In re Lehmann
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: In order for property of an independent corporation to be deemed "property of the debtor," the fraudulent prepetition transfer of which may provide basis for denying debtor a discharge, plaintiff must prove that the corporation's property is debtor's property by reverse veil-piercing. 11 U.S.C.A. § 727(a)(2)(A).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Corporate property transfer did not provide basis for denial of individual debtor's discharge.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Harman
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: In order to state plausible alter ego claim under Georgia law, Chapter 7 trustee had to allege: (1) that debtor disregarded respective corporate entities so as to make them mere instrumentalities for transaction of debtor's own affairs; (2) that there is such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporations and debtor no longer exist; and (3) that recognizing corporate entities would promote injustice or fraud.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Case Administration. Trustee stated plausible claim for substantive consolidation.

Title: In re Palisades at West Paces Imaging Center, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Corporation and limited liability partnership (LLP) that acted as transferees on fraudulent transfers made by Chapter 7 debtor were alter egos of spouses who owned and controlled the corporation and LLP, so that spouses could be held personally liable on alter ego theory for any judgment entered against corporation and LLP, given evidence that corporate and/or partnership funds were used to purchase vacation home in name of husband, and to furnish and remodel it, as well as to purchase motor vehicle for spouses and to pay various personal expenses on their behalf; evidence showed that spouses had disregarded the separate identities of corporation and LLP and used them as mere instrumentalities for transaction of their own personal affairs. 11 U.S.C.A. § 550.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Concealed payments for no consideration were avoidable as actually fraudulent to creditors.

Title: In re Palisades at West Paces Imaging Center, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Chapter 7 trustee failed to satisfy burden of showing that limited partnership that ultimately received some of the funds fraudulently transferred by debtor was mere alter ego of its owners, so that owners could not be held personally liable on alter ego theory for any judgment entered against partnership, notwithstanding evidence of partnership's failure to file any income tax returns and of some commingling of funds of partnership and one of its owners; trustee failed to introduce evidence of the use of funds generally in partnership, and it was unclear from evidence in record whether the owners against whom trustee asserted alter ego claims were sole owners of limited partnership or whether there were other ownership interests. 11 U.S.C.A. § 550.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Concealed payments for no consideration were avoidable as actually fraudulent to creditors.

Title: Tommy Lee Handbags Mfg. Ltd. v. 1948 Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, successor corporation and its predecessor did not operate as single economic entity, and thus successor was not subject to liability for predecessor's debts under alter ego theory, where successor was not established until one month after predecessor was insolvent.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST - Bid-Rigging. Unsecured creditor lacked antitrust standing to pursue bid rigging claims.

Title: Brown v. Knowles
Court: Supreme Court of Alaska.
Headnote: Discharge of closely-held corporation's personal liability on the debt did not prevent the superior court from establishing the corporation's indebtedness for the sole purpose of holding the president liable, and thus, the court could pierce the corporate veil to hold the president liable.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Employee's veil-piercing claim did not become property of the corporation's bankruptcy estate.

Title: Tap Holdings, LLC v. Orix Finance Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Promissory note holders stated a cause of action to pierce corporate veil of new corporation to which maker's lenders allegedly siphoned maker's assets, cutting off holders' ability to collect on the notes, by alleging that maker had been effectively extinguished for purposes of application of the mere continuation doctrine, since its sole remaining employee was a dissolution officer, that there was a de facto merger between maker and new corporation, and that maker was rendered insolvent by transfer of its assets to new corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Promissory note holders stated a claim against maker's lenders based on piercing the corporate veil theory.

Title: In re Checiek
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, TAMPA DIVISION.
Headnote: Whether Chapter 7 debtors were permitted to pierce the corporate veil to claim exemption in truck owned by their wholly-owned company was determined by Florida law where the company was incorporated in Florida and the activities relating to debtors' claim of exemption occurred there. 11 U.S.C.A. § 522(d)(6).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Debtors could not claim tool of trade exemption in truck owned by their wholly-owned company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Checiek
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, TAMPA DIVISION.
Headnote: Under Florida law, as predicted by the bankruptcy court, Chapter 7 debtors, who sought to claim "tool of trade" exemption in truck owned by their wholly-owned corporation, could not "reverse veil pierce" in the absence of evidence that the corporate form was used for a fraudulent or improper purpose; there was no record evidence that the corporate form was used for such a purpose, as debtor, a truck driver, set up the company for a legitimate purpose, namely, to own the truck that he used in his business, debtors were not injured by use of corporate form, but presumably benefited from buying and owning vehicle in a separate corporate entity, and there was no evidence that lender or truck's seller required debtor to incorporate in connection with sale of truck to avoid usury laws, and use of veil piercing in the manner sought by debtors would injure debtors' innocent creditors, who would receive $13,140.47 less in this case if veil piercing were permitted. 11 U.S.C.A. § 522(d)(6).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Debtors could not claim tool of trade exemption in truck owned by their wholly-owned company.

Title: JMB Mfg., Inc. v. Child Craft, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Indiana, New Albany Division.
Headnote: Parent corporation of children's furniture manufacturer did not orchestrate a fraudulent transfer of manufacturer's assets to the parent corporation at less than fair market value to make manufacturer both insolvent and judgment proof, as required for court to pierce corporate veil in wood sub-assembly supplier's action against manufacturer; the manufacturer specifically deducted the sale of the assets to the parent corporation from its counterclaim for damages against the supplier.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. A fact issue existed as to whether a manufacturer waived its contractual remedies under the perfect tender rule.

Title: In re Montalbano
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Corporate employees who were not paid when corporation, after years of having its operations underwritten by its sole shareholder and chief executive officer (CEO) through loans and capital contributions aggregating more than $36 million, finally ceased to operate when shareholder elected to forego making any additional advances, failed to satisfy burden of establishing any convincing reason why corporate veil should be pierced and shareholder should be held personally liable for their unpaid wages, such that wage claims filed by employees in shareholder's individual Chapter 7 case had to be disallowed as unenforceable under applicable nonbankruptcy law; no evidence was presented of any fraud or misappropriation of corporate funds, and bankruptcy court would not subject debtor-shareholder to personal liability for unpaid wages solely because he had provided much needed financing that, for a time, enabled employees to receive more wages than they would otherwise have received from corporate employer. 11 U.S.C.A. § 502(b)(1).
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Hours and Wages. Corporate principal was not personally liable for Illinois Wage Payment and Collection Act violations.

Title: Wiand v. Morgan
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division.
Headnote: In a receivership proceeding, there need not be an artificial distinction between the property of a Ponzi scheme perpetrator and the property of his alter ego corporations used to perpetrate the scheme.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Fraud. Ponzi scheme operator had intent to hinder, delay, or defraud creditors in receiver's suit seeking to claw back false profit.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Bash v. Textron Financial Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, corporate form of "special purpose entity" (SPE) created by Chapter 7 debtor could be disregarded in assessing trustee's avoidance claims against lender that had entered into prepetition revolving loan facility with debtor through SPE; trustee alleged that SPE had no employees, used same address, telephone and facsimile numbers, and email notice as debtor, controlled no bank accounts, filed no tax returns, and was completely incapable of servicing customer accounts that it "purchased" via the parties' transaction, that debtor received the subject loan funds directly from lender, that debtor cleared with lender which accounts debtor should purchase and transfer to SPE, and that loan funds borrowed from lender were directly routed to debtor-owned account for use by debtor's chief executive officer in furtherance of Ponzi scheme, and it could be fairly inferred that debtor set up SPE to further its fraudulent scheme and that SPE acted as mere facade for debtor. 11 U.S.C.A. §§ 544, 548, 550, 551.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Trustee could use Ponzi scheme presumption to satisfy fraudulent intent requirement of fraudulent conveyance claim.

Title: Abdulla v. Klosinski
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Georgia, Augusta Division.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, precondition to piercing the corporate veil and holding individual shareholders liable on corporate debtor is insolvency on part of corporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Professionals. Bankruptcy attorney for debtor-corporation did not have attorney-client relationship with its principal.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Hoffmann
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, mere fact that Chapter 7 debtor was the owner and sole officer of two companies, and that companies may have engaged in some sloppy accounting, was insufficient basis for piercing corporate veil and holding debtor liable on postpetition judgments entered against corporations.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Sellers justifiably relied on representations contradicted by close, lawyerly reading of closing documents.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: First Keystone Consultants, Inc. v. Schlesinger Elec. Contractors, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Consulting firm's officers and sole shareholder exercised sufficient control over firm to have "dominated" it with respect to challenged conveyances, thus supporting piercing corporate veil under New York law to hold officers and sole shareholder personally liable on electrical contractor's New York–law claims for fraudulent conveyances, in action related to firm's drawing of advance profits from parties' joint venture; firm observed no corporate formalities and exercised no business discretion independent of officers' will, firm and officers freely transferred money to each other, firm was inadequately capitalized and insolvent, and officers used firm's funds for their personal use. N.Y.McKinney's Debtor and Creditor Law §§ 273, 273–a, 276, 278.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Officers and Directors. Contractor was entitled to money judgment against corporation and its officers on New York claims for fraudulent conveyances.

Title: First Keystone Consultants, Inc. v. Schlesinger Elec. Contractors, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, the diversion of funds to make a corporation judgment–proof constitutes a wrong for the purposes of determining whether the corporate veil should be pierced.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Officers and Directors. Contractor was entitled to money judgment against corporation and its officers on New York claims for fraudulent conveyances.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: First Keystone Consultants, Inc. v. Schlesinger Elec. Contractors, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Consulting firm's officers and sole shareholder used their domination of firm to commit fraud or wrong that harmed electrical contractor, thus supporting piercing corporate veil under New York law to hold officers and sole shareholder personally liable on electrical contractor's New York–law claims for fraudulent conveyances, in action related to firm's drawing of advance profits from parties' joint venture; officers' and sole shareholder's domination of firm led to diversion of at least $1,094,600 from firm's bank accounts to officers' and sole shareholder's personal bank accounts, thereby rendering firm insolvent and unable to pay judgment awarded to contractor in parties' arbitration. N.Y.McKinney's Debtor and Creditor Law §§ 273, 273–a, 276, 278.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Officers and Directors. Contractor was entitled to money judgment against corporation and its officers on New York claims for fraudulent conveyances.

Title: In re Teleservices Group, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Michigan.
Headnote: Fund transfers from bank account of bankrupt shell corporation that was established by its principal solely for purposes of perpetrating fraud on financial institutions, leasing companies and other such entities in business of providing funding for acquisition of equipment, by posing as seller of nonexistent computer equipment to another entity that was also owned by same principal and that approached the defrauded entities to obtain equipment loans, represented transfers of interest of this bankrupt shell corporation in property, such as trustee of its Chapter 7 estate could attempt to recover on fraudulent transfer grounds, though corporation had no officers, directors or employees and existed only to facilitate fraud perpetrated by its principal by accepting proceeds of equipment loans fraudulently obtained by its sister company and then funneling these proceeds back to another account maintained by sister company to fund sister company's operations and lifestyle of their common principal; alter ego doctrine could not be applied to treat account from which challenged transfers were made as actually belonging to sister company, since success of fraud depended on maintaining illusion that shell company was independent seller of computer equipment, and since application of doctrine, to prevent trustee from recovering transfers for benefit of financial institutions and leasing companies that were defrauded, would not prevent, but actually promote, injustice. 11 U.S.C.A. § 548(a).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Bank was transferee on challenged transfers from moment of deposit.

Title: Perlman v. Wells Fargo Bank, N.A.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Related entities created and used to perpetrate a Ponzi scheme suffered an injury, as required for their receiver to have standing to assert claims based on torts that occurred when perpetrators of the scheme embezzled funds deposited into the entities, when perpetrators removed assets from entities for an unauthorized purpose, although they purportedly were not injured when perpetrators solicited investments, since they were allegedly merely alter egos of perpetrators.
Document Preview: FINANCE AND BANKING - Banks. Receiver for entities used to perpetrate Ponzi scheme stated aiding and abetting liability claims against bank.

Title: In re Ellis
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division.
Headnote: Materialman that dealt exclusively with contracting company that individual Chapter 7 debtor owned, and that did not obtain guarantee from debtor for company's payment obligation, was not owed any debt by debtor, such as might be excepted from discharge, given complete lack of evidence that debtor so abused corporate form that he should be regarded as company's alter ego; even if debtor had taken money out of company while company was insolvent, such conduct, without more, was insufficient to make him a corporate alter ego. 11 U.S.C.A. § 523(a).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Misrepresentation did not enable debtor to obtain supplier's property.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: U.S. ex rel. King v. Solvay S.A.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Insolvency is a precondition to piercing the corporate veil under Georgia law.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - United States. Relators failed to state claim against drug manufacturer under False Claims Act for conspiracy to promote off-label drugs.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Ritz
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Creditor of corporation controlled by Chapter 7 debtor failed to establish that debtor engaged in actual fraud, as required under Texas law to pierce the corporate veil and hold debtor personally liable for corporation's debt; there was no evidence that debtor made a material misrepresentation to creditor, the record reflected instead that the only communication that debtor had with creditor occurred after creditor had already shipped product to corporation, and creditor thus could not have relied on the representation before shipping the product. 11 U.S.C.A. § 523(a)(2)(A); V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Creditor of corporation controlled by debtor failed to establish actual fraud, as required to pierce the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Moll Industries, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: In order to establish alter ego claim under Delaware law against upstream entity with equity interest in shareholders of debtor's corporate parent, Chapter 11 trustee did not have to pierce every layer of corporate structure separating debtor from this upstream equity holder, but had to show only that debtor and upstream equity holder operated as single economic entity, and that element of injustice or unfairness was present.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Lenders' secured claims could not be recharacterized as equity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Moll Industries, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Alleged failure to observe corporate formalities, sharing of officers and/or directors, and failure to pay dividends, as set forth in alter ego complaint filed by unsecured creditors' committee, would not of itself support piercing of corporate veil between Chapter 11 debtor-corporation and upstream equity holder that had interest in shareholders of corporation's parent.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Lenders' secured claims could not be recharacterized as equity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re American Remanufacturers, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: As a matter of equity, corporate Chapter 7 debtors, which sold remanufactured automotive parts, had to be treated as single entity with respect to related retailers' defenses against estates' common claim for payment of accounts receivable, without regard to any artificial distinction among debtors, even though retailers treated debtors as separate sellers in their own books and records, where debtors' estates and corporate forms were inextricably integrated, which reflected manner in which debtors maintained their financial records, trustee administered debtors at all times as single entity, with no distinction between assets, liabilities, creditors, distributions, or accounts of each entity, and all claims against debtors, no matter how filed, were reflected in court's records as claims against one debtor's estate.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Corporate debtors had to be treated as single entity for purposes of retailers' defenses against common claim for payment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Xenerga, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Orlando Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, Chapter 7 trustee, acting on behalf of corporate debtor and its creditors, could pursue alter ego claims to pierce the corporate veil and hold debtor's principals liable where principals allegedly manipulated debtor specifically to injure debtor's creditors.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Proposed compromise, which attempted to settle claims that were not estate property, could not be approved.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Wooley v. Lucksinger
Court: Supreme Court of Louisiana.
Headnote: Receivers of Texas and Oklahoma corporations which were health maintenance organizations (HMOs) and were related to Louisiana HMO corporation, sought to hold seller of corporations liable for seller's own actions, rather than as a shareholder in corporations or for the actions of the corporations themselves, and, thus, under Texas law, statute that provided the exclusive method for piercing the corporate veil was inapplicable to receivers' claims against seller. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21 (Expired).
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Choice of Law. Texas law applied to tort claims of HMOs' receivers in action by Insurance Commissioner in which they intervened.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Wooley v. Lucksinger
Court: Supreme Court of Louisiana.
Headnote: Texas statute barring shareholder from being liable for fraud committed by corporation, unless shareholder caused the corporation to be used to perpetrate, and did perpetrate, an actual fraud on plaintiff primarily for shareholder's direct personal benefit, did not apply to preempt common-law fraud claim brought under Texas law against former parent of insolvent health maintenance organizations (HMOs) based on former parent's actions prior to sale of HMOs to another entity, and thus former parent's liability for fraud was not limited by the statute to actual fraud for its own personal benefit; statute applied only when party sought to hold shareholder liable for its status as shareholder for the actions of the corporation, and receivers of HMOs were seeking to hold former parent liable for its own pre-sale actions. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Choice of Law. Texas law applied to tort claims of HMOs' receivers in action by Insurance Commissioner in which they intervened.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Shaoxing County Huayue Import & Export v. Bhaumik
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 5, California.
Headnote: California law does not recognize a general alter ego claim by which a defendant may be held personally liable for a bankrupt corporation's debts in the absence of allegations giving the corporation a right of action against the defendant.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Alter ego allegations did not become the property of the bankruptcy estate once corporate debtor filed for bankruptcy.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re S & G Financial Services of South Florida, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Substantive consolidation under federal bankruptcy law and veil piercing pursuant to state corporations law were separate and distinct concepts, and bankruptcy court did not need not make finding that debtor was alter ego of affiliated non-debtor entities in order to apply substantive consolidation doctrine to these debtor and non-debtor entities. 11 U.S.C.A. § 105(a).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Case Administration. Court can substantively consolidate debtor and non-debtor entities.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Atateks Foreign Trade, Ltd. v. Private Label Sourcing, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: One corporation dominated and controlled other corporation, and thus corporate veil of dominating corporation could be pierced to hold it liable under New York law for debts of dominated corporation, where those corporations did not adhere to corporate formalities, they had overlapping owners, officers, directors, and personnel, they did not deal with each other at arm's length and were not independent profit centers, dominated corporation had inadequate capitalization based on its conceded insolvency, and they shared office space and equipment.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Alter ego could be jointly and severally liable for all damages.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Broadstripe, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, official committee of unsecured creditors failed to demonstrate that Chapter 11 debtor was the alter ego of creditors; committee did not show that creditors so completely and thoroughly dominated debtor that they operated as a single economic entity.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Summary judgment was not warranted in committee's action for equitable subordination.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Lentz v. Trinchard
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Allegations that insurers, as well as one of insurer's related entities, were aware of and participated in decision to limit defense of debtor, as detective, and sheriff to policy period, knew that court denied motion to establish policy limits, and participated in rejection of offers to settle case arising out of non-party's wrongful murder conviction, subsequent settlement and partial release of claims against debtor, and cessation of representation by debtor's counsel despite his continued right to defense, were sufficient for trustee of bankruptcy estate to state that insurer and its related defendants exerted control over other insurer to warrant holding them liable as insurer's alter ego, under Wisconsin law, for insurer's alleged breaches of fiduciary duty, breaches of good faith and fair dealing, fraud and conspiracy to commit fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Conspiracy. Trustee failed to state civil conspiracy claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re St. John
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Michigan.
Headnote: Bankruptcy court could not pierce corporate veil in order to hold individual Chapter 7 debtor personally liable on promissory note which he had signed in representative capacity, as vice president of corporate maker, such that there was no underlying debt of kind required to support payee's nondischargeability complaint, based solely on authority which debtor had over corporate affairs or upon fact that he may have participated in solicitation of corporate investors; record was devoid of evidence that corporation was used to evade a personal obligation, to perpetrate fraud, to commit injustice, or to gain unfair advantage. 11 U.S.C.A. § 523(a).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. There was no underlying debt to support corporate creditor's nondischargeability complaint against debtor-officer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Smith
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Kentucky.
Headnote: To extent that cattle which Chapter 7 debtor had purchased, using funds of cattle auction company that employed him as its stockyard manager, were purchased for debtor's closely-held corporation rather than for the debtor personally, corporate veil could be pierced to hold debtor personally liable for corporate debt, where evidence established that debtor and his wife completely disregarded corporate form and used corporation as mere instrumentality for their own personal expenses.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor's misuse of company funds was in nature of embezzlement or larceny.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Liberty Coal Co., LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Illinois.
Headnote: Chapter 7 trustee failed to show that the Chapter 7 debtor/corporation's owner's equitable interest perpetrated a fraud or injustice that harmed the creditors, and thus, the corporate veil was not pierced due to fraud. The debtor's owner was a city board of municipal utilities, but such instrumentalities could not own stock in any corporation. Even though the owner had an equitable interest in the debtor, the trustee did not explain how this interest perpetrated a fraud or injustice that harmed any creditors.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Trustee failed to show that the Chapter 7 debtor/corporation's owner's equitable interest perpetrated a fraud or injustice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Pisculli
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Bankruptcy court may pierce corporate veil of business and treat its assets as individual property of business owner, of kind included in property of his individual bankruptcy estate, on alter ego theory. 11 U.S.C.A. § 541(a).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Statute dealing with property of postconversion estate did not bar objection to discharge on postpetition transfer theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Pisculli
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Debtor's failure to observe corporate formalities, while operating his wholly-owned corporation out of his home, in allocating portions of his personal bills to corporation for payment without any real basis for amount allocated, in having his wife pay their personal expenses with money withdrawn from corporation and its sister companies, in depositing proceeds from sale of corporate assets in his wife's personal account, and in generally treating all his businesses as if they were single entity, was such as to warrant piercing the corporate veil in order to bring corporate assets into bankruptcy estate. 11 U.S.C.A. § 541(a).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Statute dealing with property of postconversion estate did not bar objection to discharge on postpetition transfer theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Mosher
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Western Division.
Headnote: Even assuming that Chapter 7 debtor's wholly-owned corporation could be treated as still having an existence under Nevada law after its charter was revoked and claims of its creditors were satisfied, debtor's misuse of corporate form, in having clients for whom he performed work personally make payments to corporate account in attempt to avoid taxation, debtor's failure to observe corporate formalities, including his failure to maintain registration of corporation with the Nevada Secretary of State, and his commingling of funds and regular use of corporate account to pay personal expenses were sufficient to allow bankruptcy court to disregard corporate form, on alter ego or reverse veil-piercing theory, and to treat assets of corporation as assets of debtor, for purposes of deciding whether debtor's transfer or concealment of assets or false oaths with respect thereto warranted denial of his discharge. 11 U.S.C.A. § 727(a)(2), (a)(4)(A).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor's omissions on schedules were in nature of knowing and fraudulent false oaths.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re SMTC Mfg. of Texas
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Texas, Austin Division.
Headnote: Lack of evidence that commercial lessor, in entering into long-term facilities lease with corporate debtor, had relied on financial backing of debtor's parent or affiliated corporate entities, and evidence that it only belatedly sought to obtain guarantee from parent and other entities when debtor, in response to series of business losses, was in process of shutting down its manufacturing operation, was fatal to Chapter 7 trustee's ability to assert a sham to perpetrate fraud claim based on injury to commercial lessor, in attempt to hold parent and affiliated entities liable for debtor's debt.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Even obligation on absolute and unconditional guarantee may be discounted for fraudulent transfer avoidance purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re KJK Const. Co., Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, if a corporate shareholder has misrepresented his personal assets as corporate assets, a bankruptcy trustee can bring an alter ego claim.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Factual issues precluded summary judgment for defendants on Chapter 7 trustee's fraudulent transfer claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Bolze
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Tennessee.
Headnote: A Chapter 7 trustee established that two corporations were the alter-egos of a debtor and that the assets and liabilities of those corporations should be substantively consolidated with those of the debtor. The debtor interchangeably used his name individually on applications and other documents as the owner of assets titled to both corporations and commingled his personal funds with those of the corporations. There was also evidence that the debtor used those commingled funds to pay personal bills and make personal investments and that the debtor used his personal residence as the business address for both corporations and conducted all business from that address.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Chapter 7 trustee established that two corporations were alter-egos of debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Supplement Spot, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: While courts generally protect individual assets from reach of corporation's bankruptcy case, when corporate and individual business interests are so intertwined that corporation is indistinguishable from the individual, then alter ego doctrine operates to treat assets of both as corporate property.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Debtor-LLC received no benefit from payments on its principal's debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Supplement Spot, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Test for determining whether individual is "alter ego" of corporate debtor, such that assets of individual may be brought into bankruptcy estate of corporation, is whether there is such unity of interest and ownership that corporation and individual no longer exist and whether fraud or injustice would result if corporate form were to be observed.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Debtor-LLC received no benefit from payments on its principal's debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: NPR, LLC v. Met Fin Management, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: In creditor's fraudulent conveyance action, based on tenant's release or cancellation of subleases to corporation, without consideration, that rendered tenant insolvent, piercing corporate veil of party to transaction was warranted to hold individual defendant liable to creditor, where individual defendant exercised complete domination of corporation, his domination was used to commit fraud against creditor, and he abused privilege of doing business in corporate form. McKinney's Debtor and Creditor Law §§ 271(1), 273, 276.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Landlord and Tenant. Release or cancellation of subleases by creditor's tenant constituted fraudulent conveyance.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Cahillane
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Indiana, Hammond Division.
Headnote: Brother who assisted Chapter 7 debtor in hiding his earnings from creditors, by forming a "dummy" corporation with debtor solely for purpose of holding bank account into which were deposited payments made by debtor's customers for home improvement work that debtor had done, was not liable, as "alter ego" of initial corporate transferee, on fraudulent transfers which debtor made into account; while corporation may not have had any business and functioned solely to provide name on bank account, evidence did not suggest that corporation was front for any business transacted by brother, or that brother used corporation for his own purposes and benefit, but rather that it was established to safeguard debtor's earnings, at a time when he was insolvent and his earnings had already been garnished, by allowing earnings to be held in another account under corporate name. 11 U.S.C.A. § 548, 550(a)(1).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Party with check writing authority on account into which funds were fraudulently transferred was not initial transferee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Parks v. Anderson
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Bankruptcy court did not clearly err in finding that circumstances did not warrant piercing the corporate veil in order to make individual Chapter 7 debtor liable for his solely-owned companies' debts to creditor, where court reviewed all of facts and evaluated them against relevant factors and concluded that, while debtor may not have maintained good minute books for companies or adequately documented loan which he obtained from one of companies, veil piercing was not warranted given that company was adequately capitalized when debtor took loan, that debtor annually filed franchise tax reports and federal and state income tax returns, and that debtor's actions respecting companies' assets did not amount to promotion of fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Paydown of residential mortgage debt triggered statutory cap on debtor's state homestead exemption.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Friedlander Capital Management Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida, West Palm Beach Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, reverse veil piercing was not available to adversary defendants as defense to Chapter 7 trustee's fraudulent transfer claim under Bankruptcy Code's strong-arm statute and Connecticut constructive fraudulent transfer statute, given absence of allegations that defendants had pre-existing personal claim against corporate debtor's sole shareholder, or that shareholder formed or used debtor to secrete assets to avoid pre-existing personal liability. 11 U.S.C.A. § 544(b); C.G.S.A. § 52-552e(a)(2).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Reverse veil piercing could be applied defensively to defeat fraudulent transfer claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Friedlander Capital Management Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida, West Palm Beach Division.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, reverse veil piercing could be applied defensively to cause former wife's repayment to corporate debtor's sole shareholder of $500,000 loan which had been made using debtor's funds to be treated as payment to debtor for purposes of Chapter 7 trustee's fraudulent transfer claim against former wife under Bankruptcy Code's strong-arm statute and Connecticut constructive fraudulent transfer statute, given that defense merely relieved former wife of paying additional $450,000 to trustee, that general loss suffered by creditors due to bankruptcy estate not receiving such funds was outweighed by hardship that former wife would suffer from making additional payment, and that former wife had believed that she borrowed funds from shareholder and repaid loan to shareholder. 11 U.S.C.A. § 544(b); C.G.S.A. § 52-552e(a)(2).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Reverse veil piercing could be applied defensively to defeat fraudulent transfer claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Friedlander Capital Management Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida, West Palm Beach Division.
Headnote: Sole shareholder's use of corporation to commit securities fraud upon investors in pooled investment fund managed by corporation did not satisfy element of Connecticut's instrumentality rule requiring that principal's domination of corporation be used to commit wrongful act for purposes of reverse veil piercing defense asserted by shareholder's former wife and her former business to fraudulent transfer claim in corporation's Chapter 7 case, given that investors were not defendants in fraudulent transfer action. 11 U.S.C.A. § 544(b); C.G.S.A. § 52-552e(a)(2).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Reverse veil piercing could be applied defensively to defeat fraudulent transfer claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Friedlander Capital Management Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida, West Palm Beach Division.
Headnote: Chapter 7 trustee's commencement of adversary proceeding to recover alleged fraudulent transfer from former wife of corporate debtor's sole shareholder and former wife's former business was not, in itself, injury or unjust loss and did not flow from shareholder's wrongful use of corporate debtor to commit securities fraud, and therefore former wife and former business did not establish proximate cause element of Connecticut's instrumentality rule for purposes of their reverse veil piercing defense to trustee's fraudulent transfer claim. 11 U.S.C.A. § 544(b); C.G.S.A. § 52-552e(a)(2).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Reverse veil piercing could be applied defensively to defeat fraudulent transfer claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Two Springs Membership Club
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Federal common law, like both Delaware and Nevada law, requires evidence of fraud or injustice in order to pierce corporate veil and declare corporate entity the alter ego of another; accordingly, in deciding whether Chapter 11 debtor was alter ego of corporate entity against which creditor had obtained judgment, or of corporate entities as against which the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) had filed notices of federal tax liens, for purpose of determining debtor's liability on these debts and relative priority of judgment and federal tax liens, court did not have to choose between Delaware law, as state where debtor was incorporated, and either Nevada or federal common law.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Liens. Previously-filed tax lien had priority over later-attaching judgment lien, though liens attached simultaneously.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: LaSalle Nat. Bank Ass'n v. Paloian
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Affiliated corporation that was identified as borrower on prepetition loan collateralized by Chapter 11 debtor's receivables was not alter ego or instrumentality of debtor under governing Illinois law, for purpose of deciding whether subsequent use of loan proceeds to make payments challenged as constructively fraudulent by debtor involved requisite transfer of "interest of debtor in the property," where this affiliated corporation was not created for fraudulent purpose to place debtor's assets beyond reach of its creditors, but to minimize risk to lender of debtor's possible insolvency and to secure better interest rate than if debtor had borrowed in its own right. 11 U.S.C.A. §§ 544, 548.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Trust was initial transferee of fraudulently transferred funds even without carte blanche authority over funds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Wooley v. Lucksinger
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Corporation that sold its shares of health maintenance organizations (HMOs) and corporation that bought those shares did not operate as single business enterprise prior to sale, and thus selling corporation could not be held liable for pre-sale actions of buying corporation that allegedly led to insolvency of HMOs; neither corporation incorporated the other corporation, there was no commingling of corporate or shareholder funds, and there was no centralized accounting and auditing system.
Document Preview: HEALTH - HMOs. Seller and buyer of health maintenance organization did not operate as single business enterprise prior to or after sale.

Title: Wooley v. Lucksinger
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Corporation that sold its shares of health maintenance organizations (HMOs) and corporation that bought those shares did not operate as single business enterprise after sale, and thus selling corporation could not be held liable for post-sale actions of buying corporation that allegedly led to insolvency of HMOs, although stock purchase agreement gave selling corporation several rights by which it could control buying corporation's future conduct, and although transition services agreement required selling corporation to provide certain administrative services for HMOs until buying corporation could get "up and running"; buying corporation had ultimate authority and responsibility over HMOs after sale.
Document Preview: HEALTH - HMOs. Seller and buyer of health maintenance organization did not operate as single business enterprise prior to or after sale.

Title: In re Chicago Truck Center, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Separate corporate entities, consisting of automobile manufacturer and entity through which it provided financing to purchasers of its vehicles, could not be collapsed, for purpose of permitting trustee of bankrupt automobile dealership's Chapter 7 estate to pursue fraudulent transfer avoidance claim against entity that was not party to obligation that trustee sought to avoid, based solely on fact that internal memorandum referred to the entities collectively, with their names separated only by back slash, or on fact that entities may have cooperated in past for their mutual benefit, where each entity maintained separate books and records and acted as separate entity. 11 U.S.C.A. § 548.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Transfers in repayment of debtor's antecedent debt were not constructively fraudulent to creditors.

Title: Per-Co, Ltd. v. Great Lakes Factors
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Shareholders and directors of funding company caused transfer of substantially all of its assets to factoring company with common shareholders and directors, as required to show that factoring company was alter ego or successor to funding company for purposes of adversary proceeding arising from factoring company's bankruptcy proceedings; shareholders transferred generally collectible invoices to factoring company and left funding company with invoices that were virtually worthless, thus avoiding placement of money in lockbox pursuant to agreement between bank and funding company.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Secured Transactions. Company was a mere continuation of another, and thus company was liable for obligations of other company under Ohio law.

Title: In re Oko
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Corporate veil could be pierced, in order to hold corporation's sole shareholder personally liable for default judgment entered against corporation in fraudulent transfer avoidance proceeding brought by trustee of his mother's Chapter 7 estate, given evidence that shareholder had established corporation without adequate capitalization and had thereafter done business through corporation without observing any corporate formalities, such as holding any formal meetings or keeping corporate minutes or records, that corporation had no employees other than its shareholder, and that shareholder routinely used corporate funds to pay personal expenses of himself and his parents.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Corporate veil could be pierced to hold shareholder personally liable for judgment on fraudulent transfer claim.

Title: In re Levitsky
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Bankruptcy court could reverse pierce the veil of individual Chapter 7 debtor's wholly-owned corporation, in order to bring residential real property owned by corporation into "property of the estate," where debtor had created corporation to hold title to real property on which he intended to take up residence in order to protect property from his estranged, now-former wife shortly after the two separated and debtor needed to acquire new home, where, throughout its duration, corporation had no business purpose but existed solely to hold legal title to property, where debtor ignored corporate formalities and dealt with property as his own, living there virtually rent-free for much of corporation's 25-year ostensible ownership of property, and where reverse-piercing of corporate veil would not harm corporate creditors, whose liens against residential property were equally valid or invalid inside or outside bankruptcy.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Court could reverse veil pierce to bring corporate property into debtor-stockholder's bankruptcy estate.

Title: ASARCO LLC v. Americas Mining Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Brownsville Division.
Headnote: Corporate form of shell holding company, as holder of stock, had been misused or manipulated to effect fraud, injustice or inequity, as required for corporation that created holding company to pierce corporate veil of holding company on alter-ego theory under Delaware law on fraudulent transfer claim in bankruptcy against its parent corporations, since parent corporations disregarded corporate separateness of those two entities and treated creating corporation as owner of shares for years. 11U.S.C.A. § 544.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Judicial estoppel could not be applied to reverse-veil piercing alter-ego claim against parent to avoid fraudulent transfers.

Title: Sudden Service, Inc. v. Brockman Forklifts, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Piercing forklift dealer's corporate veil was not warranted, in machine parts dealer's action alleging that president and sole shareholder of forklift dealer fraudulently conveyed money and assets to himself during forklift dealer's dissolution; conveyances were repayment of secured loans between forklift dealer and president, and there was no evidence of intermingling of assets or failure to maintain corporate records.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Fraudulent Transfers. Contributions by president and sole shareholder of corporation were loans rather than fraudulent transfers.

Title: DeWitt v. Sealtex Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: There was no legal relationship between insolvent corporation and a limited liability company (LLC) as would permit a finding that the corporation was the LLC's alter ego, so as to enable unsecured creditors of the insolvent corporation to attach liability to the LLC; although the LLC had two members, and such members were also two of the three shareholders of the corporation, the LLC did not control or have any other relationship with the corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Creditor of insolvent corporation could not prevail on claim of successor liability in commercial credit protection context.

Title: In re American Intern. Refinery
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Nevada's alter ego doctrine does not merely shift liability from one entity to another, but expands a debtor's bankruptcy estate to include the property of its alter ego.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Debtor and liquidation trustee had standing to assert avoidance claims to the extent subsidiary was debtor's alter ego.

Title: In re American Intern. Refinery
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Potential prejudice to innocent parties and creditors is a factor that must be taken into account by the court in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil in the context of a bankruptcy case.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Debtor and liquidation trustee had standing to assert avoidance claims to the extent subsidiary was debtor's alter ego.

Title: In re Romano
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Corporate veil could be pierced, in order to hold Chapter 7 debtor personally liable for debts of the closely held corporation through which he carried out his waste hauling business to purchaser of corporation's assets, given evidence that, at time of events giving rise to debt, corporation was, if not insolvent, then certainly within zone of insolvency, evidence of debtor's persistent use of corporate assets in order to pay his and his family's personal expenses, and evidence that debtor had all but admitted existence of alter ego relationship when he testified that "I was [the corporation]."
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor's silence at closing of sale of his business was false representation.

Title: EAC of New York, Inc. v. Capri 400, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Piercing of corporate veil was warranted to hold restaurant vendor's principal personally liable for equipment that was damaged or missing after sale, where principal exercised total domination over corporation with respect to transaction at issue and principal transferred all corporate assets to himself, thereby rendering corporation insolvent. McKinney's CPLR 5225(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil was warranted to hold restaurant vendor's principal liable for damaged and missing equipment.

Court: United States District Court, E.D. North Carolina, Western Division.
Headnote: Application of alter ego doctrine brings assets of a debtor's alter ego into bankruptcy estate. 11 U.S.C.A. § 541(a)(1).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Parties. Non-diverse defendant corporation was fraudulently joined.

Title: In re DiLoreto
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Reverse-piercing of the veils of various corporations and offshore entities to include their assets in Chapter 7 debtor's bankruptcy estate was warranted; while debtor was president of one corporation and sole owner of that corporation's parent company, and soon after he, his wife, and the corporation received a $16.3 million judgment against them, he made a series of cash transfers totaling $780,117.10 to corporation's offshore accounts, and five months before debtor filed for bankruptcy, he caused the corporation to be sold to an offshore company, which was owned by debtor's business associate, for much less than the corporation's fair market value.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Denial of Chapter 7 debtor's discharge was warranted.

Title: In re Friedman's Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Georgia, Savannah Division.
Headnote: Georgia law requires, as precondition to plaintiff's piercing the corporate veil and holding individual shareholders liable on corporate claim, that there be insolvency on part of corporation, in sense that there are insufficient corporate assets to satisfy the plaintiff's claim.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Professionals. In pari delicto doctrine did not bar trustee's claims against corporate debtor's former outside counsel.

Title: Pacer's Bar & Grill, Inc. v. Weinson's Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: Trial court properly pierced corporate veil and applied doctrine of judicial estoppel in dismissing corporation's action based upon two prior personal bankruptcy flings by sole shareholder, in which shareholder failed to list his ownership interest of corporation or his interest in the lease between corporation and defendant as an asset or debt in either proceeding; shareholder dominated the corporation, the corporation was undercapitalized, and shareholder attempted to misuse the corporate form in order to avoid the consequences of his failure to list corporation or the lease as an asset or debt in his personal bankruptcy proceedings.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Trial court properly pierced corporate veil and applied doctrine of judicial estoppel in dismissing corporation's action.

Title: State ex rel. Neidig v. Superior Nat. Ins. Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Oregon, En Banc.
Headnote: Insolvent workers' compensation insurer and retrocessionaire, or the reinsurer of the reinsurer, of the insolvent insurer were under actual common control, for purposes of determining whether the corporate veil of retrocessionaire and insolvent insurer could be pierced and retrocessionaire's $10.6 million deposit with Department of Consumer and Business Services (DCBS) could be used to reimburse Oregon Insurance Guaranty Association (OIGA) for claims made against insolvent insurer's policies, where retrocessionaire and insolvent insurer were operationally a single company, both corporations were under the control of the same insurance holding company, both corporations shared the same office, board members, executive officers, investment managers and accountants, both corporations violated the insurance code by not filing required deposit forms with the DCBS, and insolvent insurer failed to make required security deposit. West's Or.Rev. Stat. Ann. §§ 731.608(3), 731.628.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Guaranty Associations. Guaranty association could pierce veils and use affiliate's deposit to pay claims against insolvent insurer's policies.

Title: State ex rel. Neidig v. Superior Nat. Ins. Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Oregon, En Banc.
Headnote: Conduct of commonly owned insurers, insolvent workers' compensation insurer and its retrocessionaire, or the reinsurer of insolvent insurer's reinsurer, in failing to file timely and accurate deposit forms with Department of Consumer and Business Services (DCBS) and insolvent insurer in failing to make required security deposit, was improper conduct, for purposes of determining whether corporate veil of both insurers could be pierced and retrocessionaire's $10.6 million security deposit with DCBS could be used to reimburse Oregon Insurance Guaranty Association (OIGA) for claims made against insolvent insurer's policies; conduct allowed individuals who controlled both corporations to hide retrocessionaire's reinsurance obligation and fact that insolvent insurer owed a statutory deposit of about $4.4 million, and seek the return of retrocessionaire's deposit on ground that retrocessionaire no longer had reinsurance obligations in Oregon. West's Or.Rev. Stat. Ann. § 731.628.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Guaranty Associations. Guaranty association could pierce veils and use affiliate's deposit to pay claims against insolvent insurer's policies.

Title: State ex rel. Neidig v. Superior Nat. Ins. Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Oregon, En Banc.
Headnote: Improper conduct of commonly owned insurers, insolvent workers' compensation insurer and its reinsurer, in failing to file timely and accurate deposit forms with Department of Consumer and Business Services (DCBS) and insolvent insurer in failing to make required security deposit, harmed Oregon Insurance Guaranty Association (OIGA), for purposes of determining whether corporate veils could be pierced and reinsurer's $10.6 million security deposit with DCBS could be used to reimburse OIGA for claims against insolvent insurer's policies; insolvent insurer had the funds to make the required deposit when form disclosing its business activities was due, if DCBS had timely information it could have insisted that either insolvent insurer make the deposit or that reinsurer's deposit serve as a substitute, and, if insurers did neither, DCBS could have prevented insolvent insurer from issuing more policies and there would have been fewer claims for OIGA to cover. West's Or.Rev. Stat. Ann. § 731.628.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Guaranty Associations. Guaranty association could pierce veils and use affiliate's deposit to pay claims against insolvent insurer's policies.

Headnote: State law governed whether bankruptcy court should "reverse pierce" a bankrupt corporate subsidy's veil in order to hold it liable for debts of its nondebtor-parent.

Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: "Reverse piercing" of bankrupt corporate subsidy's veil in order to hold it liable for debts of its nondebtor-parent was not appropriate under Nevada law, despite substantial evidence of control, unity of interest, and lack of corporate formalities, where only expectation of creditors of corporate parent, the parties seeking this reverse veil-piercing, in litigating their claims against parent to final judgment lay in availability of assets of nondebtor-parent, and it would upset expectations of debtor-subsidiary's creditors to allow parent's creditors to recover more than the equity that remained after debtor-subsidiary's creditors were paid.

Title: In re National Audit Defense Network
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: Bankruptcy court would pierce and reverse pierce corporate veil existing between individual fraudulent transfer defendants and the wholly owned corporate defendants that they controlled, and through which they carried out Ponzi-like scheme to defraud clients into investing in worthless tax shelters, so that corporate defendants would be liable for fraudulent transfers to individual defendants and individual defendants would be liable for fraudulent transfers to corporations, where corporations were wholly owned by individuals and acted solely thorough them, complete unity of interest existed between parties, and corporations were vehicles through which individuals perpetrated their fraudulent Ponzi-like scheme. 11 U.S.C.A. § 550.

Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Orlando Division.
Headnote: State law provided standard which governed trustee's ability to pierce Chapter 7 debtor's corporate veil, in order to avoid, for benefit of estate, transfers that were made not by debtor, but by related corporate entity.
