Title: In re First Assured Warranty Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Hawai'i Insurance Commissioner, in his capacity as court-appointed liquidator of captive insurance company that was established by debtor's principals to provide debtor with proof of insurance required for debtor to sell extended automobile warranty coverage in some of states in which it operated, failed to establish, under either Hawai'i or Colorado alter ego law, sufficient basis for disregarding corporate barrier that existed between debtor and this captive insurance company, for purpose of establishing that debtor was itself a "domestic insurance company" ineligible for Chapter 11 relief; while debtor and this captive insurance company shared a common controlling shareholder and were supervised, managed and controlled by the same officers and directors, each company maintained its own bank accounts and financial records, there was no evidence of any unauthorized diversion of assets between companies, there was no evidence that debtor, unlike insurer, was inadequately capitalized, and Commissioner failed to demonstrate any disregard of corporate formalities. 11 U.S.C.A. § 109(b).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Case Administration. Bankruptcy case did not have to be dismissed on McCarran-Ferguson Act grounds.

Title: In re Aqua Clear Technologies, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida, Fort Lauderdale Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, business was alter ego of insolvent corporation, and thus was liable for its debts, where new business was incorporated 21 days after insolvent corporation filed bankruptcy petition, companies were in substantially same business, used same telephone number, operated from same business address, serviced same area and many of same customers, and had identical officers and directors, insolvent corporation transferred its tools and other assets to new company without consideration, and new company indicated to health insurance carrier that business was merely changing its name.

Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Western Division.
Headnote: Piercing of corporate veil by bankruptcy court, to treat prepetition transfer of inventory of debtor's wholly-owned corporation as fraudulent transfer of property of debtor, was not designed to redress any wrong to corporate entity, and was not in nature of reverse veil piercing, but of ordinary veil piercing, of kind recognized under Ohio law.

Title: In re Chira
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida, Ft. Lauderdale Division.
Headnote: Bankruptcy trustee may bring a "reverse piercing" action to draw the assets of the debtor's mere instrumentality into the debtor's estate, so long as piercing the corporate veil is an action available under state law in those circumstances to creditors generally.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Ex-wife breached her fiduciary duties of loyalty and care, warranting equitable subordination of her claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Wright
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Arkansas, Helena Division.
Headnote: Corporation was alter ego of its sole shareholders, who also were its only officers and directors, supporting piercing of the corporate veil and disregard of corporate facade in adversary proceeding in which creditor of Chapter 7 debtors sought to recover alleged preferential and fraudulent transfers from shareholders, who were debtor-husband's parents, and corporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtors' failure to maintain adequate financial records warranted denial of their Chapter 7 discharge.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Lupo
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Corporation which entered into contract to provide magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) device to medical clinic was operated as alter ego of its sole shareholder, as first prerequisite under Ohio law for piercing corporate veil and holding shareholder personally liable for corporation's alleged breach of contract and fraud in connection with sales transaction, where corporation was undercapitalized and insolvent at time that it entered into sales agreement, and where shareholder admittedly disregarded corporate formalities in allowing salesperson employed by corporation to hold himself out as corporate officer and in using funds in corporate checking account for personal expenditures.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Fraudulent scheme was in nature of willful and malicious injury to defrauded party.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: State ex rel. Neidig v. Superior Nat. Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Oregon.
Headnote: The Oregon Insurance Guaranty Association (OIGA) could not pierce corporate veil of insolvent corporation with ownership and controlling interest in two workers' compensation insurers, in proceedings seeking deposits owned by one insurer for reimbursement of liabilities arising from claims on policies of another, affiliated insurer, where there was no showing of any improper conduct on the part of the corporation relating to the deposits.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil requires some moral culpability of corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Trenwick America Litigation Trust v. Ernst & Young, L.L.P.
Court: Court of Chancery of Delaware, New Castle County.
Headnote: Litigation trust, which had been formed in reorganization of subsidiary of a publicly listed insurance holding company following bankruptcy proceedings, failed to state cause of action against former directors of holding company by alleging that holding company's imprudent business strategy rendered holding company and subsidiary insolvent; holding company did not owe subsidiary fiduciary duties, there was no allegation of gross negligence, board was dominated by independent directors, directors were not alleged to have had motive to injure companies' value or personally enrich themselves, there was no allegation of deficiencies in directors' deliberative process, and there were no grounds alleged to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Directors of subsidiary did not owe a duty to second-guess the business judgment of its parent corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Riley
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: Piercing of the corporate veil of corporation in which Chapter 7 debtor held majority interest was warranted to permit bankruptcy court to reach corporation's real property when debtor and her son, who owned remaining stock interest in corporation, treated corporation's real property as their own property and debtor, after corporation's bankruptcy case closed, gave son blanket authority to deal with impending foreclosure on property as he saw fit.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Denial of Chapter 7 discharge was warranted for transfer or concealment of estate property with fraudulent intent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: VFP VC v. Dakota Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Idaho, Boise, February 2006 Term.
Headnote: Holding corporation that was alter ego of judgment debtor and was subject to court oversight orders that limited its activities until the judgment was paid, was not entitled to relief from oversight orders on grounds the orders were no longer equitable after ownership of the corporation changed hands, where judgment debtor was still the "public face" of the corporation and ran the day-to-day operations, there was no evidence that change in ownership increased the cost of compliance with the oversight orders, and there was no evidence that the change in ownership caused the oversight orders to violate state or federal law or required application of only garnishment law. Rules Civ.Proc., Rule 60(b)(5).
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Judgment. A holding corporation was not entitled to relief from oversight orders that limited its activities.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Turner
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Both entities created by Chapter 7 debtor for the sole purpose of "asset protection," namely, a corporation and a limited liability company (LLC), were his alter egos, for purposes of determining whether various prepetition transfers of debtor's home could be avoided as fraudulent under bankruptcy law and/or California law; debtor admitted that these entities were created and their relationship structured to maximize the protection of his assets, that is, his home, the entities had no business purpose, and debtor caused one of the entities to make a fraudulent transfer. 11 U.S.C.A. § 548; West's Ann.Cal.Civ.Code § 3439.04 et seq.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor's false oaths warranted denial of his discharge.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Hertzler Halstead Hosp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: In adversary proceeding brought by Chapter 11 trustee against debtor-hospital's former chief executive officer (CEO) and a company that he controlled, seeking to avoid and recover alleged preferential and fraudulent transfers, the bankruptcy court declined, under Kansas law, to "reverse-pierce" the corporate veil and disregard defendant-company's separate existence; power to pierce the corporate veil was ordinarily used to prevent fraud or injustice against third parties, not, as here, as a sword to vindicate a company's own interests, and none of the eight factors considered by Kansas courts when determining whether to pierce the corporate veil was supported by the limited evidence before the court, which included evidence that defendant-company had observed corporate formalities, had corporate records, employees, and a bank account, filed corporate tax returns, and was a Kansas corporation in good standing.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Debtor's payments to former CEO and his company were fraudulent transfers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Adler, Coleman Clearing Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, individual who held interest in Bahamian companies exercised sufficient domination and control over those entities as to warrant piercing the corporate veil in action brought by Securities Investor Protection Act (SIPA) trustee for liquidation of securities clearing firm, seeking payment of judgments obtained by trustee against companies; even if individual was only minority owner, corporations had no officers or employees other than owners, corporations had no place of corporate operations other than those of individual's attorneys' offices, and individual admitted to having organized companies to disguise and conceal true owners and defraud the investing public. Securities Exchange Act of 1934, § 1 et seq., 15 U.S.C.A. § 78a et seq.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Individual had sufficient control over companies to warrant piercing the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Baillie Lumber Co. v. Thompson
Court: Supreme Court of Georgia.
Headnote: Allowing a corporation in bankruptcy to assert an alter ego cause of action against former principal does not needlessly interfere with creditor's legal remedies, and, thus, statute which states that a diligent creditor shall not needlessly be interfered with in the prosecution of his legal remedies does not provide grounds for refusing to allow corporation to assert such an action; the unsecured creditor's remedy is only interfered with for the valid reason that in bankruptcy, all unsecured creditors are to be treated equally with regard to like claims. West's Ga.Code Ann. § 23-1-22.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporation may bring action against principal of corporation to recover on alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Die Fliedermaus LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Allegations that individual controlled profit-sharing plan that was member of debtor-limited liability company (LLC), and that such individual "caused" debtor to make prepetition distribution payments that Chapter 7 trustee sought to avoid as fraudulent conveyances, did not state claim for piercing of corporate veil, so as to support trustee's recovery against individual for payments made to plan. Bankr.Code, 11 U.S.C.A. §§ 548, 550(a)(1, 2).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Three-year look-back or limitations period governed trustee's claims to avoid or recover alleged wrongful LLC distributions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Del-Met Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Tennessee.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, as predicted by bankruptcy court, corporation may not maintain alter ego or veil-piercing action against related corporate entity, so that trustee of corporate debtors' Chapter 7 estate had no standing to bring cause of action to pierce veil separating debtors and related corporate entity, for purpose of challenging transfer involving assets of this related corporate entity as allegedly depleting property of the estate.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Trustee lacked standing to pursue veil-piercing claim to bring property into corporate debtors' Chapter 7 estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Enterprise Acquisition Partners, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Appellate Panel of the Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Unity of interest existing between statutory "insider" and her wholly owned corporation did not justify piercing the corporate veil, in order to hold corporation liable, on preference theory, for transfer that it received more than 90 days prepetition, given complete lack of evidence that any inequity would result if corporate veil were not pierced; allowing corporation to retain preferential transfer that it received more than 90 days prior to commencement of debtor's Chapter 7 case was not, in and of itself, inequitable. Bankr.Code, 11 U.S.C.A. §§ 101(31), 547(b)(4)(B).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Corporation wholly owned by statutory insider was not statutory insider.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Taylor v. Clark
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Southern District.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to establish, in former wife's fraudulent conveyance action against former husband, that necessary criteria for piercing the veil of former husband's closely-held corporation were not present; there was evidence that both former husband's and new wife's use of corporation's checking account as their personal checking account was not unusual, and that accounting practices and tax treatment at issue were acceptable under the characteristics of an S corporation or a closely-held corporation. V.A.M.S. §§ 428.005-428.059.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Evidence established that transfers from former husband's corporation to his new wife were not fraudulent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Sunbelt Environmental Services, Inc. v. Rieder's Jiffy Market, Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Southern District, Division Two.
Headnote: Evidence supported piercing corporate veil of trustee of trust that held convenience store's assets, and of corporation to which assets were transferred; transfer was to an insider, trustee retained control of property transferred, prior to transfer, trustee had been sued, substantially all assets were transferred, less than reasonably equivalent value was received, store became insolvent, and transfer occurred shortly after a substantial debt was incurred. V.A.M.S. § 428.024.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence warranted piercing corporate veil to impose liability on trustee, store, and transferee corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Cambridge Electronics Corp. v. MGA Electronics, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, requiring electronics supplier to seek repayment of corporate customer's outstanding debts in customer's bankruptcy case, with the consequence that supplier might not recover full extent of monies it was owed, was not inequitable result that warranted disregard of corporate form under alter ego doctrine so as to make customer's sole shareholder liable to supplier for customer's debts; rather, such result was normal incident of doing business.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Fraudulent Transfers. Payment made by corporation to shareholder's father was not fraudulent transfer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Flutie New York Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Corporate veil would be pierced, so as to hold principal of corporate Chapter 7 debtor personally liable under New York law for debts of estate, based on evidence that principal had consistently failed to observe corporate formalities, never causing any stock to be issued and not holding any meetings of board, that debtor was undercapitalized from the start, and that principal had caused corporate assets to be transferred, for no consideration, to related corporate entities so as to deprive debtor's legitimate creditors of assets to which they could look for payment of their claims.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Veil would be pierced to hold debtor's principal personally liable for debts of bankruptcy estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Crowe Rope Industries, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Maine.
Headnote: Under Maine law, as predicted by bankruptcy court, Chapter 7 trustee could not reverse pierce veil of bankrupt limited liability company in order to hold limited liability company's insider liable as alter ego on company's debts.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Alter ego claim was not included in property of estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Oregon Public Employees' Retirement Bd. ex rel. Oregon Public Employees' Retirement Fund v. Simat, Helliesen & Eichner
Court: Court of Appeals of Oregon.
Headnote: When a plaintiff seeks to collect a corporate debt from a shareholder, the plaintiff must prove that the defendant controlled the debtor corporation, the defendant engaged in "improper conduct", and, as a result of that "improper conduct," the plaintiff either entered into a transaction that it otherwise would not have entered into, or was unable to collect on a debt against the insolvent corporation.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Plaintiff failed to prove reasonable reliance as element of fraud claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Oregon Public Employees' Retirement Bd. ex rel. Oregon Public Employees' Retirement Fund v. Simat, Helliesen & Eichner
Court: Court of Appeals of Oregon.
Headnote: Corporate developer had not possessed, or exercised, actual control over insolvent corporations, and thus developer could not be held personally liable as shareholder for corporations' debt to Public Employees Retirement Board (PERB) through "piercing of corporate veil," which debt arose from corporations' breach of contract relating to airport facility; while developer had been an active participant in corporate affairs, he held only five percent of stock, and he was not responsible for financial decisionmaking.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Plaintiff failed to prove reasonable reliance as element of fraud claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Oregon Public Employees' Retirement Bd. ex rel. Oregon Public Employees' Retirement Fund v. Simat, Helliesen & Eichner
Court: Court of Appeals of Oregon.
Headnote: Developer's "milking" of $2 million in corporate assets materially affected corporation's prospect of attracting $10 million in investment, which was necessary for corporation to fulfill contractual obligation to fund start-up company to manage maintenance facility at airport, and thus Public Employees Retirement Board (PERB), which had guaranteed bonds financing such facility, was entitled to "pierce corporate veil" of insolvent corporation and to hold developer personally liable as shareholder who had engaged in "improper conduct."
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Plaintiff failed to prove reasonable reliance as element of fraud claim.

Title: In re JTS Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Chapter 11 trustee failed to show that corporate form should have been disregarded under Delaware law, on evidence of inadequate capitalization, assumption of debt, asset stripping, and improper maintenance of corporate records, since corporation had real business objectives, it had operating board of directors that met regularly, it retained its own corporate counsel which regularly advised corporation concerning corporation's business affairs, it maintained its own bank accounts and corporate records, and there was nothing to indicate that there was any attempt to use corporate form to defraud or otherwise deceive those who did business with corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Trustee failed to show that corporate form should have been disregarded.

Title: In re iPCS, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, it is appropriate to allow representative of corporate debtor's bankruptcy estate to pierce debtor's own corporate veil, in order to hold another entity liable for debtor's debts.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Parties. Creditors' committee would be allowed to pursue alter ego claims on behalf of estate.

Title: In re Xyan.Com, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Official committee of unsecured creditors stated fraud claim under Pennsylvania law against corporation related to Chapter 11 debtor, under theory of reverse piercing of the corporate veil, on allegations that the corporations were alter egos of one another by reason of configuration of the assets and liabilities of the two entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Creditors' committee stated fraud claim under theory of reverse piercing of the corporate veil.

Title: John T. Callahan & Sons, Inc. v. Dykeman Elec. Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: In veil piercing context in Massachusetts, "insolvency" is the inability to pay debts as they become due, and is evaluated at the time of the litigated transaction.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Creditor failed to show that new corporation was liable on mere continuation theory of successor liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Gemignani v. Pete
Court: Court of Appeals of Oregon.
Headnote: Home purchasers were not required to prove corporate vendor's insolvency or undercapitalization at time of incorporation, in order to pierce the corporate veil so that vendor's sole shareholder would be personally liable for vendor's breach of contract, where purchasers alleged shareholder's improper conduct in exercising control over corporation at a time when corporation was insolvent or undercapitalized.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Vendor and Purchaser. Home purchasers' loss was not result of vendor's unlawful trade practice.

Title: Gemignani v. Pete
Court: Court of Appeals of Oregon.
Headnote: Insolvency or undercapitalization may provide a basis for securing the benefit of piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Vendor and Purchaser. Home purchasers' loss was not result of vendor's unlawful trade practice.

Title: Serio v. Ardra Ins. Co., Ltd.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Piercing of corporate veil, holding principals liable for reinsurer's debts to insolvent insurer, was supported by evidence that principals, through their control of reinsurer, deprived it of funds needed to meet its reinsurance obligations, and that circumstance rendered reinsurance agreements at issue inequitable. McKinney's Insurance Law § 1505(a).
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Reinsurance. Evidence supported piercing of reinsurer's corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Foxmeyer Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Where Chapter 7 trustee sought to combine debtor-subsidiary and debtor-parent corporation via a piercing of the corporate veil, for purposes of his proceeding to recover fraudulent conveyances, the corporate veil which trustee sought to pierce was that of subsidiary, not that of parent. Bankr.Code, 11 U.S.C.A. § 548(a)(1)(B).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Trustee failed to prove that debtor-subsidiary's corporate veil should be pierced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Foxmeyer Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Drain of assets from the combined Chapter 7 debtors, a subsidiary and its parent corporation, did not constitute fraud or a similar injustice necessary to pierce subsidiary's corporate veil under Delaware law; evidence did not show that parent drained assets out of subsidiary but, instead, established that parent's parent was the entity that drained assets out of both corporations, so that the injustice would have supported piercing the corporate veils of both subsidiary and parent, but not just the corporate veil of subsidiary.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Trustee failed to prove that debtor-subsidiary's corporate veil should be pierced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re Foxmeyer Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Chapter 7 trustee failed to establish that debtor-subsidiary and debtor-parent corporation operated as a single economic entity, as required to satisfy first prong of the Fletcher test for veil-piercing under Delaware law; although parent's parent may have siphoned off funds of both parent and subsidiary, there was no evidence that parent siphoned off funds of subsidiary, subsidiary did not function simply as a facade of parent, but existed in order to carry out parent's pharmaceutical distribution business, factors of inadequate capitalization and insolvency did not support finding that parent and subsidiary operated as single economic entity, and evidence was equivocal, at best, as to whether subsidiary's corporate formalities were observed.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Trustee failed to prove that debtor-subsidiary's corporate veil should be pierced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Brannan v. Fremont Homes, Inc.
Court: Shoshone and Arapaho Tribal Appellate Court.
Citation: Not Reported in Am. Tribal Law
Headnote: Tribal court had a rational basis to hold officers of corporation that sold mobile liable individually for buyers' breach of warranty claims, where sale and liquidation of corporation by defendant officers appeared to have been in response to suit and attempt to avoid liability and thereby benefit unjustly.
Document Preview: Background: Buyers of mobile home brought action against corporation that sold mobile home and officers, alleging breach of warranty, breach of implied warranty of fitness for a particular purpose, and negligence. The Tribal Court, John St. Clair, J., entered order in favor of buyers consisting of $6,260.00 for recoverable costs, $1,000.00 penalty as damages for breach of the Mobile Home Warranty Act, and $2,521.06 for attorneys fees and costs. Sellers appealed. Holdings: The Court of Appeals held that: 2(1) buyers were entitled to damages in amount of $9,781.06; 3(2) tribal court had jurisdiction over sellers; and 4(3) tribal court had a rational basis to hold officers of corporation individually liable.  Appeal denied.

Title: Maiz v. Virani
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas turnover statute, court's factual determination in judgment creditor's collection action, that judgment debtor actually controlled assets of non-judgment debtor corporations, was insufficient to justify enforcement of turnover order against assets owned by corporations; prior legal adjudication piercing corporate veils was required. V.T.C.A., Civil Practice & Remedies Code § 31.002(a), (b)(1).
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Texas turnover statute could not be used to seize assets of non-judgment debtor corporations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Interfaith Community Organization v. Honeywell Intern., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Mere fact that subsidiary was in bankruptcy proceedings did not require conclusion that it was undercapitalized, in context of analysis to determine whether to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Factors weighted against piercing veil to make parent corporation liable for CERCLA cleanup costs.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Kay v. Pasternak
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division Eight.
Headnote: Trial court did not pierce corporate veil when it required doctors who practiced in medical corporation to disgorge portion of money they received from corporation's receiver in order to pay receiver's fee; receiver sought, and the court ordered, recovery of money that the receiver paid to doctors by mistake. West's Ann.Cal.Corp. Code § 13403.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Dissolution and Survival. Trial court could order doctors to disgorge payments to pay receiver of their medical corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: Medlock v. Medlock
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: In a case of "reverse piercing" of the corporate veil, in which the assets of the corporate entity may be used to satisfy the obligations of the controlling alter ego, factors to be considered in determining to disregard the corporate entity are the insolvency of the individual and the extent to which the individual's ostensible poverty is supported by corporate assets.
Document Preview: FAMILY LAW - Marital Property. Nonprofit religious corporation was former husband's alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1065 Insolvency, bankruptcy, and receivership >
Title: In re World Vision Entertainment, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Orlando Division.
Headnote: Florida bankruptcy court would apply law of Tennessee and Mississippi to trustee's veil piercing claims, since corporations were incorporated in those states, Chapter 11 debtor's notes were sold primarily in those states, unpaid investors generally resided in those states, and existence and extent of shareholder's liability to corporations for assessments or contributions, and to its creditors for corporate debts, was to be determined by local law of state of incorporation. Restatement (Second) Conflict of Laws § 307.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Commission payments to brokers under investment program were fraudulent and would be avoided.

Title: Jelco Construction, Inc. v. Van Schoonenberg
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Trial court exceeded its jurisdiction by imposing conditional alter ego liability on president of home remodeling corporation, under which president would become liable if corporation or president filed bankruptcy within seven years, or if corporation committed other acts prohibited by judgment, in customer's breach of contract action against corporation and president, since prohibited acts would not necessarily be determinative or even relevant in determining alter ego liability, prohibited acts that might occur in future could not be considered by court, and alter ego doctrine did not guard every unsatisfied creditor of a corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Trial court could not impose conditional alter ego liability on president of remodeling corporation.

Title: Official Committee of Unsecured Creditors v. R.F. Lafferty & Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Corporation's existence could not be disregarded, in lawsuit asserting a "deepening insolvency" cause of action against corporation's sole shareholders, officers, and consultants; although corporation's sole shareholders, officers, and consultants used corporation to commit a fraud, corporation was not fictional or a sham, corporate formalities were not ignored, and corporation did not lacked an identity separate from sole shareholders.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. In pari delicto defense precluded recovery by innocent victims of Ponzi scheme.

Title: In re Singer Co., N.V.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Parent's common ownership of two corporations, one of which had owned patent prior to sale thereof by bankruptcy trustee, and the other of which had used patent pursuant to alleged license, was not sufficient, without more, to allow piercing of corporate veil, in order to estop second corporation from claiming license upon theory that it had not sold "pig in a poke"; no evidence was presented that corporations had shared single corporate existence, or had been used in common scheme to perpetrate fraud on third parties.
Document Preview: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY - Licenses. Implied license to use patent arose on equitable estoppel theory.

Title: Trustees of Nat. Elevator Industry Pension v. Lutyk
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: In determining whether sole shareholder of bankrupt employer was subject to personal liability, under alter ego theory, for employer's failure to make contributions to ERISA benefit plans, relevant time period for determining solvency of employer was time at which it incurred liability. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 2 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 1001 et seq.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Sole shareholder was liable for unpaid contributions to ERISA plans.

Title: Trustees of Nat. Elevator Industry Pension v. Lutyk
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil was justified to hold sole shareholder of bankrupt corporation personally liable for unremitted contributions to ERISA benefit plans, where corporation was grossly undercapitalized and insolvent during its period of delinquency, funds were siphoned to sole shareholder at time of financial distress to injury of other creditors, existing records showed that corporate recordkeeping and procedures were inadequate, and it was unjust to allow shareholder to enjoy protections normally afforded by the corporate form. Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 2 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 1001 et seq.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Sole shareholder was liable for unpaid contributions to ERISA plans.

Title: Brito v. DILP Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Fact that corporation had insufficient assets or insurance to satisfy plaintiff's potential damages was not a basis upon which to impose a corporate liability on an individual owner or shareholder.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. That corporation had insufficient assets was not basis to impose liability on shareholder.

Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Five.
Headnote: When action of a dominant corporation renders a subservient corporation insolvent, the requisite injury to a third party and causal connection is established for piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Actual occupant of premises leased to corporation was liable to lessor under alter-ego theory.

Title: In re Clary
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Georgia, Brunswick Division.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, corporate veil could not be pierced to hold Chapter 13 debtor personally liable on equipment lease renewals of his dissolved corporation, on theory that debtor, by incurring lease payment obligations after corporation had been administratively dissolved, had used corporate form in order to perpetrate fraud on lessor; rental contract renewals were part of ordinary course of business of corporation, as they involved equipment necessary for day to day running of its construction business, and were properly renewed even after administrative dissolution. O.C.G.A. § 14-2-1421(c).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Post-dissolution renewal of corporate leases was not fraud permitting veil to be pierced.

Title: D.S.I. v. Natare Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Corporate veil was appropriately pierced to hold owner of swimming pool business personally liable for attorney fees awarded to competitor for defending frivolous lawsuit brought by swimming pool business, which sought to recover on claims assigned to it by competitor's bankruptcy creditors; owner was the business's president and sole stockholder, and he decided what actions to undertake. West's A.I.C. 34-52-1-1.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Swimming pool business's corporate veil was pierced to hold owner liable for frivolous suit sanctions.

Title: Attorney General v. M.C.K., Inc.
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Suffolk.
Headnote: Separate corporate identities of holder of nursing home license and owner of property on which home was operated could be disregarded, and sale of home, real property and personal property directed under Patient Protector Receivership Act; corporations were pervasively controlled by single shareholder, entities were thinly capitalized, corporate formalities were not observed and separate identities ignored, corporate funds were siphoned off to shareholder, and corporations were engaged in common enterprise; deception or fraud on part of entities was not required. M.G.L.A. c. 111, § 72R.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Residential Facilities. Sale of nursing home could include real property owned by related entity.

Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Virginia, Richmond Division.
Headnote: Under Virginia law, fraudulent conveyance from one corporation to another does not mean that the corporate veil ought to be pierced as to the individuals involved.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Successor liability would be imposed on company that acquired Chapter 7 debtor's assets prepetition.

Title: In re Blatstein
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: "Reverse" piercing of corporate veil of corporations controlled by Chapter 7 debtor was not warranted, so as to bring corporations' assets into debtor's bankruptcy estate, even though debtor and his spouse did not run corporations as strictly separate entities, inasmuch as debtor and spouse upheld corporate form sufficiently by having corporations keep separate records and bank accounts and entering on the books all loans that corporations made to each other and to shareholders, and given that debtor did not hide personal assets in corporations nor commingle his assets with corporations' assets to make separation impossible.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Reverse piercing of corporate veils of corporations controlled by debtor was not warranted.

Title: Pointer (U.S.A.), Inc. v. H & D Foods Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Corporate veil of importer of seafood would not be pierced, under Massachusetts law, to allow provider of line of credit to corporation to reach assets of sole shareholder, after drop in price of seafood caused corporation to become insolvent; credit line provider knew that corporation was short of capital and could not procure credit from financial institution.
Document Preview: Provider of credit to corporation engaged in importation of seafood sued sole shareholder, seeking to pierce corporate veil after corporation became insolvent and went out of business. Parties cross moved for summary judgment. The District Court, Griesa, J., held that: (1) provider's knowledge that corporation was short of capital precluded veil piercing, and (2) shareholder did not misuse corporate form by temporarily taking money from corporation to finance real estate venture of another corporation. Summary judgment for shareholder.

Title: In re Valley-Vulcan Mold Co.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Appellate Panel of the Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Finding that official unsecured creditors' committee had not established valid alter ego claim under Ohio law against Chapter 11 debtor-partnership's corporate parent was not clearly erroneous, where only alleged wrong asserted by committee, which corporate parent allegedly misused corporate form in order to commit, were transfers previously found insufficient to support fraudulent transfer claims. Ohio R.C. §§ 1336.04-1336.07 (Repealed).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Decision not to equitably subordinate claims was not abuse of discretion.

Headnote: When the dominant corporation renders the subservient corporation insolvent, then the requisite injury and causal connection for piercing the corporate veil are established.

Title: In re Erdman
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. North Dakota.
Headnote: Corporate veil could be pierced in order to hold Chapter 7 debtors personally liable on nondischargeable loan which they fraudulently secured on behalf of their corporation, where corporation never issued any shares, had no directors other than debtor-husband, and did not pay salaries or declare dividends, where debtor-husband freely commingled his assets with those of corporation and siphoned off proceeds of loan for his and his wife's personal benefit, where corporation was sorely undercapitalized, and where failure to pierce would allow debtors to avoid personal liability for fraudulent representations they made, including representations as to corporation's profitability and use they intended to make of loan proceeds.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could be pierced to hold debtors personally liable on nondischargeable loan.

Title: M. Sobol, Inc. v. James
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Term, New York., Second Department.
Headnote: Fact that corporation filed Chapter 7 bankruptcy proceedings, without more, did not establish fraudulent intent of corporation's sole shareholder to deceive unpaid seller of goods to corporation, as basis for disregarding the corporate form.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence that shareholder fraudulently used corporate assets to pay personal debt was admissible.

Title: In re Altman
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under New York law, corporate veil could be pierced to bring property owned by Chapter 11 debtor's corporations into bankruptcy estate, where debtor was sole and controlling shareholder of at least two of the three corporations, and presented no evidence to substantiate his claims that he had gratuitously granted another party a 50% interest in the third, and where debtor used corporate form to effect multiple transfers of painting in derogation of creditor's security interest therein, of which debtor was undoubtedly aware at time of transfers. Bankr.Code, 11 U.S.C.A. § 541(a)(1).
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Professionals. Creditors established requisite cause for appointing Chapter 11 trustee.

Title: In re Blatstein
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Corporate veil could not be pierced under Pennsylvania law, to hold Chapter 7 debtor-corporation's nondebtor affiliates liable on debtor's obligations, though corporate affiliates frequently assumed each other's loan obligations, loaned money to each other without interest, and paid dominant shareholder's personal expenses; affiliates maintained separate books and bank accounts and filed separate tax returns, and intercompany transactions, which totaled just over $1.2 million, or only 3.89% of combined corporate revenues, were not used to shelter funds from creditors.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Court caps landlord's rent claim based on date premises were re-leased.

Title: George Hyman Const. Co. v. Gateman
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Corporate veils of demolition subcontractor that did not pay its vendors and related demolition contracting company would not be pierced as to de facto shareholders, under Massachusetts law, even though shareholders had pervasive control of companies, subcontractor ultimately became insolvent, and companies were used, to limited extent, for transactions of shareholders, since there was a substantial regard for the separateness of the companies from the individuals.
Document Preview: General contractor brought action against demolition subcontractor, which did not pay its vendors, and subcontractor's shareholders. Shareholders filed counterclaim for unfair and deceptive trade practices. The District Court, Saris, J., held that: (1) shareholders could not be held liable for corporate debts by virtue of piercing the corporate veil; (2) general contractor failed to state claim for fraud; (3) shareholders' conduct in transferring money from subcontractor to related corporation was not an unfair and deceptive business practice; and (4) general contractor's suit was not baseless, so as to constitute an unfair and deceptive trade practice. So ordered.

Title: In re Main, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Corporate veil could not be pierced, so as to bring debtor-corporations' assets into bankruptcy estate of individual Chapter 7 debtor that controlled them, despite evidence of corporations' payment of individual debtor's loans, of individual debtor's use of corporate funds to pay his personal expenses, and of corporations' failure to document or to charge any interest on their purported loans to individual debtor, his wife, or other sister corporate entities; corporations were not in existence only to benefit individual debtor's private concerns but were, for the most part, financially stable and successful businesses, no evidence was presented that individual debtor abused legal separation of corporations for illegitimate purposes, each corporation kept its own financial records and had its own bank account, and no evidence was presented of any siphoning of corporate assets to individual debtor.
Document Preview: Business Organizations. Corporate veil could not be pierced, so as to bring debtor-corporations' assets into bankruptcy estate of individual Chapter 7 debtor.

Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Jacksonville Division.
Headnote: Notwithstanding common management, common business location, common personnel, common computer network, office equipment, and receptionist, and absence of corporate formality, related entities were not alter egos of Chapter 7 debtor-corporation under Florida law, as separate books were kept for each entity, funds from investors for each entity were deposited in separate account for each entity, and each entity was engaged in its own distinct business practice.

Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.

Headnote: Alter ego claim against parent corporation did not become property of bankruptcy estate when debtor-subsidiary filed bankruptcy petition and, thus, automatic stay did not apply to creditor's alter ego action against parent corporation as debtor-subsidiary may not bring alter ego claim against its parent company under Michigan law. Title: In re Montclair Homes
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Bankruptcy court, in interest of justice, would pierce the Chapter 7 debtor's corporate veil and hold debtor's principal personally responsible for debts of debtor corporation, given evidence that principal had operated debtor, a "spot builder" of residential real estate, without adequate capitalization and without ever observing any corporate formalities, given evidence that principal had freely used debtor's funds to pay his personal debts and debts of related corporate entities, and given evidence that, shortly before commencement of debtor's bankruptcy case, principal had effectively siphoned off all of debtor's assets and left debtor without funds to pay creditor claims.

Title: McDonough Marine Service, a Div. of Marmac Corp. v. Doucet
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate veil of corporations, which had become bankrupt, would not be pierced so as to expose shareholders to individual liability, even though it was claimed that corporations were alter ego of shareholders; corporation had reasonably complied with formalities, had separate bank accounts, filed separate income tax returns, conducted informal board meetings and insured that contracts were entered into by appropriate corporation, and there were valid business reasons for separate corporations, including need for separate corporation to hold Interstate Commerce Commission license allowing for government contracting.

Title: Winey v. Cutler
Court: Supreme Court of Vermont.
Headnote: Trustee process against corporation's earnings could not be defeated by judgment-debtor using his influence, as alter ego of corporation, to divert his salary to his wife. 12 V.S.A. § 3169(b)(1).

Title: Allard v. Arthur Andersen & Co. (USA)
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In action by bankruptcy trustee of corporate general partner against general partner's former auditors for failing to detect misappropriation of funds, trustee could not recover damages for losses sustained by limited partners on piercing corporate veil theory; under state law, limited partners' separate existence from general partner was mandated and could not be disregarded and, thus, trustee had no standing to assert rights of limited partners against general partner's former auditors.
Document Preview: Corporation's bankruptcy trustee brought action against corporation's former auditors for failing to detect or disclose misappropriation of funds, alleging malpractice, negligence, breach of contract, unjust enrichment, common-law fraud, aiding and abetting fraud, securities fraud, and violations of Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO).  Auditors moved for summary judgment. Headnote: Corporate form may be disregarded by bankruptcy court when domination of subservient corporation is shown.

Title: In re Manhattan Woods Golf Club, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Bankruptcy court could not engage in "reverse corporate veil-piercing" to hold Chapter 11 debtor-corporation liable on contracts of its corporate parent, where party seeking to invoke "reverse corporate veil-piercing" to assert claim against debtor for sums owing on their agreements with corporate parent were executive officers and directors of debtor, who were charged with knowledge of debtor's separate and distinct identity and with duty to maintain that separate identity; officers and directors would not be permitted to profit at expense of debtor's creditors by disregarding corporate entity they were charged with maintaining.
Document Preview: Corporations. corporate subsidiary's former officers and directors could not engage in reverse veil-piercing to hold subsidiary liable on their agreements with corporate parent.

Title: Towe v. Martinson
Court: United States District Court, D. Montana, Billings Division.
Headnote: Corporation formed by Chapter 7 debtor's children was alter ego of debtor, even though debtor was not stockholder in corporation; nearly all of corporation's assets originated with debtor, corporation was owned almost entirely either by debtor's family or debtor's entities, and debtor signed checks transferring large sums of money from corporation to debtor.

Title: Towe v. Martinson
Court: United States District Court, D. Montana, Billings Division.
Headnote: Under Montana law, corporate veil could be pierced to hold corporations liable for debts of Chapter 7 debtor; corporations were alter egos of debtor, and debtor used corporations to avoid and evade collection of taxes by IRS.

Title: Olen v. Phelps
Court: Court of Appeals of Wisconsin.
Headnote: Accounting firm was alter ego of its sole shareholder, and thus, avoiding conveyance of accounting firm's office building to shareholder's daughter as fraudulent as to shareholder's creditor would leave office building free for future garnishment by judgment creditor, where sole shareholder treated firm's funds as his own and commonly directed firm's funds to satisfy both corporate and personal debts, treated corporate assets as his own, used corporate funds to make mortgage payments both on corporate office building and his own properties, and treated firm as corporation only when it was convenient.
Document Preview: Garnishment. Reverse veil-piercing applied to permit judgment creditor of sole shareholder of accounting firm to garnish accounting firm office building to satisfy judgment against sole shareholder.

Headnote: Corporate creditor constituted mere alter ego of Chapter 7 corporate debtor, and, thus, creditor's corporate form had to be disregarded and its lien voided, where debtor's president and sole stockholder completely controlled creditor's stock ownership, officers, directorships, finances, policies and practices, and every other corporate function without regard to any corporate formality, and where financial transactions giving rise to asserted lien bore none of the features of arm's length transaction.

On remand, the bankruptcy court held that creditor's lien was null and void, and creditor appealed.  The District Court, Stephen M. Reasoner, Chief Judge, affirmed, and creditor appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Heaney, Senior Circuit Judge, held that: (1) proceeding did not constitute alter ego proceeding over which trustee would not have standing; (2) bankruptcy court had jurisdiction over proceeding, even though liens asserted...

Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Colorado.

West's C.R.S.A. §§ 7-114-106, 7-114-108.

Title: In re Coala, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Alabama, Northern Division.
Headnote: Under Alabama law, property owned by corporations related to Chapter 7 debtor could not be reached by piercing debtor's corporate veil; if grounds existed for piercing debtor's corporate veil, remedy was by separate suit for money judgment against debtor's stockholders.

Title: In re Coala, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Alabama, Northern Division.
Headnote: Under Alabama law, even if Chapter 7 debtor's stockholders owned all stock of related corporations, debtor's former employees had not provided basis for piercing debtor's corporation veil, or for finding that stockholders were alter egos of related corporations for which they served as presidents, and, thus, debt to employees could not be satisfied from sewing machine equipment leased by debtor from corporations, where employees had not proved that either debtor or related corporations were undercapitalized, facts did not show any fraudulent purpose or scheme in lease transaction, and employees had not proved that stockholders treated debtor and related corporations as mere instrumentalities.
Document Preview: Corporations. Chapter 7 debtor's employees failed to establish that debtor's shareholders were alter egos of corporations that leased equipment to debtor so as to subject equipment to debtor's creditors' claims.

Title: Scholes v. Lehmann
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Standing of receiver for corporations created by Ponzi scheme principal to assert fraudulent conveyance claims would not be affected by corporations' status as principal's alter ego; availability of reverse veil piercing to reach corporate assets would not render corporations incapable of being injured by allegedly fraudulent conveyances. Ill.Rev.Stat.1989, ch. 59, ¶ 4.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Fraudulent Transfers. Fraudulent conveyance statute could not be interpreted to exclude gifts to religious groups and other charitable organizations.

Title: Wolf v. Walt
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: For purposes of determining whether corporate veil should be pierced, corporation would be deemed "insolvent" if it is unable to pay its debts as they become due in usual course of its business, or if it has excess of liabilities over assets at fair valuation. Neb.Rev.St. § 21–2002(15).
Document Preview: Lessor of cattle brought suit against sole shareholder of lessee, seeking recovery under theories of conversion, constructive fraud, breach of contract and bailment.  Claims were either dismissed by trial court or found against lessor by jury, and the District Court, Cuming County, Robert B. Ensz, J., entered judgment for lessee.  Appeal was taken.  The Supreme Court, Lanphier, J., held that: (1) corporate veil would not be pierced; (2) shareholder had not converted cattle; and (3) shareholder had not committed constructive fraud. Affirmed.

Title: Wolf v. Walt
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: Corporation which was lessee of cattle had not been used to commit fraud, violate legal duty, or perpetuate dishonest or unjust act, so as to allow piercing of corporate veil to reach assets of sole shareholder; evidence as to amount of adequacy of capitalization was inconclusive, making of some lease payments belied idea that corporation was insolvent at time it incurred debt in question, and there was no indication of diversion of corporation's assets for individual use of shareholder.

Title: In re Black
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Texas, Sherman Division.
Headnote: Evidence that Chapter 7 debtor was president and controlling shareholder of Chapter 11 debtor in possession (DIP) and was personally responsible for day-to-day operations of DIP and that DIP acted through its president and majority shareholder at all relevant times was insufficient to show, under Texas law, that DIP was alter ego of Chapter 7 debtor so as to justify piercing corporate veil to make Chapter 7 debtor per se liable for DIP's failure to pay over proceeds from sale of secured inventory to secured creditor, as required by financing statements and cash collateral order, where there was no evidence to suggest that any actions of Chapter 7 debtor were ultra vires and there was no intent on part of Chapter 7 debtor to take any action other than discharge of his duty to corporation.
Document Preview: CORPORATIONS. Chapter 7 debtor president of Chapter 11 debtor in possession, was not personally liable for DIP's breach of fiduciary duty and willful malicious acts in using proceeds from sale of secured inventory to pay other expenses while under duty to remit proceeds to secured creditor.

Title: In re Mass
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Reverse piercing of corporate veil was available under Pennsylvania law, even absent any allegation of fraud or misconduct by debtor-shareholders, in order to make corporate assets available in Chapter 11 for payment of debtor-shareholders' creditors.
Document Preview: VEIL PIERCING. reverse piercing of corporate veil was appropriate, to make assets of debtor-shareholders' wholly owned corporation available for payment of creditors.

Title: In re Mass
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Unusual circumstances existed that would support reverse piercing of corporate veil under Pennsylvania law, in order to make assets of Chapter 11 debtors' corporation available for payment of creditor claims, where debtor-shareholders had totally failed to observe any corporate formalities, to keep corporate records, or to hold directors' or shareholders' meetings, had no checking account of their own, and used corporate account to pay business and personal expenses, including personal telephone bills and mortgage payments; reverse piercing was warranted to place creditor that had garnished corporate account on same footing as all other creditors of debtor-shareholders.
Document Preview: VEIL PIERCING. reverse piercing of corporate veil was appropriate, to make assets of debtor-shareholders' wholly owned corporation available for payment of creditors.

Title: In re Brandywine River Hotel, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: "Corporate veil" would not be pierced so as to collapse general partnership, which owned hotel, and Chapter 11 corporate debtor, which operated hotel, into one entity, and thus, assignment of rents language in partnership's mortgage did not permit mortgagee to attach corporation's operating revenues, even though same persons were partnership's partners and corporation's sole shareholders, lease amendment between partnership and corporation had reduced rent payable by corporation, and lease was partnership's only source of income, where mortgagee was always aware of bifurcated ownership interests of realty versus hotel business, each entity had separate annual financial statements, and mortgagee's ability to exercise its state law collection rights was not affected by lease amendment.
Document Preview: HOTEL REVENUES. partnership, which owned hotel, and Chapter 11 debtor-corporation, which operated hotel, would not be collapsed into one entity in determining whether partnership's mortgagee could attach corporation's operating revenues.

Title: In re United Stairs Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Nondebtor affiliated entity was merely extension of Chapter 7 debtor, where nondebtor entity essentially took over debtor's operations and purchased location of debtor's business for consideration of $1, nondebtor entity's employees were former employees of debtor, and nondebtor entity's president, daughter of sole shareholder of debtor, actually had no idea how these employees were paid.
Document Preview: CONSOLIDATION. individual creditor had standing to bring action for substantive consolidation against nondebtor entity.

Title: In re Americana Services, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Missouri.
Headnote: While principal's wholly owned company was liable only to extent that it was recipient of any fraudulent transfer from corporate-debtor, principals of debtor were liable for all fraudulent transfers from debtor, whether directly received by them or not, under both alter ego theory and fiduciary theory; principals transferred debtor's assets to themselves and to corporations that principals owned and controlled, and principals had total control of debtor as sole shareholders, sole directors and sole officers of debtor.
Document Preview: FRAUDULENT TRANSFERS. principals of corporate-debtor made fraudulent transfers and were liable for all such transfers, whether directly received by them or not, under both alter ego theory and fiduciary theory.

Title: In re Pajaro Dunes Rental Agency, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Lender named as defendant in fraudulent transfer proceeding could not pierce corporate veil, for purposes of establishing that loan proceeds advanced to corporate parent constituted "reasonably equivalent value" for promissory note signed by subsidiary, notwithstanding parent's control over subsidiary's day-to-day operations and constant upstreaming of cash from subsidiary to corporate parent; corporate parent had also signed note and was directly liable to lender thereon, and piercing of corporate veil would not prevent injustice but prejudice subsidiary's other creditors. Bankr.Code, 11 U.S.C.A. § 548.
Document Preview: FRAUDULENT TRANSFERS. chapter 11 debtor did not receive reasonably equivalent value for its obligation to lender on note, through disbursement of loan proceeds to its corporate parent.

Title: Matter of Commonweal, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division.
Headnote: Eleventh Circuit Shades Ridge decision, that issue of "nominee" status of corporation under either state or federal law depends on who has active or substantial control of corporation, in no way limits bankruptcy court's power to ignore fiction of separateness in interests of equity or justice.
Document Preview: CORPORATIONS. corporate debtor was nominee of individual taxpayer and liable for individual taxpayer's obligations.

Title: Matter of New Center Hosp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Various medical corporations, including Chapter 11 debtor hospital, health services corporation incorporated by hospital trustees, and clinics purchased by health services corporation using hospital funds, acted as alter egos of one another, as required to pierce corporate veil under Michigan or federal law; assets and operations of entities were extensively commingled, health services corporation was instrumentality of hospital serving merely as conduit for transfer of revenue from hospital to clinics, and hospital avoided garnishments and levies by using clinic bank account.
Document Preview: CORPORATIONS. Equities required that nondebtor medical corporations be substantively consolidated with estate of Chapter 11 debtor hospital.

Title: In re Nutri/System, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Neither prospective purchaser of Chapter 11 debtors nor entities controlled by prospective purchaser "controlled" corporate debtors in such a way as would permit disregarding debtors' separate corporate existences, under Pennsylvania law; although prospective purchaser, with court approval, had gained control of debtors in ordinary corporate governance sense, he did not utilize debtors as his mere appendages in aid of accomplishing illicit or underhanded designs, and debtors' financial picture was cast long before arrival of prospective purchaser and entities on the scene.
Document Preview: EQUITABLE SUBORDINATION. landlords of stores leased to Chapter 11 debtors failed to establish that prospective purchaser of Chapter 11 debtors, who eventually acquired debtors, and who ran debtors during reorganization, and related entities treated landlords unfairly, and thus, claims of prospective purchaser and related entities would not be equitably subordinated.

Title: In re Nutri/System, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Landlords of stores leased to Chapter 11 debtor corporations failed to establish that corporate formalities were dispensed with once prospective purchaser of debtors took control of debtors, or that prospective purchaser and related entities had intent to perpetrate fraud or injustice, and thus, corporate entities of debtors would not be disregarded to hold prospective purchaser and related entities liable for rent claimed by landlords, under Pennsylvania law; administrative requirements of the Bankruptcy Code were met, there was no evidence of missing or incomplete records, and design of prospective purchaser to gain control of debtors was fully disclosed and supported by most of parties who took active role in bankruptcy cases.
Document Preview: EQUITABLE SUBORDINATION. landlords of stores leased to Chapter 11 debtors failed to establish that prospective purchaser of Chapter 11 debtors, who eventually acquired debtors, and who ran debtors during reorganization, and related entities treated landlords unfairly, and thus, claims of prospective purchaser and related entities would not be equitably subordinated.

Title: In re Loevner
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Virginia, Alexandria Division.
Headnote: Under Virginia law, debtor was alter ego of corporation, and thus was not insulated from issues of whether corporation's fraudulent transactions with client's money created nondischargeable debt, where debtor was officer, director, and 50% shareholder in corporation, and debtor was person who made investment decisions concerning client funds.

Headnote: Bankruptcy trustee could assert reverse piercing of corporate veil theory in preference action against creditor of incorporated subsidiary of debtor. Bankr.Code, 11 U.S.C.A. § 547(b).
Document Preview: LIMITATIONS PERIODS. in case converted to Chapter 7 after appointment of Chapter 11 trustee, Chapter 7 trustee has two years from date of appointment to bring actions under avoiding powers.

Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Even corporation that has filed for Chapter 7 liquidation may have alter ego.

Title: In re HSR Associates
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, corporate partner's principal's uncontested statements that he did not want other partner to obtain partnership property and would tie other partner up in litigation did not constitute fraud, and, therefore, statements did not provide basis for piercing corporate veil and holding principal liable for damages under Bankruptcy Code for corporate partner's filing of involuntary Chapter 11 petition against partnership in bad faith and for improper purpose. Bankr.Code, 11 U.S.C.A. § 303(i).
Document Preview: INVOLUNTARY PETITIONS. Chapter 11 debtor's partner failed to show cause to pierce corporate veil and hold other corporate partner's principal liable for damages under Bankruptcy Code for filing of involuntary petition against partnership in bad faith and for improper purpose.

Title: In re Nahas
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, corporate veil could not be pierced so as to include, in property in corporate principal's bankruptcy estate, insurance proceeds properly payable to corporation, where corporation paid premiums for insurance and was named an intended beneficiary, and where no evidence was presented that corporation failed to observe corporate formalities; corporation held annual shareholder's meetings, of which minutes were kept, corporation filed its own tax returns and had bank account separate from that of corporate principal.
Document Preview: ESTATE PROPERTY. corporate veil could not be pierced in order to bring insurance proceeds available to corporation into corporate principal's bankruptcy estate.

Title: In re Carrousel Motels, Inc.

Headnote: Bank could not use alter ego doctrine to require consideration of financial health of all entities in group of corporations controlled by same individual who also controlled debtor-corporation to determine whether debtor was insolvent when transfers of notes were made by debtor to bank, for purposes of fraudulent transfer claims, absent any allegation of misuse of corporateness and where debtor was distinct operating entity that had generated body of creditors in its operations.

Title: Smetherman v. Wilson
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil for benefit of one shareholder and at expense of another shareholder was inappropriate; neither shareholder actively participated in operation of corporation prior to its insolvency, statutory formalities were met, failure to file annual report was inconsequential since corporation existed for less than one year, and no allegations were made concerning commingling of corporate and shareholder funds, undercapitalization, and failure to keep separate bank accounts and bookkeeping records.
Document Preview: Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing veil was inappropriate.

Title: In re Newtowne, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, mere fact that debtor and sister corporation shared same common shareholders, shared office space, shared telephone line, and may have shared expenses was not sufficient basis for disregarding their separate corporate identities, for purpose of deciding whether debtor received "reasonably equivalent value" for its alleged fraudulent transfer of property to third party in satisfaction of sister corporation's debt.
Document Preview: FRAUDULENT TRANSFERS. court could not ignore debtor's and sister corporation's separate corporate identities for purpose of deciding whether debtor received reasonably equivalent value for alleged fraudulent transfer in satisfaction of sister corporation's debt.

Headnote: Chapter 7 debtor employer's corporate veil would not be pierced so as to hold its president personally liable for all of debtor's debts, where no probative evidence was produced that corporate entity was alter ego, alias, stooge, or dummy of president and that corporation was device or sham used to disguise wrongs, obscure fraud, or conceal crime.

Title: In re Vermont Toy Works, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Vermont.
Headnote: Under Vermont law, debtor's failure to hold director's meetings and to approve by disinterested quorum of directors certain actions with sole shareholder was insufficient to justify piercing of corporate veil to satisfy common debtor element of marshaling doctrine. 11 V.S.A. § 1882.
Document Preview: Involuntary Chapter 7 bankruptcy proceeding was filed.
