Title: In re Dakota Drilling, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. North Dakota.
Headnote: Even assuming bankruptcy trustee for corporate debtor had standing to pursue alter ego remedy against debtor's principal officers, principal officers were not alter ego of debtor; debtor kept independent accounts of its operations and maintained books and records of its businesses which were detailed and complete, and principal officers took gradual reductions in their monthly salary as debtor entered closer to bankruptcy and made payments to debtor to keep the business afloat.
Document Preview: Trustee for corporate Chapter 7 debtor filed proceeding to avoid transfers.  The Bankruptcy Court, William A. Hill, J., held that: (1) trustee did not have standing to pursue alter ego remedy against debtor's principal officers; (2) even if trustee had standing to pursue alter ego remedy, principal officers were not alter ego of debtor; (3) transfers made while debtor was solvent could not be recovered on preferential transfer theory; and (4) transfers between debtor and principal officers could not be avoided on fraudulent transfer theory. So ordered.

Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota, Third Division.
Headnote: Chapter 7 trustee had no power to assert an alter ego remedy theory, derivative of property interests of the estate, against a corporation of which debtor was a principal but not a shareholder; under Minnesota corporations law, "reverse piercing" of corporate veil is not available to creditors, and person or entity invoking such piercing must have some sort of substantial property interest in corporation itself. Bankr.Code, 11 U.S.C.A. §§ 541(a)(1), 704.

Motions granted in part and denied in part.

Title: In re Murray
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Virginia, Norfolk Division.
Headnote: Corporate veil was not defense to secured creditor's claim that bankruptcy debtors, who were sole shareholders of corporation, were liable for conversion of secured creditors' property, which occurred when corporation surrendered property in which creditors had priority security interest to suppliers in exchange for credit on suppliers' accounts, even though security agreement spoke of corporate entity; promissory note and agreement of purchase and sale were individually signed, and debtors were in reality the corporation.
Document Preview: Creditors which had security interest in corporation's property brought adversary proceeding in sole shareholders' Chapter 7 case to determine dischargeability of debt.  The Bankruptcy Court, Hal J. Bonney, Jr., J., held that: (1) constructive or implied malice is sufficient to establish malice, within meaning of exception from discharge for any debt for willful and malicious injury by debtor to another person or to property of another person; (2) debtors converted secured creditors' property by surrendering inventory in which creditors had priority security interest to suppliers in exchange for credit on suppliers' accounts; (3) corporate veil was not defense to secured creditors' claim; and (4) debt was dischargeable despite conversion, where debtors had placed their trust in counsel and in good faith followed counsel's advice. So ordered.

Headnote: Corporate veil would be pierced to establish bankruptcy debtor as equitable owner of corporate stock which was ostensibly owned by debtor's father and, therefore, stock was property of estate and was properly subject of turnover order, where most of funds designated as father's capital contribution for stock was originally intended as loan to corporation controlled by debtor and debtor exercised control over corporation and drew generous salary from corporation. The District Court, Freedman, Chief Judge, held that: (1) corporate veil would be pierced to establish debtor as equitable owner of corporate stock which was ostensibly owned by debtor's father, and therefore, stock was property of estate subject to turnover order, and (2) evidence was insufficient to establish debtor concealed his beneficial interest in stock so as to warrant denial of discharge. Title: In re Blanton
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Texas, Austin Division.
Headnote: In context of action to pierce the corporate veil under Texas law, point at which company becomes insolvent is important in trust fund theory when company has ceased to do business in normal fashion because at that point directors have duty not to prefer one creditor over another and corporate veil may be pierced when this has been done.
Document Preview: Chapter 7 debtors objected to claim of Arizona Department of Revenue for gross receipt taxes incurred by corporation owned by one debtor while corporation performed two family housing rehabilitation contracts at Air Force base in Arizona. The Bankruptcy Court, Larry E. Kelly, Chief Judge, held that: (1) Texas law applied to determine whether corporate veil should be pierced; (2) ground for piercing corporate veil, that corporate form was resorted to as means of invading existing legal obligation, was inapplicable; (3) ground for piercing corporate veil, that corporation was mere alter ego of debtor, was inapplicable; and (4) ground for piercing corporate veil, that corporate entity of corporation and its related entities were used as means of perpetrating fraud, was inapplicable. Objection granted.

Title: Campisano v. Nardi
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Sole shareholder and officer of dissolved corporate contractor was not personally liable for corporations breach of contract under instrumentality rule where, although officer exercised complete domination over finances, policy and business practice of corporation, there was no showing that he used control over corporation to commit fraud or other wrong or injustice.
Document Preview: Homeowners brought action seeking to hold sole shareholder officer and director of dissolved corporate contractor liable for breach of contract entered into by corporation prior to dissolution.  The Stamford-Norwalk Superior Court, Cioffi, J., granted defendant's motion for judgment in accordance with report of Dennis G. Eveleigh, referee, recommending judgment for defendant and Lewis, J., rendered judgment in accordance with referee's report.  Plaintiffs appealed.  The Supreme Court, Peters, C.J., held that: (1) plaintiffs failed to prove that officer had committed fraud, and (2) sole shareholder, officer and director of corporation dissolved by forfeiture could not be held personally liable for breach of contract entered into by corporation prior to its dissolution. No error.

Title: Keffer v. H.K. Porter Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Parent company was financially liable to continue retiree medical and life insurance benefits which its wholly owned subsidiary was obligated to pay where it would have been fundamentally unfair to allow parent to escape liability by hiding behind insolvent subsidiary's corporate existence, given parent's sale of insolvent's assets and its subsequent retention of nearly $9 million in proceeds; disregard of corporate entity was also justified by subsidiary's gross undercapitalization and excessive control exercised by parent over subsidiary through management system which required, among other things, parent's approval of any expenditures in excess of $25,000.
Document Preview: Retirees brought suit against wholly owned subsidiary and parent seeking continuation of health and life insurance benefits after expiration of collective bargaining agreement and subsidiary's insolvency.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of West Virginia, Robert J. Staker, J., held that subsidiary was under an obligation to continue benefits and that parent was also financially liable for benefits continuation. Subsidiary and parent appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Phillips, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) subsidiary's obligation to provide retiree medical and life insurance benefits survived expiration of subsidiary's collective bargaining agreement, and (2) facts justified disregard of corporate entity so as to hold parent financially liable for continuation of benefits. Affirmed.

Title: In re Hill Petroleum Co.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Louisiana, Lafayette–Opelousas Division.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, two corporations that were under common control would be held solidarily liable to bankruptcy estate for petroleum products that corporations claimed were purchased by only one of them; reports of purchase to state Tax Commission indicated purchase by allegedly nonpurchasing corporation, no consideration passed from allegedly nonpurchasing corporation to allegedly purchasing corporation for products lifted by allegedly nonpurchasing corporation, and fiction of separate corporate identities should be disregarded.
Document Preview: Chapter 11 liquidator for debtor that was petroleum product seller brought action against corporations that were under common control for unpaid monies due for sales of petroleum products.  The Bankruptcy Court, W. Donald Boe, Jr., J., held that: (1) corporations were solidarily liable for product purchase price, although it was claimed only one of the corporations had purchased products, under Louisiana law; (2) claimed setoff by corporation that purchased petroleum products of debt owed seller against amounts owed another corporation under common control by seller was invalid; and (3) under Louisiana law, corporation was not entitled to cleaning fees for tanks that had stored petroleum product seller's unleaded gasoline, leaded gasoline, and diesel fuel. Judgment against defendant corporations.

Title: In re Iowa-Missouri Realty Co., Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Missouri.
Headnote: Under Missouri law, bankruptcy court could not disregard separate identities of debtor and corporate parent, for purpose of holding the transfer of property by parent was transfer by debtor as well, where debtor and parent maintained separate books, records and business operations, and no evidence was presented to contradict apparent legitimate purposes of businesses or to indicate insufficiency of funding or diversion of assets.
Document Preview: Chapter 11 debtor-in-possession brought adversary proceeding to avoid deed of trust lien claimed by the SBA on real property owned by debtor, and the Small Business Administration moved to terminate stay.  The Bankruptcy Court, Karen M. See, J., held that: (1) creditor which acquired deed of trust from property owner's corporate parent acquired no lien therein, as parent, unlike subsidiary, was stranger to title; (2) deed of trust executed by parent could not be reformed after filing of property owner's Chapter 11 petition; and (3) bankruptcy court could not disregard separate identities of debtor and parent, for purpose of holding the transfer of property by parent was transfer by debtor as well. So ordered.

Title: In re Lazar
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Corporation formed solely for purpose of taking title to boat purchased with funds of debtor, and on which debtor subsequently lived, qualified as debtor's "alter ego" against which trustee could maintain turnover action.
Document Preview: Trustee brought adversary proceeding to recover alleged fraudulent transfers. Creditors moved for order denying debtor's discharge in bankruptcy based on alleged fraud. The Bankruptcy Court, Sidney M. Weaver, J., held that: (1) property which debtor transferred to family members for no consideration, within a few months of creditors' state court action against him, was transferred with intent to hinder, delay and defraud creditors; (2) corporation formed solely for purpose of taking title to boat purchased with funds of debtor, and on which debtor subsequently lived, qualified as debtor's alter ego against which trustee could maintain turnover action; and (3) debtor's failure to disclose property on bankruptcy schedules, and his false statements under oath regarding property interests, warranted denial of discharge in bankruptcy. So ordered.

Title: In re Duque Rodriguez
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Bankruptcy court would not pierce and ignore corporate veil which separated debtor parent corporation from its wholly owned subsidiary under Florida law, in action by trustee to recover transfers consisting of payments made by debtor upon chattel mortgage held on Lear jet owned by subsidiary on theory of constructive fraud; there was no evidence that subsidiary was organized or used for any illegal purpose or to mislead or defraud its only creditor, but rather, it was conceded that credit was extended primarily upon value of aircraft that was collateral for debt and secondarily upon guarantees of debtor's owner and another subsidiary of debtor, with no reliance being placed on debtor's credit. Bankr.Code, 11 U.S.C.A. §§ 548(a)(2), 550(a)(1).
Document Preview: Trustee for Chapter 7 debtor corporation sought recovery on constructive fraud theory of payments made by debtor on chattel mortgage held upon jet owned by wholly owned subsidiary of debtor, which obligation was not guaranteed by debtor. The Bankruptcy Court, Thomas C. Britton, Chief Judge, held that: (1) transfers involved interest of the debtor in property, although debtor was offshore holding company that could not itself generate any income, but received income from its wholly owned subsidiaries and its sole owner, and transferee claimed debtor was therefore mere conduit for payments of another entity's funds; (2) debtor did not receive reasonably equivalent value in exchange for the payments, which did not increase the subsidiary's net worth; and (3) under Florida law, bankruptcy court would not pierce and ignore corporate veil which separated debtor parent and wholly owned subsidiary. Judgment for trustee. See also, Bkrtcy., 77 B.R. 937.

Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Corporation against which involuntary petition was brought was one and the same as sister corporation which owed debts to petitioning creditors, and order for relief would thus be entered, rendering corporation against which petition was brought debtor under Chapter 7; facts justified piercing corporate veil and presented no bona fide dispute as to liability of corporation to petitioning creditors. Bankr.Code, 11 U.S.C.A. § 303(h)(1).

Ordered accordingly.

Title: Matter of Walway Co.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Debtor corporation and holding company that owned it were each identifiable entities within strictures of corporations law, so that bankruptcy court could not exercise jurisdiction over nondebtor corporation, even though companies had filed joint tax returns. Bankr.Code, 11 U.S.C.A. § 101(12); 28 U.S.C.A. §§ 157, 1334.
Document Preview: Chapter 11 debtor brought adversary proceeding to reject collective bargaining agreement. Title: In re WJM, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Piercing of corporate veil to include real estate acquired by related trusts as assets of estates of debtor nursing home providers was not justified, in determining solvency of debtors for purposes of determining whether Massachusetts Department of Public Welfare's deductions from prepetition reimbursements to debtor nursing home providers to satisfy overpayments made by Department to other nursing providers could be set aside as preferential transfers; separate books and records were maintained by the entities, there was no intermingling of funds or assets, and sufficient disclosure of separate ownership and income of entities, relationship of nursing homes, trusts, management company, and corporate owners to one another was made to Department on forms filed in years prior to filing of petitions. The District Court, Mazzone, J., held that: (1) transfers took place by reason of Department's decision to offset, for purposes of statute governing avoidable preferential transfers; (2) Department had not established its prepetition deductions satisfied setoff requirement of mutuality; and (3) exhaustion doctrine did not deprive Bankruptcy Court of jurisdiction based on fact appeals of final nursing home rates were pending before State Division of Administrative Law Appeals. Title: In re Peoples Bankshares, Ltd.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Iowa.
Headnote: Property interest of debtor's bankruptcy estate extends only to intangible personal property rights represented by stock certificates indicating ownership in corporation, even though debtor owns 100% of corporate stock; technical, legal distinctionsbetween corporations will be respected and applied with reference to automatic stays of actions against property of estate. Bankr.Code, 11 U.S.C.A. § 362(a)(2, 3).
Document Preview: Chapter 11 debtor bank holding company brought declaratory judgment action seeking determination that state superintendent of banking was stayed from exercising his regulatory authority over five state-chartered subsidiary banks wholly owned, or mostly owned, by debtor bank holding company, or alternatively, determination that bankruptcy court had right to issue injunction against superintendent.  Department of Banking moved to dismiss.  The Bankruptcy Court, Michael J. Melloy, J., held that: (1) automatic stay of actions against debtor did not apply to state banks controlled by debtor; (2) debtor's ownership of all or nearly all of outstanding shares of stock in state banks did not make banks themselves property of bankruptcy estate, so automatic stay of actions against property of estate did not apply; and (3) bankruptcy court did not have jurisdiction to enjoin superintendent from taking action against state banks. Adversary proceeding dismissed.

Title: In re Landbank Equity Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Virginia, Norfolk Division.
Headnote: Brother of one of two stockholders of debtor was "insider," for purposes of defining time frame applicable to recovery of favored or preferred payments, where brother was uncontested sole stockholder and officer of corporate entity which was alter ego of debtor and was part of same fraud and scheme by which debtor was relieved of assets. Bankr.Code, 11 U.S.C.A. §§ 101(28), 547(c).
Document Preview: Trustee brought action seeking to recover from relatives and entities related to debtor funds trustee believed went to them illegally.  The Bankruptcy Court, Hal J. Bonney, Jr., J., held that: (1) position of stockholder-president in center of stew with knowledge, with nothing at arms' length, and as conductor through which manipulations of 90 entities passed was clearly fraud; (2) routine failure to charge points on second mortgages to insiders became fraudulent design due to widespread nature of failure to charge points and involvement of large amounts of money; and (3) exemplary damages of threefold actual damages would be awarded; but (4) actions of individuals in relation to debtor were not conspiracy. Title: Almac, Inc. v. JRH Development, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: Mere fact that corporation became insolvent did not mean that corporation was undercapitalized for purposes of determining whether to permit corporation's creditor to pierce corporate veil where total equity kept pace with corporation liabilities until president could no longer bear to plow any more of his personal funds into corporation.
Document Preview: Creditor sued corporation and its president to collect on promissory note backed by mortgage.  The District Court, Scott County, John M. Fitzgerald, J., determined that the president was personally liable.  President appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Crippen, J., held that: (1) the trial court erroneously pierced the corporate veil to hold the president liable; (2) there was no basis for promoter liability where a de facto corporation existed at the time the president executed the note; and (3) the president was not responsible for attorney fees incurred by the corporation. Reversed.

Title: Matter of Kaiser
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Trustee stood in shoes of unsecured creditors who would have been entitled, under Wisconsin law, to pierce veil of principal's corporation for misrepresentation of his personal assets as corporate assets in order to induce extension of additional credit to corporation, but, in any event, principal, by holding out land as corporation's property, made it corporation's property so far as corporation's creditors were concerned, and land was property of corporation's bankruptcy estate. Bankr.Code, 11 U.S.C.A. § 541.
Document Preview: Appeal was taken from judgment of the United States District Court for the Western District of Wisconsin, John C. Shabaz, J., affirming Bankruptcy Court judgment holding that property claimed by trustee was part of bankruptcy estate.  The Court of Appeals, Posner, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) real property was part of bankruptcy estate; (2) utilitarian items of personal property were property of the estate; and (3) there was fact question as to whether decorative items of personal property were property of the estate. Affirmed in part, reversed in part and remanded with directions.

Title: Matter of Reading Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: No basis existed for ignoring corporate distinction between reorganized railroad and other railroad so as to permit reorganized railroad to reject lease entered into by other railroad; there was no allegation that distinction was in any way fraudulent or wrongful, other railroad had not been operated as part of reorganized railroad, and allowing trustee to reject trust lease would frustrate rather than advance public interest in continued rail operation. Bankr. Act, § 77(a, b), 11 U.S.C.(1976 Ed.) § 205(a, b).
Document Preview: Prereorganization petition of reorganized railroad to both disaffirm lease and collect damages for breach of lease came before court. The District Court, Ditter, J., held that: (1) basis for ignoring corporate distinction between reorganized railroad and another railroad which would permit reorganized railroad to reject lease entered into by other railroad did not exist, and (2) reorganization court lacked jurisdiction to consider reorganized railroad's claims that lessee breached provisions of lease of which it was third-party beneficiary. Order accordingly.

Title: In re Bellanca Aircraft Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Creditor, a corporation, was not entitled to pierce its own corporate veil so as to take credit for new value advanced by its subsidiary to debtor under § 547(c)(4), which precludes trustee from avoiding transfer as preferential to extent that creditor subsequently gives new value to or for benefit of debtor. Bankr.Code, 11 U.S.C.A. § 547(b), (c)(4).
Document Preview: Trustee filed complaint seeking to avoid certain allegedly preferential and postpetition transfers from debtor to creditors, a corporation and its subsidiary, and to equitably subordinate creditors' claims against estate. Creditors sought claim for administrative expenses.  The Bankruptcy Court, Margaret A. Mahoney, J., held that: (1) property debtor preferentially transferred to second creditor was entirely offset by second creditor's subsequent new value advances to debtor, and thus, trustee was not entitled to avoid any transfers to second creditor; (2) first creditor was only entitled to partial offset against preferential transfers for new value subsequently advanced to debtor, and thus, trustee was entitled to avoid preferential transfers in amount of $111,010.38; and (3) trustee failed to establish inequitable conduct on part of creditors warranting equitable subordination of their claims. Order accordingly.

Title: West Bldg. Materials, Inc. v. Daley
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Shareholder's use of building materials purchased by corporation to improve shareholder's building did not perpetrate fraud against supplier of building materials, even though corporation subsequently ceased operating and was insolvent, where refurbished property was building which housed office of corporation, absent evidence that shareholder incurred debts in anticipation of closing corporation in order to evade his obligation, particularly where corporation was never formally liquidated.
Document Preview: Supplier of building materials brought action against shareholder on open account maintained by corporation.  The Lake Charles City Court, Parish of Calcasieu, Nick Pizzolatto, Jr., J. ad hoc., entered judgment for shareholder, and supplier appealed.  The Court of Appeal, Stoker, J., held that: (1) shareholder's use of materials purchased by corporation to improve shareholder's building which housed corporation did not perpetrate fraud upon supplier; (2) shareholder's use of some of building materials purchased by corporation for shareholder's personal benefit and fact that there were no regular shareholders' meetings of corporation were insufficient to justify piercing corporate veil and holding shareholder liable for corporation's debt; and (3) shareholder's use of building materials purchased by corporation to refurbish shareholder's building did not entitle supplier to recover against shareholder on theory of unjust enrichment. Affirmed.

Title: In re Tampa Chain Co., Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Equitable subordination, as companion doctrine of disregard of corporate veil, lies where principals of corporation engaged in fraud or other inequitable conduct resulting in harm to creditors or an unfair advantage to claimant, and is not contrary to principals of bankruptcy law.
Document Preview: Secured creditor sought order directing trustee to turn over proceeds of debtor's inventory, and trustee sought marshalling order requiring creditor to first proceed against shareholders/guarantors of debt to creditor.  The Bankruptcy Court, Howard C. Buschman, III, J., held that: (1) fraud and inequitable conduct of shareholders warranted treating shareholders and corporate debtor as a common debtor, so as to allow marshalling of assets, where debtor's capitalization was removed and replenished by one shareholder, assets were transferred by shareholders to another family corporation, and corporate funds were used to redeem personal jewelry of second shareholder; (2) trustee failed to establish by preponderance of credible evidence the defense of payment of portion of amount claimed due on loan; and (3) creditor was entitled to attorney fees for action seeking turnover of proceeds of collateral. Order accordingly.

Title: In re Criswell
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Virginia, Richmond Division.
Headnote: House purchasers were not entitled to pierce corporate veil of corporate debtor as builder to hold liable the individual debtor, one of two shareholders, which was a requirement for purchasers' success on dischargeability claims, notwithstanding that corporation was dominated by its two shareholders. There was no fraud on part of individual debtor with respect to transaction between the parties, there was no evidence of either failure to observe corporate formalities, and there was no evidence of nonpayment of dividends, siphoning of funds by individual debtor, nonfunctioning of other officers or directors, absence or corporate records or that corporation was grossly undercapitalized for purposes of corporate undertaking.
Document Preview: House purchasers filed complaint seeking determination of nondischargeability with respect to debt alleged to be owed by debtor as house builder.  The Bankruptcy Court, Blackwell N. Shelley, J., held that: (1) purchasers were not entitled to pierce corporate veil, which was a requirement in order for purchasers to succeed on any of the counts in their complaint for dischargeability; (2) purchasers failed to establish nondischargeability on theory of either fraud, defalcation while acting in fiduciary capacity, embezzlement, larceny, or willful and malicious injury; and (3) purchasers were not entitled to punitive damages. Ordered accordingly.

Title: In re Lawler
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Debtor could not be considered alter ego of corporation in which he held 50% interest and which had been formed expressly for purposes of holding title to debtor's land, such that creditor's foreclosure of liens on land held by corporation was subject to automatic stay of debtor's bankruptcy case, where there was no evidence that corporate formalities had been ignored or that any other signposts of abuse or corporate form were present.
Document Preview: Debtor brought complaint seeking to set aside Bankruptcy Court orders lifting automatic stay and to invalidate foreclosure of liens on land held by corporation in which debtor was 50% shareholder.  Creditor moved to dismiss.  The Bankruptcy Court, John C. Ford, J., held that: (1) debtor's complaint seeking to set aside orders lifting automatic stay was barred by laches, and (2) debtor, as mere shareholder, had no interest in land held by corporation sufficient to bring it within scope of automatic stay. Motion granted.

Title: In re Stop & Go of America, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Chapter 11 trustee was entitled to substantive consolidation of debtor corporation and another corporation, where other corporation was a totally inactive shell which was constructed as a deliberate scheme to protect interest of seller of franchise to debtor by insuring its status as sole creditor of legal titleholder of franchise, the shell corporation, in a manner likely to result in fraud to other creditors because of concealment of relationship. Bankr.Code, 11 U.S.C.A. § 1101 et seq.
Document Preview: Chapter 11 trustee filed amended complaint seeking legal title to certain franchise contracts and property rights, and to avoid purported lien asserted by creditor on assets.  In addition, trustee requested substantive consolidation of corporate debtor and another corporation on basis of nonobservance of corporate formalities, lack of legitimate business purpose or joint venture.  The Bankruptcy Court, Harold Lavien, J., held that Chapter 11 trustee was entitled to substantive consolidation of debtor corporation and another corporation, where other corporation was a totally inactive shell which was constructed as a deliberate scheme to protect interest of seller of franchise to debtor by insuring its status as sole creditor of legal titleholder of franchise, the shell corporation, in a manner likely to result in fraud to other creditors because of concealment of relationship. Judgment for trustee on Counts II, III and IV.

Title: Johnson v. Lipton
Court: Supreme Court of Georgia.
Headnote: Precondition to creditor piercing corporate veil and holding individual shareholders liable on corporate claim is insolvency by corporation in that there are insufficient corporate assets to satisfy creditor's claim.
Document Preview: Former division president of corporation brought action against corporation, officers, and shareholders to recover bonuses due.  The Superior Court, Fulton County, Philip F. Etheridge, J., granted motion for partial summary judgment, and former president appealed.  The Supreme Court, Marshall, P.J., held that corporate veil could not be pierced to hold officers and shareholders liable on claim against corporation. Affirmed. Hill, C.J., concurred in judgment only.

Title: In re Telemark Management Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: In light of debtor's sole shareholder's disregard of debtor's corporate structure and his depletion of debtor's assets, it would have been inequitable to limit trustee's recovery to only those corporate assets which shareholder chose to relinquish.
Document Preview: Debtor and his wife appealed from judgments of the Bankruptcy Court for the Western District of Wisconsin, William H. Frawley, J., declaring certain assets to be part of debtors' estate and enjoining plaintiffs from appropriating, interfering, or unfairly competing with a skiing event sponsored by debtor.  43 B.R. 579.  The District Court, Shabaz, J., held that debtor and his wife were equitably estopped from withholding certain lands from debtor. Affirmed and remanded.

Title: In re Pirsig Farms, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota, Fourth Division.
Headnote: No basis existed for treating Chapter 11 debtor, a family farming operation doing business in corporate form, as an individual for purposes of Minnesota filing requirements regarding financing statements covering items of farm equipment; there was no showing that debtor failed to observe corporate formalities or that any member of the family siphoned off corporate funds, nor did the consolidation of bankruptcy proceedings for individual members of the family with those for the corporation support conclusion that the corporation was not so operating at the time creditor filed the liens in question. M.S.A. § 336.9-401(1)(a).
Document Preview: Chapter 11 debtor, a family farm operation doing business in corporate form, sought to avoid liens in various items of farm equipment.  From order of the Bankruptcy Court granting debtor's summary judgment motion, secured party appealed.  The District Court, MacLaughlin, J., held that: (1) no equitable considerations militated in favor of relieving secured creditor from consequences of avoidance of liens in farm equipment on the basis of failure to file financing statement with the Secretary of State, which, under former Minnesota law, was the proper place for filing as to farm equipment of a corporation, and (2) avoidance of the liens did not constitute a taking in violation of the Fifth Amendment, since any property rights in the liens derived from Minnesota state law, pursuant to which the liens were unperfected and were therefore ineffective against bankruptcy trustee. Affirmed. See also, 41 B.R. 835.

Title: In re Tureaud
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Oklahoma.
Headnote: Circumstances warranted disregarding purportedly separate existence of nondebtor corporate entities and granting trustee's application for substantive consolidation of the affiliate corporations of individual debtor within Chapter 11 case, given evidence that, inter alia, individual organized the affiliates and exercised control over them merely as a front to raise money for his own purposes and to hinder and delay judgment creditors, together with relative absence of prejudice to any secured or unsecured creditors. Bankr.Code, 11 U.S.C.A. §§ 105(a), 1101 et seq.
Document Preview: In Chapter 11 case, trustee applied for substantive consolidation of certain affiliate corporations within the case. The Bankruptcy Court, Mickey D. Wilson, J., held that circumstances warranted disregarding purportedly separate existence of nondebtor corporate entities and granting trustee's application for substantive consolidation of the affiliate corporations of individual debtor within the Chapter 11 case, given evidence that, inter alia, individual organized the affiliates and exercised control over them merely as a front to raise money for his own purposes and to hinder and delay judgment creditors, together with relative absence of prejudice to any secured or unsecured creditors. Application granted.

Title: In re Duo Metal & Iron Works, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Bankruptcy Court would not pierce corporate veil of an entity other than the Chapter 11 debtor and subject that entity's president to a creditor's contract claim, where liability was predicated on creditor's assertion that president committed fraud in procuring the contract since he never had any intention of having his corporation pay the charges which would ultimately accrue under that contract, but record bore no support for the charge of fraud other than entity's failure to comply with terms of the contract. Bankr.Code, 11 U.S.C.A. § 1101 et seq.
Document Preview: Chapter 11 debtor sought to recover purchase price and consequential damages from purchaser of debtor's equipment, and purchaser counterclaimed for return of monies paid toward purchase price and sought an exception to discharge for such monies paid.  Purchaser also filed third-party complaint against entity other than debtor and the entity's president for monies due under a separate contract.  The Bankruptcy Court, Emil F. Goldhaber, Chief Judge, held that: (1) debtor was entitled to balance due for the equipment but not to any consequential damages; (2) purchaser was not entitled to an exception from discharge for monies paid toward purchase of the equipment; and (3) purchaser had valid claim against separate entity but Court would not pierce entity's veil to subject entity's president to the claim. Order and recommendation entered.

Title: In re Ozark Restaurant Equipment Co., Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Arkansas, Fayetteville Division.
Headnote: Bankruptcy court, being court of equity, looks beyond mere outward shell to parties in interest beyond fictions of law and corporate forms to purposes and officers who are identified with that purpose.
Document Preview: In three adversary proceedings, the Bankruptcy Court, Charles W. Baker, J., held that: (1) corporation to which equipment having value of $20,208.39 was shipped without ever being paid for was liable to debtor in that amount, and testimony was insufficient to form basis of setoff; (2) payments made by debtor to bank within year of filing of petition in bankruptcy were preferential transfers; (3) because original loan was in default, guarantors were liable to bank for balance due on note; and (4) debtor was so controlled and manipulated by and for benefit of principal and his various subsidiaries that principal, other 50% shareholder, president and business consultant were personally liable for debts of debtor. Title: Norris Chemical Co. v. Ingram
Court: Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division 2.
Headnote: Under trust fund doctrine, corporate entity will be disregarded when dominant shareholder of insolvent corporation prefers himself or other creditors in violation of his duties as trustee of remaining assets.
Document Preview: Action was brought against corporation and individual officers and shareholders for money due and owing on open account for agricultural products.  The Superior Court, Pinal County, Cause No. 33254, James E. Don, J., awarded judgment for plaintiff and against both the corporation and the individual defendants.  Individual defendants appealed, contending that the trial court erred in holding them personally liable for the corporate debt.  The Court of Appeals, Howard, J., held that fact that defendant corporation, adequately capitalized at time of its inception, subsequently suffered financial setbacks making it impossible to make full payment to creditors did not warrant disregarding corporate entity and holding individual shareholders and officers liable for the debt. Reversed and remanded with directions.

Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Missouri, Southern Division.
Headnote: Notwithstanding casual nature in which debtor's businesses were run, corporate and partnership form of such businesses were not shams so as to warrant disregard or legal form of such entities in determining eligibility for Chapter 13. Bankr.Code, 11 U.S.C.A. § 1301 et seq.

The Bankruptcy Court, Joel Pelofsky, J., held that: (1) debtor was eligible to be in Chapter 13; (2) corporate and partnership legal forms of debtor's business interests were not shams; and (3) totality of debtor's conduct did not demonstrate bad faith. Title: In re Harron
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Where debtors used checking accounts of corporation wholly owned by one debtor to pay personal expenses, where debtors' personal and corporate funds were occasionally commingled and where debtors listed the corporate debt on their petition, the corporate debts would be treated as a joint obligation of debtors.

Government's motion for summary judgment granted.

Title: Hillebrand v. Sav-Co
Court: United States District Court, E. D. Illinois.
Headnote: Corporate status of a subsidiary of bankrupt can be disregarded in bankruptcy proceedings if subsidiary is found to be a mere "alter ego" of the bankrupt parent corporation.
Document Preview: Trustee in bankruptcy brought action to set aside and recover certain allegedly voidable transfers and defendants filed motion to dismiss. The District Court, Foreman, J., held that complaint in which it was alleged, inter alia, that wholly owned subsidiaries of bankrupt corporation made payments for antecedent debts to defendants, that each subsidiary was merely the alter ego of bankrupt corporation, that defendants knew, or had reason to know, of relationship between subsidiaries and bankrupt, that transfers had been made within four months of filing of involuntary petition for bankruptcy while bankrupt was insolvent, that defendants had reasonable cause to believe bankrupt was insolvent and that effect of transfers was to give defendants greater percentage of their debts than another creditor of same class was sufficient to state cause of action to set aside and recover the allegedly voidable transfers. Motion to dismiss denied.

Title: In re Beck Industries, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Where debtor had entered into negotiations with stockholders of first corporation for purpose of acquiring stock of that company, in order for the stockholders to secure benefits of a tax free reorganization a second corporation was formed, merger agreement was executed between first and second corporations, pursuant to further agreements second corporation issued all its capital stock to debtor, thereby becoming its wholly owned subsidiary, and there was an exchange of stock of first corporation for stock of debtor, it was not improper for referee to pierce corporate veil in order to enjoin stockholders of first corporation from proceeding with state court action against second corporation, the debtor's subsidiary, to rescind merger agreement. Document Preview: Proceeding to review referee's order enjoining stockholders of first corporation from proceeding with a state court action pending against debtor's wholly owned subsidiary. Affirmed. See also, D.C., 338 F.Supp. 1369.

Title: Harrison v. Puga
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 1, Panel Two.
Headnote: Where, if corporate entity was not disregarded, plaintiffs would be first compelled to obtain judgment against insolvent corporation and then obtain receiver to collect corporate assets taken in defendant's name, and where no innocent third-party rights would be prejudiced by disregarding corporate entity, judgment, based on right of restitution could be awarded directly against defendant for monies paid including those advanced to corporation.
Document Preview: Action for monies advanced or paid. From a judgment of the Superior Court, King County, William J., Wilkins, J., in favor of the plaintiffs, the defendants appealed. The Court of Appeals, Horowitz, Acting, C.J., held that in the absence of a provision in a contract making time of the essence or providing for a forfeiture, where plaintiffs never abandoned their efforts to obtain financing and defendant waived a deadling by accepting payments after the deadline, defendant who had conditionally agreed to gransfer his cable television system to a corporation could not legally forfeit the contract without prior notice giving plaintiffs reasonable opportunity to perform, and the failure to given such notice was a breach of contract. Affirmed.

Title: Noto v. Cia Secula di Armanento
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Where solvency of subsidiaries is unquestioned, where outward indicia of corporate form have been carefully maintained, and where corporate form has not been used to defraud, there is no equitable reason to pierce the corporate veil since to do so would do violence to concept of separate corporate identity and stockholder relationship which the law recognizes for the very purpose of escaping personal liability.
Document Preview: Five actions brought on behalf of next of kin of 28 deceased crew members and by 7 injured survivors of a tanker which exploded in an Iranian port. The District Court, Edward Weinfeld, J., held, inter alia, that in determining liability for deaths and injuries caused by explosion of Italian tanker in Iranian port because of alleged negligence of Dutch corporation which owned terminal and loading facilities, under facts, Iranian, Dutch or Italian law would govern on issue of whether corporate veil might be pierced and Iranian Oil Consortium members held individually liable and, under any such law, claims for alleged tort liability could only be asserted against these corporate entities responsible, and their shareholders, direct or indirect, were exempt from personal liability for those claims, and that under the facts defendants were entitled to dismissal on ground of forum non conveniens. Order in accordance with opinion.

Title: McNellis v. Raymond
Court: United States Court of Appeals Second Circuit.
Headnote: Under New York law, corporate veil could not be pierced in determining whether defendant's loans to corporation, inuring to bankrupt individual's benefit, were usurious, but corporation and individual could be recognized as one for purpose of determining that individual had received benefit of loans and that his personal repayment was not without consideration; defendant could without inconsistency claim that loans were to corporation for purpose of defending usury claim and that loans were to bankrupt individual personally for purpose of defending fraudulent conveyance claim.
Document Preview: Action by bankruptcy trustee to recover alleged fraudulent conveyances and usurious payments. From an order of the United States District Court for the Northern District of New York, William H. Timbers, J., 287 F.Supp. 232, holding that the trustee was entitled to trial on the first cause but that the defendant lender was entitled to judgment of dismissal of the second cause alleged in complaint, the trustee appealed. The Court of Appeals, Feinberg, Circuit Judge, held that New York's six-year statute of limitations for actions based upon fraud or mistake, and not the one-year statute for usury actions, was applicable to the bankruptcy trustee's action against a money lender to set aside payments on loans as fraudulent conveyances under the New York Debtor and Creditor Law. Reversed for further proceedings; affirmed in part. Hays, Circuit Judge, dissented in part. See also D.C., 304 F.Supp. 1172.

The Supreme Court, Underwood, C.J., held that where individual, who was sole owner of insurance company and general agency, illegally withdrew money belonging to insurance company, turn over order and judgment entered against individual was proper, since individual could not take refuge in his corporate structures and profess personal innocence. Order of referee approved and confirmed.

Title: Long v. McGlon
Court: United States District Court D. South Carolina, Columbia Division.
Headnote: Trustee of bankrupt corporation was entitled to bring suit to impose liability on individual defendants who were sole shareholders, officers and directors of corporation for debts of corporation on ground that defendants had at all times treated corporation as if it were a proprietorship or partnership, as trustee represented creditors as well as bankrupt corporation and there was no prejudice to corporate creditors by seeking to hold individual shareholders of nominal but insolvent corporation liable for its debts. Headnote: In plenary suit by trustee in bankruptcy of drilling company seeking to recover value of two diesel engines which had been allegedly supplied by investment company to the bankrupt, drilling company did not have to be deemed to be identical with driller, where driller himself made distinction in course of purchase of engines and in course of obtaining financing, and other parties made the distinction when consent form was executed for installation of the engines.
Document Preview: Plenary suit by trustee in bankruptcy of drilling company, seeking to recover value of two diesel engines which had been allegedly supplied by investment company to the bankrupt. Doyle, J., held that evidence that dealings were between president of investment company and driller personally, that investment company was not even aware of drilling company as such, that contract was signed by driller, and that financing was in name of driller, did not support trustee's contention that bankrupt drilling company was purchaser of the engines. Court: District Court of Appeal, Fifth District, California.
Headnote: Bankruptcy court may look behind corporate veil in weighing effect of agreement by stockholders to purchase from assignee of general creditors preferred stock to be issued under Chapter XI arrangement proceeding. Bankr.Act, § 301 et seq., 11 U.S.C.A. § 701 et seq.

Title: Imperial Paper & Color Corp. v. Sampsell
Court: Circuit Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Though it be assumed that corporation was bankrupt stockholder's alter ego, referee who held proceeds of corporation's property was not authorized in entering order declaring that creditor of corporation had no right to the proceeds of the corporation's property except as a general unsecured creditor of the bankrupt, disregarding the existence of the corporation as a separate legal entity, since, to warrant such disregard of the corporation's separate existence, required a showing, not only that corporation was the bankrupt's alter ego, but that its separate existence would promote fraud, defeat justice, or produce inequitable results.

Title: Thach v. Brown Knitting Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee, Eastern Section.
Headnote: The fact that there was a very close relationship between bankrupt corporation and another corporation and that, for all practical purposes, they were originally owned by the same persons, did not render it impossible to distinguish between them as separate identities so as to make transactions between corporations void as to third parties, or as to rights of bankrupt corporation's trustee in bankruptcy seeking to have alleged preferences and fraudulent conveyances set aside, where corporations were run as separate enterprises, and there was no indication that there was any diversion of assets without full restitution of the value thereof. Code 1932, §§ 7271-7278; Bankr.Act § 70, sub. e, 11 U.S.C.A. § 110, sub. e.

Title: Taszarek v. Lakeview Excavating, Inc.

Title: Integrated Communications & Technologies, Inc. v. Hewlett-Packard Financial Services Company
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: At time that computer company's subsidiary sold used goods to buyer located in China, company's corporate parent did not know to a substantial certainty that its corporate structure, which permitted goods' manufacturer, as parent's other subsidiary, to independently pursue trademark enforcement actions in China as mark holder, would result in imprisonment of buyer's employees in China on charges of selling counterfeit goods, and, thus, corporate structure was insufficient to support buyer's and employees' claim against parent for false imprisonment under Massachusetts law, as predicted by the district court; manufacturer's past actions had not led to imprisonment of other resellers, and any bribe manufacturer paid Chinese authorities was unforeseeable to parent as criminal conduct. Restatement (Second) of Torts § 35.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Company's representation that used transceivers it was selling to buyer were genuine was not false.

Title: Neill v. Cinema de Lux

Headnote: Tort liability cannot be solely predicated upon the fact of a parent corporation's ownership of a controlling interest in the shares of its subsidiary, and consequently, a parent company will not be held liable for the torts of its subsidiary unless it can be shown that the parent exercises complete domination and control over the subsidiary.

Title: Shorter Brothers, Inc. v. Vectus 3, Inc.
