Title: General Fidelity Insurance Company v. WFT, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: To establish a defendant corporation's liability for a tortious transaction of another corporation it controls, a plaintiff is required to prove the following: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) that such control was used by the defendant corporation to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) that aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Insurance company was winding up when it transferred assets to second company, as necessary for transfer of assets to constitute constructive fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Durham v. Accardi
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: While a corporation's capitalization can be a consideration in deciding whether to pierce the corporate veil in a tort case, the corporation's financial strength or weakness is generally only one factor to be considered.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was insufficient that corporation's representatives were corporation's alter ego and thus employee could not pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Meehan v. Mardis
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, First District, Hamilton County.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil is not a claim, it is a remedy encompassed within a claim, whereby liability for a particular tort may be imposed upon a particular individual.
Document Preview: TORTS  Conspiracy. Evidence was insufficient to support construction company co-owner's claim that other co-owner and member of tile company engaged in civil conspiracy.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Gristede's Foods, Inc. v. Madison Capital Holdings LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, while any breach of contract and any tort is, in some sense, an injustice, obviously this type of injustice is not what is contemplated by the common law rule that piercing the corporate veil is appropriate only upon a showing of fraud or something like fraud.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Plaintiff's complaint failed to state cause of action for negligent misrepresentation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: R&M Mixed Beverage Consultants, Inc. v. Safe Harbor Benefits, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, El Paso.
Headnote: Because a parent corporation generally has no duty to control its subsidiaries, courts will not disregard the corporate fiction and hold a parent corporation liable for the torts of its subsidiaries.
Document Preview: INSURANCE  Liability. Insurance entities that helped procure liquor liability insurance were not liable for damages resulting from the insurer's subsequent insolvency.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: In re Batcheler
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida, West Palm Beach Division.
Headnote: Chapter 13 debtors, as mere attorney and non-attorney employees of limited liability company (LLC) providing legal services, were not liable on "alter ego" theory for any alleged misconduct by the LLC in connection with its representation of client, though one of the debtors had signatory authority on the LLC's bank accounts; such signatory authority did not give rise to presumption of ownership interest in LLC, as required under Florida law for imposition of "alter ego" liability, in face of substantial documentary and testamentary evidence to contrary.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Mere employees could not be liable, on alter ego theory, for any willful and malicious conduct.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: In re Gannon
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, it is not necessary in all instances to pierce corporate veil in order to hold corporate officer liable for company's torts; corporate officer is personally liable for tort committed by corporation that employs him, if he personally participated in that tort by, for example, directing, controlling, approving, or ratifying the act that injured the aggrieved party.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Misrepresentations by debtor-contractor were either not shown to be fraudulent or could not be justifiably relied on.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Bates Energy Oil & Gas v. Complete Oilfield Services
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Texas, San Antonio Division.
Headnote: A defendant's liability in his individual capacity for his own tortious conduct is distinct from liability under a veil piercing theory, which is a form of vicarious liability.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Jurisdiction. Purchaser adequately alleged that defendant had sufficient purposeful contacts with Texas, and thus district court had specific personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Padron v. Bentley Marine Group, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil allows a plaintiff to impose legal liability for a corporation's obligations, or for torts committed by the corporation, upon some other individual that controls and dominates a corporation to such an extent that the corporation exists as a mere instrumentality or alter ego of that individual.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY  Defects. Investor in LLC that purchased boat manufacturer lacked the due process minimum contacts needed for personal jurisdiction in boat purchaser's action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Mirage Entertainment, Inc. v. FEG Entretenimientos S.A.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Concert promoters failed to sufficiently allege that corporation owed by recording artist to manage her public performances was an alter ego of artist, or that artist's social media post blaming promoters for cancellation of concerts was made within artist's authority as officer of corporation, as required to state defamation claim against corporation under New York law; promoters did not allege that artist's use of corporation was in any way improper, as would have supported alter ego theory, and there was no indication artist's post involved corporation, since it was posted on artist's personal account, and did not mention corporation or agreements between promoters and corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Concert promoters were not entitled to pierce corporate veil for breach of contract claims directly against recording artist who canceled concerts.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Sam v. Genesis Behavioral Hospital, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Patient who was raped by another patient at hospital and exposed to human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) did not show that two of hospital's corporate officers had been delegated duties by hospital or had assumed a personal or independent duty to patient, as required to pierce the corporate veil and expose officers to liability for patient's alleged injuries; patient did not show that officers knew that patient who raped plaintiff patient was a potential hazard to her, did not show that officers had authority to prevent harm to patient but failed to do so, or that officers undertook the duty to supervise or protect patient, but failed to adequately do so. La. Civ. Code Ann. art. 24; La. Rev. Stat. Ann. § 12:1-622.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Patient who was raped at hospital did not show that corporate officers had assumed a duty to patient, to pierce the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: State ex rel. DeWine v. Osborne Co., Ltd.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eleventh District, Lake County.
Headnote: A corporate officer can be held personally liable for tortious acts he or she has committed and, under such circumstances, a plaintiff need not pierce the corporate veil to hold individuals liable who have personally committed such acts; this has become known as the "personal participation theory."
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW  Clean Water. Water Pollution Control Act prohibition on placing certain materials in location to cause water pollution did not encompass failure to obtain permit.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Dougherty v. Harvey
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Under Georgia defamation law a corporation can be held liable for slander made by an alter ego of the corporation; in such cases, the corporation's president is presumed to be its alter ego, but no such presumption exists in favor of any other official.
Document Preview: TORTS  Defamation. Defamatory character of former employee's statement during speech at industry conference, that former employer may or may not be HIV positive, was apparent on its face.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Dougherty v. Harvey
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, an alter ego theory of corporate liability for an agent in a defamation action does not require that the company authorize or direct the statement.
Document Preview: TORTS  Defamation. Defamatory character of former employee's statement during speech at industry conference, that former employer may or may not be HIV positive, was apparent on its face.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Dougherty v. Harvey
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, a corporation can commit slander under an alter ego theory, but otherwise lacks the capacity to commit slander and, absent evidence that the corporation expressly directed the saying of the slanderous words, a corporation cannot be held liable for the slander.
Document Preview: TORTS  Defamation. Defamatory character of former employee's statement during speech at industry conference, that former employer may or may not be HIV positive, was apparent on its face.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Gecko Outdoor Products Corporation v. Casablanca Construction Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Mississippi.
Headnote: The corporate veil will not be pierced, in either contract or tort claims, except where there is some abuse of the corporate form itself.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Circumstances warranted piercing the corporate veil of successor corporations for subcontractor in order to hold owner individually liable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Gowen v. Helly Nahmad Gallery, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York.
Headnote: Ancillary administrator for estate of original owner of painting that was taken by Nazis during occupation of Paris sufficiently stated claims for conversion and replevin against owner of art dealership, art gallery owner, and art gallery; despite fact that dealership held title to painting, administrator asserted claims under theory of alter ego liability.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Replevin. New York was not inconvenient forum for replevin action seeking return of painting taken by Nazis during occupation of Paris.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Johnson v. New Destiny Christian Center Church, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Orlando Division.
Headnote: Piercing title holding company's corporate veil was not warranted in website operator's malicious prosecution action under Florida law, even though company had no day-to-day operations, employees, assets, bank accounts, or income, and shared a mailing address with a co-defendant corporation, where evidence reflected that company was formed for the legitimate business purpose of holding title to property, operator provided no evidence to controvert this, the proximity of company's formation to other defendants receiving operator's summons did not constitute improper purpose, and the fact that company never operated, never had assets or expenses, nor exchanged in transfers with co-defendant corporation conclusively established that company was neither a sham corporation nor corporation's alter ego.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing title holding company's corporate veil was not warranted in website operator's malicious prosecution action under Florida law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: In re CIL Limited
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, liability of corporate parent for alleged torts of wholly-owned subsidiary can never be predicated solely upon the fact of parent corporation's ownership of controlling interest in shares of its subsidiary; rather, at very least, a plaintiff seeking to hold parent company so accountable must demonstrate direct intervention by parent in management of the subsidiary to such an extent that subsidiary's paraphernalia of incorporation, directors and officers' are completely ignored.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Bankruptcy strong-arm and fraudulent transfer statutes could not be applied extraterritorially.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: G v. Fay School, Inc. by and through its Board of Trustees
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil under Massachusetts law, plaintiffs must show that an officer of a corporation has personal liability for the corporation's tort by virtue of participating in and benefiting from the action in question.
Document Preview: EDUCATION  Disabled Students. Student established a prima facie case of ADA retaliation based on private school's refusal to allow student to participate in after-school athletics.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: In re 91st Street Crane Collapse Litigation
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Evidence that crane lessor, and affiliated corporation, were owned by principal that operated these and other corporations as a single entity was sufficient to support piercing of corporate veils among the corporations, in survivors' wrongful death action against lessor, corporation, and principal, arising out of crane collapse that killed crane operator and worker; while principal asserted that he was merely one person who was shareholder, officer and director in two or more corporations, evidence established that he exercised domination and control over separate corporations which he treated as one entity.
Document Preview: TORTS - Wrongful Death. Award of $7.5 million to crane operator's survivor for preimpact terror felt by operator killed in crane collapse would be reduced to $2.5 million.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: In re 91st Street Crane Collapse Litigation
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Evidence that principal who owned crane lessor, affiliated corporation, and other corporations, personally participated in tortious acts by lessor and corporation that launched instrumentality that killed crane operator and worker in crane collapse, was sufficient to pierce corporate veil and impose personal liability against principal in wrongful death action by survivors of operator and worker.
Document Preview: TORTS - Wrongful Death. Award of $7.5 million to crane operator's survivor for preimpact terror felt by operator killed in crane collapse would be reduced to $2.5 million.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: LaMusga v. Summit Square Rehab, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Second District, Montgomery County.
Headnote: In wrongful death action against owners of security services company, first prong of test for piercing corporate veil, namely, control over corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that corporation had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, was not met, despite fact that corporate funds were commingled with personal funds, where LLC filed articles of incorporation with state, maintained agent for service of process, kept records of its state licensing, employee rosters, contracts, and personnel files, maintained policies of insurance for both liability and workers' compensation, and did not grossly undercapitalize.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Employer's Liability. Security officer training company was not liable for death allegedly caused by actions of guards trained by company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: LaMusga v. Summit Square Rehab, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Second District, Montgomery County.
Headnote: Alleged failure of security services company to discipline security guard employees for incidents involving improper detentions and interactions with individuals, if proven, did not rise to level of illegal act satisfying second prong of test for piercing corporate veil in wrongful death action, namely, control over corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such manner as to commit fraud or illegal act against person seeking to disregard corporate entity.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Employer's Liability. Security officer training company was not liable for death allegedly caused by actions of guards trained by company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: In re Zak
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, piercing the corporate veil is not limited to those circumstances in which there is a confused intermingling of activities of corporate entities, but can be employed to thwart the perpetration of fraudulent or other reprehensible conduct by an alter ego or to hold corporate officers responsible for their personal torts.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debtor's breached duties as partner to account for profits were fiduciary defalcations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Phelan v. Lawhon
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Headnote: Piercing of corporate veil was warranted in civil conspiracy action by life insurance company against multiple defendants stemming from alleged recruitment of insurance sales agents and improper replacement of life insurance policies, where there were unrebutted allegations of intentional misconduct by individual defendants.
Document Preview: TORTS  Jurisdiction. Allegations of civil conspiracy were sufficient to support exercise of personal jurisdiction over non-resident defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Chico Auto Parts & Service, Inc. v. Crockett
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, El Paso.
Headnote: A plaintiff may sue a corporation's affiliate for his torts, including fraud, without the need to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Managing member for operator of well could not be held personally liable as part owner of well in breach of contract action by remediation services provider.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Unterberg v. ExxonMobil Oil Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Where subsidiary is mere instrumentality of parent, or where parent used subsidiary to perpetuate fraud, parent may properly be sued under Jones Act. 46 U.S.C.A. § 30104.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW  Personal Injury. Oil company was not employer subject to liability under Jones Act for injuries allegedly suffered aboard its subsidiary's vessels.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Unterberg v. ExxonMobil Oil Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Oil company's wholly-owned marine shipowning subsidiary had sufficient degree of discretion to be considered independent of company, and thus company was not "employer" subject to liability under Jones Act for injuries allegedly suffered by seaman as result of his exposure to asbestos aboard subsidiary's vessels, even if there was overlap in directors and personnel between company and subsidiary, and they shared office space and legal counsel, where vessels were not documented under United States' flag, and subsidiary had general responsibility for company's international marine transportation system. 46 U.S.C.A. § 30104.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW  Personal Injury. Oil company was not employer subject to liability under Jones Act for injuries allegedly suffered aboard its subsidiary's vessels.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Finerty v. Abex Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of New York.
Headnote: Automobile manufacturer, as parent of foreign subsidiary, could not be held derivatively liable under strict products liability theory in action by mechanic who suffered from type of mesothelioma, alleging that he sustained personal injuries from his exposure to asbestos while replacing asbestos-containing brakes, clutches, and engine parts in Ireland, unless manufacturer disregarded separate identity of subsidiary and involved itself directly in subsidiary's affairs, so as to merit piercing of corporate veil.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Persons Liable. Automobile manufacturer was not party within distribution chain for asbestos-containing components, precluding strict products liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Gourdine v. Karl Storz Endoscopy–America, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Carolina, Charleston Division.
Headnote: Under California law, German medical device manufacturer's subsidiary, which was a California company that marketed and distributed the devices within the United States, was manufacturer's agent under representative services theory, as required for subsidiary's actions to be imputed to manufacturer in patient's products liability action; manufacturer and subsidiary shared the same market branding, manufacturer drafted all marketing, training, and sales materials used by the subsidiary and directed the subsidiary to market its products in all states, manufacturer had similar subsidiaries in other markets around the world and managed those subsidiaries collectively, and services of those subsidiaries were essential to manufacturer's unitary enterprise.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY  Jurisdiction. District court could exercise personal jurisdiction over German medical device manufacturer in products liability action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Minnie Rose LLC v. Yu
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York Law, piercing corporate veil is not required to hold corporate officer liable for his company's torts, and corporate officer who controls corporate conduct and thus is active individual participant in that conduct is liable for corporation's torts.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Jurisdiction. Hong Kong sourcing agent and its principal were subject to specific personal jurisdiction in New York in New York clothing retailer's fraud action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Steiner Elec. Co. v. Maniscalco
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: The doctrine of piercing the corporate veil is an equitable remedy; it is not itself a cause of action but rather is a means of imposing liability on an underlying cause of action, such as a tort or breach of contract.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Costs. Judgment creditor was entitled to attorney fees incurred in piercing corporate veil and collecting judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: In re Tronox Incorporated
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Indirect claims asserted by tort claimants against Chapter 11 debtors' former ultimate parent, under theories of alter ego, veil-piercing, or respondeat superior in connection with wood treatment plant formerly owned and operated by predecessor of debtor-affiliate, were not plausibly pled where, because settlement agreement between debtors, the United States, and parent had extinguished claimants' claims against debtors, claimants could not establish direct liability against debtors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Gillespie Community Unit School Dist. No. 7, Macoupin County v. Union Pacific R. Co.

Title: Gillespie Community Unit School Dist. No. 7, Macoupin County v. Union Pacific R. Co.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Fourth District.

Title: He Nam You v. Japan
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, theory of outside reverse piercing could not be used by Korean citizens to impose liability upon United States subsidiaries of Japanese corporations for damages based on their parents' role in facilitating their abduction by Japanese government during Second World War to serve as sex slaves for benefit of Japanese soldiers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Henderson v. Bank of New York Mellon Corporation
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Trust beneficiary's allegations that parent trustee and its subsidiaries were all directly liable for breach of fiduciary duty by imprudent investment decisions were only sufficient to state class action claim against trustee, but not subsidiaries; beneficiary alleged that parent controlled business activities of subsidiaries, but failed to allege other facts necessary to show that parent was directly liable for trust management decisions or that subsidiaries could be held liable by piercing parent's corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Sugartown Worldwide LLC v. Shanks
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: While puppetry may create tort liability under Pennsylvania law regarding piercing the corporate veil, such control alone does not transform a corporate debt obligation into a personal judgment obligation of individual control persons under an alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Morrissey v. Krystopowicz
Court: Court of Appeals of New Mexico.
Headnote: Causal connection existed between death of a nursing home resident and abuse of the corporate form by sole shareholder of corporation, who also was sole member and managing partner of nursing home, which was a limited liability company (LLC) owned by corporation, and thus veil piercing was appropriate; shareholder intentionally failed to perform a debt-equity analysis for nursing home, to check operations, to determine budgetary needs, or to obtain insurance for the facility, shareholder conveyed all of corporation's assets for no consideration when the enterprise collapsed, and shareholder failed to engage counsel to represent corporation and LLC in litigation initiated by resident's estate.
