Title: Wallop Canyon Ranch, LLC v. Goodwyn
Court: Supreme Court of Wyoming.
Headnote: The corporate veil need not be pierced where a tort action is brought against an officer or director and the elements of the tort are proved.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Partnerships. General partner's business agreements with third parties did not breach duty of care owed to limited partnership.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Phillips v. Carlton Energy Group, LLC
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: Two corporations were subject to alter ego liability, under Nevada law, to investor in a coalbed methane prospect for corporate energy company operator's breach of contract with investor and tortious interference with investor's agreement with owner of the prospect; all three corporations were inseparable from operator and thus, insofar as energy company's operations were concerned, inseparable from each other, and operator's pursuit of his interests in the prospect was to benefit himself and the three corporations.
Document Preview: TORTS  Damages. Requirement of reasonable certainty of proof applies when lost profits are used to determine market value of property for which recovery is sought.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Omega Demolition Corp. v. Hays Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, parents of wholly owned subsidiaries necessarily control direct, and supervise the subsidiaries to some extent, but unless there is a basis for piercing the corporate veil and attributing the subsidiaries' torts to the parent, the parent is not liable for those torts.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Parties. Client's action against insurance broker's parent could not proceed in equity and good conscience among existing parties.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Brown v. Johnson & Johnson
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Parent company of manufacturer of over-the-counter children's anti-inflammatory drug did not use its corporate form to perpetuate wrongdoing, as required to pierce manufacturer's corporate veil to proceed directly against parent company for claims under Pennsylvania's Uniform Trade Practices and Consumer Protection Law by parents of child who allegedly contracted severe skin conditions from use of drug. 73 P.S. § 201–1 et seq.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Defects. Genuine issue of material fact existed as to whether drug could have used a different active ingredient.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Weaver Inv. Co. v. Pressly Development Associates
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: President of property management company, which managed apartment complex owned by partnership, who was also a partner in partnership, was individually liable for the torts committed by management company pursuant to a piercing the corporate veil theory, and thus, he was subject to the same trebling of damages and attorney fees to which company was subject to under unfair and deceptive trade practices statute, even though he was not subject to such damages as a member of partnership. West's N.C.G.S.A. § 75–1.1.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Unfair Practices. Misconduct of property management company fell within scope of statute prohibiting unfair or deceptive trade practices.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: William v. AES Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Alexandria Division.
Headnote: Citizens and residents of Cameroon failed to state a claim against Cameroonian power company's Virginia parent corporation for alter-ego liability in connection with power company's alleged provision of faulty and dangerous electrical supply in Cameroon, where their allegations were wholly consistent with normal incidents of corporate ownership and did not specify how actions taken by power company in Cameroon were imputable to parent corporation, or that parent corporation used power company's corporate form as a vehicle for fraud.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Alien Tort Statute did not give court jurisdiction over customers' claims against Cameroonian power company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Nieto-Vincenty v. Valledor
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Under Puerto Rico law, piercing corporate veil of corporation that was record owner of vessel that sank in order to impose individual liability on director and shareholder of corporation was not warranted, in action by passengers who were aboard vessel when it sank, asserting claims for negligence and maritime tort, even though corporation was extensively controlled by its shareholders, absent evidence that corporation was merely shareholder's alter ego or that recognizing the corporate form would sanction a fraud or promote an injustice. 14 L.P.R.A. § 3501 et seq.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Personal Injury. Vessel passenger's wife was not in zone of danger, as required to establish admiralty claim for NIED.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Manka v. Walt Disney Co.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Trial court did not clearly err in finding that, although family entertainment company and sports network company were linked through intermediary corporations, there was no direct relationship between them as would support a determination that family entertainment company was party to contract between sports network company and media company, in motorist's action against family entertainment company arising from automobile accident allegedly caused by non-party driver, media company's president, in performing her duties under contract, where trial court properly characterized evidence offered by motorist in support of a direct relationship, "a variety of printouts from internet websites that [we]re otherwise unauthenticated" as "unreliable."
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Evidence. Trial court did not clearly err in finding no direct relationship between companies absent reliable evidence of affiliation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Manka v. Walt Disney Co.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Trial court did not clearly err in finding that non-party driver and president of media company was media company's employee and was not employed by family entertainment company, in motorist's action against family entertainment company arising from automobile accident allegedly caused by driver in performing her duties under contract between media company and sports network company, purported affiliate of family entertainment company, where contract stated that media company would make driver available to sports network company to provide commentary and analysis at sports network company's discretion, and trial court found no direct relationship between family entertainment company and sports network company.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Evidence. Trial court did not clearly err in finding no direct relationship between companies absent reliable evidence of affiliation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Country Contractors, Inc. v. A Westside Storage of Indianapolis, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: The mere fact that a corporation commits an unfair labor practice, or breaches a contract, or commits a tort, does not mean that the individual shareholders of the corporation should personally be liable. West's A.I.C. 23–1–26–3(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence did not support finding that contractor corporation was undercapitalized, as would support piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Country Contractors, Inc. v. A Westside Storage of Indianapolis, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Evidence was insufficient to support finding that contractor corporation was undercapitalized, as could support piercing of corporate veil in landowner's action for breach of contract and slander of title action brought against contractor's shareholders, where contractor had run at a profit for many years, and there was no evidence that contractor's dwindling capital was due to anything other than a general downturn in the economy and a specific downturn in the construction industry. West's A.I.C. 23–1–26–3(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence did not support finding that contractor corporation was undercapitalized, as would support piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Country Contractors, Inc. v. A Westside Storage of Indianapolis, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: There was no evidence of any causal link between alleged failure of contractor corporation to respect corporate formalities, through lack of detail in recordkeeping, and injustice alleged by landowner, as would be required to pierce corporate veil in landowner's action against contractor for breach of contract and slander of title based on unfinished project and contractor's filing of mechanic's lien. West's A.I.C. 23–1–26–3(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence did not support finding that contractor corporation was undercapitalized, as would support piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Smith v. Ford Motor Co.
Court: Court of Common Pleas of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia County, First Judicial District, Civil Trial Division.
Headnote: Estate of mechanic's son, who alleged that he developed mesothelioma as a result of inhaling asbestos-containing dust from automotive parts when he visited mechanic's garage and when he came in contact with mechanic's person and clothing at home, did not demonstrate an abuse of the corporate form so as to pierce corporate veil of clutch manufacturer, whose wholly owned subsidiary supplied brakes and clutches that mechanic used in England; subsidiary was fully funded and viable company which maintained separate and independent books, records, financial statements, and bank accounts, and estate did not demonstrate the level of domination and control necessary to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Mechanic's son's estate did not demonstrate abuse of corporate form so as to pierce corporate veil of clutch manufacturer, whose wholly owned subsidiary supplied clutches that mechanic used.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: National Gear & Piston, Inc. v. Cummins Power Systems, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, that engine parts distributor was created as a joint venture between an engine parts manufacturer and one of the manufacturer's former executives, that the distributor was described as a "unit" of the manufacturer in a press release and on the manufacturer's website, that most of the capital contribution for the creation of the distributor came from the manufacturer, and that there was an overlap in corporate officers did not indicate that the manufacturer and distributor were a single economic entity, as required to pierce the corporate veil and find manufacturer liable for distributor's alleged tortious interference with the prospective business relationship of an authorized engine parts dealer.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Engine parts manufacturer was not the same economic entity as its corporate affiliate, a parts distributor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Abbott v. Crown Mill Restoration Development, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: Worker stated a claim to pierce property owner's corporate veil so as to hold its chief executive officer (CEO) personally liable for default judgment entered against owner in worker's action to recover damages for injuries he allegedly sustained when he fell from a ladder while working on owner's property, where worker alleged that CEO was sole owner of property owner, he failed to adhere to corporate formalities, keep adequate records concerning governance and financial accounting, and retain sufficient earnings from corporate operations to meet financial obligations before distributing those earnings to himself, that he completely dominated and intentionally undercapitalized owner, and that he conducted business of owner in disregard of its formalities in a manner that suited his own personal convenience.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Judgment. Absent a reasonable excuse for the default, vacating default judgment was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Kinn v. HCR ManorCare
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Sixth District, Lucas County.
Headnote: Estate of patient, who died from esophageal cancer, did not show that hospice provider was operated as a mere instrumentality of its parent corporation so as to hold parent corporation liable for provider's alleged torts; administrator at provider stated that parent corporation was a separate legal entity from provider and had no involvement in patient's care, and there was no indication that provider was controlled by parent corporation to the extent that it had no separate existence of its own.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Experts. Court's determination that expert's testimony was unreliable and, thus, inadmissible did not constitute an abuse of discretion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Kinn v. HCR ManorCare
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Sixth District, Lucas County.
Headnote: In order to hold a corporation liable for the torts of its subsidiary, it must appear that the subsidiary was operated as a mere instrumentality of the parent corporation, and this rule is rarely applied, and only under special circumstances, for it runs contrary to the principal of corporate limited liability.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Experts. Court's determination that expert's testimony was unreliable and, thus, inadmissible did not constitute an abuse of discretion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Alkanani v. Aegis Defense Services, LLC
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: English military contractor and its American subsidiary did not have unity of ownership and interest, and thus, it was inappropriate to pierce corporate veil to hold subsidiary liable for injuries caused when American soldier was shot by contractor's employee at security checkpoint in Iraq; although two members of contractor's board of directors were members of subsidiary's board of directors, contractor and subsidiary did not commingle assets and funds, they did not share offices or business locations, they maintained separate payrolls, subsidiary managed its own day-to-day business affairs free from contractor's control and influence, and contractor's majority stock interest in subsidiary did not create identity of interest.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Subsidiary of military contractor could not be held liable for injuries caused, prior to its corporate existence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Alkanani v. Aegis Defense Services, LLC
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, the absence of any facts or evidence that American subsidiary's corporate form was used by its English parent corporation, a military contractor, to perpetuate fraud precluded piercing of corporate veil to hold parent corporation liable for injuries caused when American soldier was shot by contractor's employee at security checkpoint in Iraq.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Subsidiary of military contractor could not be held liable for injuries caused, prior to its corporate existence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Janki Bai Sahu v. Union Carbide Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Under New York law, parent company was not liable for the negligence of or nuisance created by its subsidiary under a theory of piercing of the corporate veil, in residents and property owners' nuisance action against parent company for soil and water contamination at a factory owned and operated by subsidiary, where parent company did not exercise complete domination over subsidiary with respect to the transaction at issue and did not use such domination to commit a fraud or wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Parent company's involvement with subsidiary, a pesticide manufacturer, was not sufficiently direct for direct nuisance liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Mulch Mfg., Inc. v. Advanced Polymer Solutions, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, a corporate officer can be held personally liable for tortious acts he or she has committed and, under such circumstances, a plaintiff need not pierce the corporate veil to hold individuals liable who have personally committed such acts.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Issues of fact precluded summary judgment on manufacturer's fraud claim against developer of fire retardant under Ohio law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: JMB Mfg., Inc. v. Child Craft, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Indiana, New Albany Division.
Headnote: Under Indiana law, in order to pierce the corporate veil and hold a corporation's officers liable for tort, the moving party must show a causal connection between misuse of the corporate form and the harm suffered by the movant.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. A fact issue existed as to whether a manufacturer waived its contractual remedies under the perfect tender rule.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: JMB Mfg., Inc. v. Child Craft, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Indiana, New Albany Division.
Headnote: Children's furniture manufacturer did not transfer wood sub-assembly supplier's wood products to manufacturer's parent corporation in a way that breached corporate formalities, as required under Indiana law for the court to pierce the corporate veil in supplier's conversion action against the parent corporation and its principals.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. A fact issue existed as to whether a manufacturer waived its contractual remedies under the perfect tender rule.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Ramos v. 24 Cincinatus Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: While corporate officer may not be held liable for corporation's wrongs simply because of her status as corporate officer, corporate officer who participates in commission of tort may be held individually liable, regardless of whether corporate veil is pierced.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Officers and Directors. Fact issues precluded summary judgment on personal injury claims against corporate officer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Doe 1631 v. Quest Diagnostics, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Missouri, En Banc.
Headnote: There was no evidence that parent laboratory corporation had complete domination over subsidiary laboratory corporation, as would support piercing corporate veil to hold parent corporation liable for alleged tort by subsidiary corporation in disclosing, contrary to statute, patient's human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) test results. V.A.M.S. § 191.656.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Medical Records. Patient's action against laboratory for wrongful disclosure of HIV test results did not require affidavit of merit.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Friend v. Remac America, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. West Virginia, Martinsburg.
Headnote: Under West Virginia law, Maryland employer did not have a lack of corporate formalities justifying piercing the corporate veil in a tort case, even though the employer's owner was the sole owner, officer, and shareholder of the employer, and the employer did not have a board of directors or board or directors or shareholder meetings, as those practices and decisions were legally permitted under a close corporation under Maryland and West Virginia law. West's Ann.Md.Code, Corporations and Associations, §§ 4–101, 4–102.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Employer did not have a lack of corporate formalities justifying piercing the corporate veil in a tort case.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Friend v. Remac America, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. West Virginia, Martinsburg.
Headnote: Under West Virginia law, allegations that Maryland employer was undercapitalized because it may not have carried proper insurance coverage to protect employees injured on the job in West Virginia, and may not have had any insurance policies in place which covered deliberate intent causes of action, or negligence causes of action, filed by employees who were injured on the job in the State of West Virginia, were insufficient to establish the employer was undercapitalized so as to justify piercing the corporate veil in a tort case, absent any allegations that employer was inadequately capitalized for the reasonable risks of its corporate undertaking.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Employer did not have a lack of corporate formalities justifying piercing the corporate veil in a tort case.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Gieseke ex rel. Diversified Water Diversion, Inc. v. IDCA, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: Trial court did not abuse its discretion by finding veil-piercing factors favored piercing purchaser's corporate veil and holding purchaser's shareholder and purchaser's promoters personally liable, in tortious interference with prospective advantage that corporation brought against purchaser of void judgment against one of corporation's shareholders that purchaser used in an attempt to shut corporation down; purchaser was formed by a brother one of corporation's shareholders who was involved in a protracted feud with the shareholder, and brother's wife, for the express purpose of purchasing the judgment and shutting corporation down, and brother's wife, who was the sole shareholder, was not certain of her total capital contribution, whether there had been any source of revenue or financing since corporation was formed, or who made purchaser's bank deposits and withdrawals.
Document Preview: TORTS - Tortious Interference. A claim of tortious interference with prospective advantage is a valid tort claim under Minnesota law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: In re Kalinowski
Court: United States Bankruptcy Appellate Panel of the Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Personal liability of corporate officers for their own tortious acts, even when performed on behalf of corporation, does not depend on the same grounds as "piercing the corporate veil"; true basis of liability is officer's violation of some duty owed to third person that injures such third person.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor stood in fiduciary capacity based on status as de facto manager of licensed general contractor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Georgia Cash America, Inc. v. Greene
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: A corporate officer who takes part in the commission of a tort by the corporation is personally liable therefor, but an officer of a corporation who takes no part in the commission of a tort committed by the corporation is not personally liable unless he specifically directed the particular act to be done or participated or cooperated therein or if he disregarded the corporate form so as to authorize piercing of the corporate veil.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Usury. Triable issue existed as to whether payday lender that contracted with bank was the de facto lender of usurious payday loans.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Moore v. Johnson & Johnson
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Pennsylvania courts recognize executive tort liability under traditional veil-piercing theory.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Parties. Corporate executives were fraudulently joined in consumers' products liability action involving allegedly defective drug.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Lobegeiger v. Celebrity Cruises, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Under Florida law, cruise line was not so dominated and controlled by its parent that piercing of corporate veil was warranted to hold parent vicariously liable for cruise line's alleged actions in passenger's action against cruise line and parent arising out of injuries passenger allegedly sustained aboard cruise ship.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Cruise line was not so controlled by its parent that piercing of corporate veil was warranted to hold parent vicariously liable for cruise line's actions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Bigio v. Coca-Cola Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Assertions that American corporations invested in Egyptian bottling company, did business with bottling company, and advised bottling company in some unspecified manner on the subject of profitability did not suggest that American corporations had the power to control bottling company's conduct so as to be subject to agency liability under either New York and Georgia law for bottling company's trespass or conversion.
Document Preview: TORTS - Conversion. Complaint failed to state a claim for aiding and abetting Egyptian bottling company's trespass or conversion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Synthes, Inc. v. Marotta
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, where the corporate officer has personally or actively committed intentional torts, it is unnecessary to pierce the corporate veil to hold the officer liable.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Pleading. Plaintiff did not engage in undue delay or dilatory tactics in filing motion to amend complaint.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Tucker v. Thomas
Court: United States District Court, N.D. West Virginia.
Headnote: Allegations that multiple companies had overlap in ownership and management, shared common office space, had some of the same telephone numbers, and had limited purposes were insufficient to support piercing of the corporate veil, under West Virginia law, in action for slander of title, tortious interference, legal malpractice, invasion of privacy, fraud, and other claims.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Process. Leaving copy of summons and complaint on defendant's mother's chair in defendant's place of business was not effective service.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Cameron v. Olin Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut and Texas law, gun manufacturer's subsidiary was not subject to liability for death resulting from defectively-designed rifle, even though there was evidence that corporation with subsidiary's name designed rifle in 1894, where subsidiary was incorporated in 1938, existed only to prevent another company from incorporating using that same name, and never conducted any business or manufactured or sold any products. C.G.S.A. § 52–572m(b); V.T.C.A., Civil Practice & Remedies Code § 82.001.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Limitations. Texas statute of repose did not apply in products liability action against gun manufacturer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: McCloud v. Bettcher Industries, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: Plaintiff who had allegedly been injured while operating breader machine failed to present sufficient evidence to pierce the corporate veil, so as to support imposition of liability on shareholder who, 21 years earlier, had purchased all of the common stock of manufacturer of breader machine; there was no evidence that shareholder was not acting within its capacity or that it had exercised complete domination or control over manufacturer.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. There was no evidence of control or dominion as required to support piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Informatics Applications Group, Inc. v. Shkolnikov
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Alexandria Division.
Headnote: Under Virginia law, employer failed to show that its former employee's company was the alter ego of employee, and that employee used the company as a device to disguise his alleged wrongs in attempting to claim employer's technology as his own in various patents and patent applications, as would support employer's alter ego claim against company.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Parties. Employer had standing to bring claim to correct inventors named in its former employee's patent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Roberts v. RMB Ents., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Twelfth District, Butler County.
Headnote: A corporate officer can be held personally liable for tortious acts he or she has committed and, under such circumstances, a plaintiff need not pierce the corporate veil to hold individuals liable who have personally committed such acts.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Employer's sister corporation was entitled to workers' compensation immunity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Cohen v. Roll-A-Cover, LLC
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Imposition of individual tort liability on a corporate officer does not require the piercing of the corporate veil when there is ample evidence in the record that a defendant has personally committed a tort.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST - Supply and Distribution. Swimming pool cover manufacturer violated Connecticut Business Opportunity Investment Act in negotiating distributorship agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: James v. Loran Realty V Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Plaintiffs failed to show that actions of corporation's president were for purpose of leaving corporation judgment proof, or that president's actions amounted to a wrong against plaintiffs, and thus corporate veil of corporation that owned building would not be pierced to hold president personally liable for injuries sustained by infant as result of exposure to lead-based paint in building, even though corporation was now judgment proof shell, since corporation was not judgment proof at time president turned over control of corporation, and president had no financial interest in, or involvement in management or control of, corporation at time it became judgment proof.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Actions of corporation's president were not for purpose of leaving corporation judgment proof, and thus piercing of corporate veil was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Verizon New York, Inc. v. Labarge Bros. Co., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: Owner of underground cable failed to establish that new defendant used its alleged dominion and control over original defendant to commit fraud or wrong against owner, as required to pierce defendants' corporate veils and find that they were united in interest, as required for owner to assert claim against new defendant for damage to cables after the expiration of limitations period under the relation back doctrine.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Limitations. New defendant did not share unity of interest with original defendant, as required for application of relation back doctrine.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Broxmeyer v. United Capital Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: A parent company will not be held liable for the torts of its subsidiary unless it can be shown that the parent exercises complete dominion and control over the subsidiary.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Nuisance. Fact issues precluded summary judgment on adjacent property owners' private nuisance and negligence claims against commercial building owner.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Ottens v. McNeil
Court: Court of Appeals of Utah.
Headnote: Plaintiff in negligence action, whose car was rear-ended when she stopped on interstate to avoid hitting chair that had fallen off pickup truck driven by defendant's son, failed to establish as basis for respondeat superior liability that son's corporate employer was merely defendant's alter ego; while plaintiff contended that defendant used corporation to move his personal property, thereby promoting injustice, there was no injustice to plaintiff, as corporation was listed in accident report as owner of truck, defendant's son identified corporation as his employer in his deposition years before trial, and plaintiff was not prevented during discovery from investigating corporation's role.
Document Preview: TRANSPORTATION - Motor Vehicles. One who undertakes to secure a load on a vehicle has a duty not to do so negligently.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Asay v. Kolberg-Pioneer
Court: United States District Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: A stacking conveyor manufacturer's parent company was not liable for a quarry worker's products liability claim. The worker failed to present sufficient evidence to pierce the corporate veil between the manufacturer and the parent company. The worker failed to provide evidence suggesting that the parent company sold or manufactured the stacking conveyor, that the company misused its position as a shareholder to accomplish any wrongful purposes, that company influenced or governed the manufacturer, or that the parent company and the manufacturer were inseparable from each other.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Persons Liable. A stacking conveyor manufacturer's parent company was not liable for a quarry worker's products liability claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Archer v. Mead Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Alabama law, correspondence of subsidiary corporations among one another and with other parties did not show that parent corporation assumed a duty of safety at the facility of its subsidiary that manufactured products containing asbestos, and thus subsidiary was not an adjunct, instrumentality, or alter ego of parent for parent to be liable to employee of the asbestos subsidiary for injuries sustained as a result of employee's exposure to asbestos under a piercing theory. The correspondence mainly largely of inquiries into the safety procedures and conditions at the recipient's facilities, the responses thereto, and advisories of federal laws going into effect.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Occupational Safety. Correspondence of subsidiary corporations did not show that parent corporation assumed a duty of safety at the facility of its subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Kriegel v. Bank of America, N.A.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Banking corporation could not be held directly liable for alleged fraud, negligence, unjust enrichment, negligent misrepresentation, and violations of Washington's Consumer Protection Act (WCPA) that purportedly arose from automatic renewal of certificate of deposit (CD) by corporation's subsidiary. While corporation and subsidiary clearly had similar names, the deposit agreement governing the CD specifically defined the name of the bank as referring to the subsidiary. Customer's relationship was solely with the subsidiary. West's RCWA 19.86.020.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Banking corporation could not be held directly liable regarding automatic renewal of certificate of deposit by subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Taylor v. Ron's Liquors, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Familial connection between liquor store owner, manager, and vice-president to the assailant was insufficient to state a basis for piercing the corporate veil. The victim was lured by the assailant into the upstairs area of the liquor store, and then he physically and sexually abused her. Victim sought to hold each defendant individually liable for the assailant's actions because they knew he was a registered sex offender, and they failed to adequately supervise him. However, the victim failed to demonstrate a unity of interest between the owner, manager, vice president and the company that would warrant holding them responsible for assailant's actions under the theory of vicarious liability.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Familial connection between liquor store owner, manager and vice-president and the assailant was insufficient to state a basis for piercing the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Wordtech Systems, Inc v. Integrated Networks Solutions, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Federal Circuit.
Headnote: In general, a corporate officer is personally liable under Nevada law for his tortious acts, just as any individual may be liable for a civil wrong; however, "corporate veil" shields a company's officers from personal liability for direct patent infringement that the officers commit in the name of the corporation, unless the corporation is the officers' alter ego.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Officers and Directors. Officers could not be personally liable for direct patent infringement, absent piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Rivera v. Club Caravan, Inc.
Court: Appeals Court of Massachusetts, Suffolk.
Headnote: Corporate veil of corporation that owned bar could not be pierced, so as to impose liability on realty trust that owned real estate on which bar was located, in dram shop action by motorist and police officer who were involved in traffic accident with bar patron, since trust was not created, and thus trust's relationship with corporation did not commence, until after occurrence of the accident.
Document Preview: TORTS - Dram Shop. Realty trust that purchase real estate on which bar was located was not liable in dram shop action for accident occurring prior to sale.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Antonio v. Security Services of America, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland, Southern Division.
Headnote: Even though parent corporation controlled subsidiary security company, corporate veil would not be pierced, under Maryland law to hold parent liable for actions of subsidiary's security guard employees who, while guarding housing development after-hours, carried out racially motivated arson;; although parent owned 100 percent of security guard company, security guard company did not hold annual board meetings, keep corporate minutes, or conduct its own auditing, and all but one of parent corporation's officers were also officers of security guard company, Maryland courts had explicitly rejected application of "control or instrumentality" exception to corporate veil doctrine, absent fraud or paramount inequity.
Document Preview: CIVIL RIGHTS - Contracts. Federal Fair Housing Act (FHA) applied to racially-motivated arsonists' actions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Department of Agriculture v. Appletree Marketing, L.L.C.
Court: Supreme Court of Michigan.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil is not necessary to a determination of personal liability for intentional torts: regardless of the corporate form, officers remain personally liable for their intentional and criminal conduct.
Document Preview: AGRICULTURE - Farming. Department of Agriculture's Apple Committee could pursue conversion claims against distributor and its principal.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Grice Engineering, Inc. v. JG Innovations, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: Corporate officers can be held personally liable for infringement or other tortious acts of their corporation if there is reason to disregard the corporate form, such as evidence that the corporation was merely the alter ego of its officers.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST - Deceptive Trade Practices. Manufacturer failed to allege that it was induced to act by competitor, as required to state claim for deceptive trade practices.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Williams v. Lovell Safety Management Co., LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Plaintiff who was allegedly injured in safety demonstration by company's employee could not pierce corporate veil to reach company's alleged corporate alter ego, absent evidence of domination or fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Injured plaintiff could not pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Archie v. Ma's & Papa Joe's, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: President of a corporate tenant operating a bar at which a patron was allegedly assaulted by another patron was not liable for the wrongs of the tenant under the doctrine of piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. President of corporate tenant operating bar was not liable a patron's injuries under doctrine of piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: City of Newburgh v. Sarna
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, piercing the corporate veil is not required to hold a corporate officer liable for his company's torts.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - Clean Water. Preliminary injunction was not warranted in Clean Water Act citizen suit.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Hand v. City of New York
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: There was no evidence that corporate commercial property owner dominated nonparty corporations that owned and used parking lot or that either corporation was alter ego of owner, as required for pedestrian to recover damages from owner for injuries allegedly sustained from tripping and falling in front of commercial property on sidewalk that owner did not make special use of as driveway leading into parking lot.
Document Preview: TORTS - Premises Liability. Commercial property owner did not make special use of sidewalk on which pedestrian sustained injuries by tripping and falling.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: North American Clearing, Inc. v. Brokerage Computer Systems, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Orlando Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, causing a corporation to intentionally breach a contract or commit conversion, without more, does not mislead or defraud creditors such that the corporate veil should be pierced; however, creditors are defrauded incident to a breach of contract or act of conversion where the breaching alter ego transfers funds out of the corporation such that the corporation's creditors cannot collect on their claims.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Shareholder's alleged conduct in causing licensee to decompile software did not entitle licensor to piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Marlyn Nutraceuticals, Inc. v. Improvita Health Products
Court: United States District Court, D. Arizona.
Headnote: When assertion of corporate officer or board member's personal liability for acts of corporation is based on an allegation of tortious conduct, corporate veil need not be pierced under Arizona law.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Arizona court had specific jurisdiction over Ohio buyer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: In re SMTC Mfg. of Texas
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Texas, Austin Division.
Headnote: Texas courts are less reluctant to disregard the integrity of related corporations in tort cases, as opposed to contract cases.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Even obligation on absolute and unconditional guarantee may be discounted for fraudulent transfer avoidance purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: In re SMTC Mfg. of Texas
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Texas, Austin Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, while attitude toward judicial piercing of corporate veil is more flexible in tort, legal precepts governing both tort and contract suits are substantially the same.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Even obligation on absolute and unconditional guarantee may be discounted for fraudulent transfer avoidance purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Wilson v. Davis
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (1st Dist.).
Headnote: Statute limiting the use of alter ego and like theories when a claimant seeks to hold a shareholder liable for a corporate obligation does not apply when claimant seeks to hold a corporation liable for its shareholder's tortious action under a reverse-piercing theory. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Fact issue barred summary judgment for closely held corporation on alter ego theory of liability for fatal accident.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: L.D.G., Inc. v. Brown
Court: Supreme Court of Alaska.
Headnote: Whether sole shareholder in subchapter S corporation that owned bar could be held personally liable in action under dram shop statute arising from a fatal shooting by bar patron after he left bar would be determined under standards for piercing the corporate veil, rather than under a theory that corporation and shareholder were engaged in a partnership; proceeding under the latter theory would do violence to concept that a sole shareholder normally has only very limited liability for the debts of the corporation. AS 04.16.030, 04.21.020.
Document Preview: TORTS - Dram Shop. Evidence regarding intoxicated bar patron's role in decedent's death was inadmissible at trial on damages in dram shop action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Smith v. Simmons
Court: United States District Court, E.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, corporation's shareholders are not normally liable for its torts, but personal liability may attach to them through application of alter ego doctrine, or when shareholder specifically directed or authorized wrongful acts.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Guaranty. Buyer corporation's vice president did not personally guarantee its obligations under asset purchase agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: In re South African Apartheid Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Allegations in complaint brought under Alien Tort Claims Act (ATCA) on behalf of individuals who suffered damages as result of crimes of apartheid in South Africa, that automobile manufacturer simply maintained its business through subsidiary so that it could continue to benefit from participation in crimes of apartheid regime, were insufficient to permit tort claims against automobile manufacturer for actions of subsidiary on veil-piercing theory. 28 U.S.C.A. § 1350.
Document Preview: INTERNATIONAL LAW - Pleading. Allegations were sufficient to sustain claims for aiding and abetting apartheid against automotive manufacturers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: In re South African Apartheid Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Allegations in complaint brought under Alien Tort Claims Act (ATCA) on behalf of individuals who suffered damages as result of crimes of apartheid in South Africa, that automobile manufacturer used its foreign subsidiary to build trucks and other vehicles that it sold to South African security forces, were insufficient to permit tort claims against automobile manufacturer for actions of subsidiary on veil-piercing theory, where alleged relationship did not differ from ordinary relationship between parent and local sales and manufacturing subsidiary. 28 U.S.C.A. § 1350.
Document Preview: INTERNATIONAL LAW - Pleading. Allegations were sufficient to sustain claims for aiding and abetting apartheid against automotive manufacturers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: In re South African Apartheid Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Allegations in complaint brought under Alien Tort Claims Act (ATCA) on behalf of individuals who suffered damages as result of crimes of apartheid in South Africa were sufficient to support liability against automobile manufacturer for actions of agent under agency theory; complaint alleged that manufacturer carried out activities in South Africa through separately incorporated subsidiary, that senior management in subsidiary included American personnel, who had been sent from manufacturer, that although manufacturer purportedly sold subsidiary to South African investors headed by local management, manufacturer allegedly sent senior manager from Detroit to South Africa to run new company, and that manufacturer allegedly executed buy-back provision in original sale agreement and allegedly once again owned subsidiary. 28 U.S.C.A. § 1350.
Document Preview: INTERNATIONAL LAW - Pleading. Allegations were sufficient to sustain claims for aiding and abetting apartheid against automotive manufacturers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: In re South African Apartheid Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Allegations in complaint brought under Alien Tort Claims Act (ATCA) on behalf of individuals who suffered damages as result of crimes of apartheid in South Africa were sufficient to support liability against technology manufacturer for actions of agent under agency theory; manufacturer allegedly carried out activities through subsidiary, supplied products, parts, and expertise to subsidiary, which then merely distributed goods to South African customers, manufacturer engaged in campaign to deliver products to South Africa in circumvention of export controls implicitly involving U.S. management, after manufacturer sold its subsidiary to group of local employees, subsidiary allegedly continued to serve as mere conduit for manufacturer's products and parts, and manufacturer allegedly executed buy-back provision in divestment agreement in order to regain ownership of subsidiary. 28 U.S.C.A. § 1350.
Document Preview: INTERNATIONAL LAW - Pleading. Allegations were sufficient to sustain claims for aiding and abetting apartheid against automotive manufacturers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Lieberman v. Mossbrook
Court: Supreme Court of Wyoming.
Headnote: Shareholders of successor corporation to former limited liability company (LLC) were not individually liable to former member of LLC for damages awarded to former member on his conversion claim against them, as there was nothing in the record to support a determination that the identity of the corporation should have been disregarded and the shareholders held individually liable.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. LLC's failure to make liquidating distributions to its former member, as required by LLC's operating agreement, constituted conversion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Jones ex rel. Jones v. Enterprise Leasing Company-Southeast
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: Car rental agency was not alter ego of its parent corporation, as required to pierce corporate veil in action brought by motorist injured when driver who leased vehicle from agency struck motorist's vehicle; parent exhibited no day-to-day control over agency, both parent and agency held separate meetings, agency paid its own employees from its own banking accounts, agency was self-insured, there was no evidence of undercapitalization or fraud in agency corporate operations or structure or that agency was not financially viable on its own.
Document Preview: TORTS - Negligent Entrustment. Car rental agency's parent corporation was not liable to injured motorist on theory of negligent entrustment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Hamlet at Willow Creek Development Co., LLC v. Northeast Land Development Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Principals of excavator and asphalt company did not misuse corporate form for personal ends or otherwise abuse privilege of doing business in corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice in removing excess fill material from development site, and thus developer could not pierce corporate veil so as to reach principals' personal assets in action for conversion and unjust enrichment.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Subrogation. Developer was entitled to recover funds it paid to town for environmental fees as equitable subrogee under payment bonds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Minno v. Pro-Fab, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Ohio.
Headnote: Employee of steel erection company that acted as subcontractor on project could not pierce the corporate veil of subcontractor to hold subcontractor's sister company, which acted as steel erection contractor on project, liable for unsafe work conditions; although the subcontractor and contractor had common individual shareholders and officers, engaged in similar lines of work, and had identical business addresses, the corporations were separately incorporated and neither corporation had an ownership interest in the other.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Employee of subcontractor could not pierce corporate veil to hold sister company liable for unsafe work conditions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Lawlor v. Hoffman
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Alleged victim of an assault by a bar patron failed to present sufficient evidence to pierce the corporate veil, so as to support imposition of liability on the shareholders and officers of the corporation that owned the bar; there was no evidence that they were not acting within their corporate capacity or that they exercised complete domination or control over the corporate affairs that required further inquiry.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence did not warrant piercing the corporate veil in personal injury suit against bar owner's shareholders.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Guinan v. A.I. duPont Hosp. for Children
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Stent manufacturer's president and sole owner did not exercise complete domination of corporation with respect to stent implanted in minor child's heart, as required under New York law to pierce corporate veil in minor child's action against president alleging negligence, fraud and intentional misrepresentation, assault and battery, strict products liability, breach of warranties, and medical monitoring.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Warranties. Minor child who received heart stent did not have breach of implied warranty claim against stent manufacturer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Wooley v. Lucksinger
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, only tort duty that shareholder of health maintenance organization (HMO) had according to statute governing liability of shareholders for corporation's obligations was a duty not to commit actual fraud.
Document Preview: HEALTH - HMOs. Seller and buyer of health maintenance organization did not operate as single business enterprise prior to or after sale.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Nassau County v. Richard Dattner Architect, P.C.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: A parent company will not be held liable for the torts of its subsidiary unless it can be shown that the parent exercises complete domination and control over the subsidiary.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was not warranted to hold parent liable for subsidiary's breach of contract

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Doe v. Exxon Mobil Corp.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Indonesian villagers' allegations were insufficient to establish corporate liability on the part of American affiliates of oil corporation for alleged tortious acts of Indonesian military security force that corporation's Indonesian subsidiary hired to protect oil field, where evidence regarding corporate control over subsidiary referred to corporation's control as the ultimate parent, and not any control by the affiliates, evidence related to piercing subsidiary's corporate veil were aimed upward to corporation, and not to affiliates, affiliates were not merely alter-egos of subsidiary, and affiliates did not take direct action that would have made them liable as aiders and abettors.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Foreign subsidiary and security force had master-servant relationship, supporting respondeat superior finding against parent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Richard A. Pulaski Const. Co., Inc. v. Air Frame Hangars, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of New Jersey.
Headnote: Existence of doctrine allowing a plaintiff to pierce a corporate veil barred construction company's resort to prima facie tort claim against officer and shareholder of insolvent corporation to recover balance due on construction contract.
Document Preview: TORTS - Prima Facie Tort. Availability of contract claim against developer barred separate claim for prima facie tort against officer of developer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Shaw v. Yellin
Court: Massachusetts Appellate Division, District Court Department, Southern District.
Headnote: Homeowners who hired home repair company to perform work on their home adequately stated claims against company's shareholders directly based on shareholders' tortious conduct in their individual capacities as officers of the company; complaint alleged that shareholders used false names, used a false contractor license number, held themselves out to be partners, provided inferior materials, failed to perform contracted-for services, and shut down the company's offices in an effort to defraud customers with claims against it.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Homeowners adequately stated claims against shareholders of home repair company based on shareholders' tortious conduct.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Pazur v. Belcher
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Personal participation by shareholders in a tort committed by a corporation is irrelevant to an attempt to pierce the corporate veil and hold the shareholders personally liable for the corporation's tort.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence of owner's personal involvement in corporation's tort did not support effort to pierce corporate veil.

Title: Pazur v. Belcher
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Evidence that corporation's former owner was personally involved in making deductions from salesman's commission accounts, which activity was adjudged to be conversion by the corporation in a separate action by salesman against the corporation, did not support salesman's efforts to pierce the corporate veil and hold owner personally liable for corporation's conversion; owner's personal involvement might support a conversion claim directly against her, but was irrelevant to showing that she disregarded the corporate entity and made corporation her alter ego, as necessary to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence of owner's personal involvement in corporation's tort did not support effort to pierce corporate veil.

Title: Pazur v. Belcher
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Holding a corporate officer or owner personally liable for her own tortious conduct is a distinct and separate claim from piercing the corporate veil; it is only where the evidence is insufficient to pierce the corporate veil that the liability of the corporate officers for a tort committed by the corporation is dependent upon the separate evidence of direct participation in the tort.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence of owner's personal involvement in corporation's tort did not support effort to pierce corporate veil.

Title: Eichstadt v. Frisch's Restaurants, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Tortious intent will be imputed to employer that is a legal entity or artificial person where either (1) the corporation is the tortfeasor's alter ego or (2) the corporation has substituted its will for that of the individual who committed the tortious acts.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Employee failed to establish that her injuries were not by accident, and therefore not within contemplation of Workers' Compensation Act.
