Title: Eichstadt v. Frisch's Restaurants, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: To impute tortious intent on corporate employer under alter ego theory, employee must show both ownership and control of corporation are in the hands of the tortfeasor.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Employee failed to establish that her injuries were not by accident, and therefore not within contemplation of Workers' Compensation Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: GIW Industries, Inc. v. JerPeg Contracting, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Georgia, Augusta Division.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, a corporate officer who takes part in the commission of a tort by a corporation is personally liable therefor, but an officer of a corporation who takes no part in the commission of a tort committed by the corporation is not personally liable unless he specifically directed the particular act to be done or participated or cooperated therein, or unless he disregarded the corporate form so as to authorize piercing of the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Officer-shareholder was protected by corporate veil under Georgia law from individual liability on fraud claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Matson v. Noble Inv. Group, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Hotel franchisor's parent companies were not liable as franchisors for injuries to hotel employee; parent companies were not parties to the governing franchise agreement, and there was no showing that franchisor was parent companies' alter ego or agent.
Document Preview: TORTS - Pleading. Plaintiff was not entitled to add party as a defendant after statute of limitations had run, despite timely service on the party's parent company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Axtmann v. Chillemi
Court: Supreme Court of North Dakota.
Headnote: In tort cases when an attempt is made to pierce a corporate veil, particular significance is placed on whether a corporation is undercapitalized, which involves an added public policy consideration of whether individuals may transfer a risk of loss to the public in the name of a corporation that is marginally financed.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Judgment debtor's assignment of listing services contracts to new corporation did not constitute a fraudulent conveyance.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Gaerte v. Great Lakes Terminal & Transport Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Indiana, South Bend Division.
Headnote: Under Indiana law, injured motorist, who was "majority shareholder" and president of company that manufactured race care engines, could not recover damages based on the company's lost profits following motorists's accident with tanker truck owned by defendant company, even though motorist attended trade shows on a regular basis on behalf of company, and notwithstanding his contention that he was the company's alter ego, where motorist was not the sole shareholder of his company, was not personally liable for the company's secured debt, did not provide evidence that he was in charge of the company's day-to-day operations or that he was the company's primary decision maker, and any loss to the company during his absence had also been caused by a negative "market trend."
Document Preview: TORTS - Damages. Injured motorist could not recover his company's lost profits due to his absence following accident.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Ripley v. Eon Labs Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Allegations that two subsidiary pharmaceutical manufacturing corporations were wholly owned by parent and acted as agent and alter ego of parent in operations, and that all three corporations knowingly and deliberately failed to warn patients and consumers that they could be exposed to life threatening reactions if they took drug, were sufficient to plead that corporate veil should be pierced under New Jersey law, as required for customer alleging that she suffered life threatening allergic reaction to drug manufactured by subsidiary corporation to state claim against parent.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Removal for diversity was warranted even though two named parties were residents of same state.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Fitzgerald v. CBS Broadcasting, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: A tort plaintiff may not multiply defendants by breaking up a corporation or other institution into its organizational components, when those components have no separate legal identity.
Document Preview: COPYRIGHTS - Fair Use. Television stations did not make fair use of gangster arrest photograph.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: In re B.L. Jennings, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Jacksonville Division.
Headnote: Under California law, allegedly defective firearms manufactured by corporation owned by wife of firearms designer were manufactured as part of joint venture that existed between spouses, so as to make wife jointly and severally liable, as joint venturer, for injuries and damages inflicted by these firearms, where corporation was mere instrumentality, that was created for sake of convenience in carrying out this joint venture, where requisite community of interest existed between spouses, where wife shared in profits and losses by receiving dividends as shareholder and receiving salary as president of corporation, where wife delegated authority to husband and followed his instructions in running corporation, and where fiduciary duties existed between parties, based on wife status as officer of corporate manufacturer that was dependent upon husband and his separate company for design and marketing of firearms.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Transfer of unencumbered property for no consideration after debtor was named as tort defendant was fraudulent transfer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Tehozol v. Anand Realty Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Verdict against individual defendants was unsupported in action brought by tenant against corporate building owner and individual defendants after he was allegedly attacked in lobby of his apartment building while retrieving his mail, where there was no evidence supporting a piercing of corporate veil.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Landlord and Tenant. Counsel's remarks were sufficiently prejudicial as to together create likelihood that misconduct influenced verdict.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Penn Nat. Gaming, Inc. v. Ratliff
Court: Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Headnote: The corporate veil will not be pierced, in either contract or tort claims, except where there is some abuse of the corporate form itself.
Document Preview: TORTS - Dram Shop. Parent company of casino operator was not liable for operator's alleged violations of dram shop law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Figueiredo v. New Palace Painters Supply Co. Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: General contractor could not seek indemnification or contribution from property owner on negligence and scaffolding law claims asserted against general contractor on behalf of laborer who died on renovation project when he fell through an open hole, though general contractor and property owner shared common owners and officers, as general contractor and property owner were separate entities and not parent/subsidiary, property owner had hired general contractor to run the renovation project, and property owner did not supervise, direct, or control the contractors or work, and it did not enter into contracts with subcontractors, or provide tools or materials. McKinney's Labor Law § 240(1).
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Contractors and Developers. Violation of scaffolding law was the proximate cause of death of laborer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Mistrulli v. McFinnigan, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: There was no basis upon which to pierce the corporate veil so as to hold individuals who were shareholders of corporation that allegedly owned and operated bar in which plaintiff's husband was fatally stabbed during altercation with other patrons liable for common-law negligence and violation of the Dram Shop Act; the evidence failed to raise a triable issue of fact as to the presence of either element required to pierce the veil, namely, that the individuals exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction at issue, or that such domination was used to commit a wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in the plaintiff's injury. McKinney's General Obligations Law § 11-101.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil would not be pierced as to individuals who owned company that owned bar in which patron was fatally stabbed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: In re Ephedra Products Liability Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Texas law, in toxic-tort products liability action brought by consumer of ephedra product who had suffered stroke, against corporate marketer/seller and marketer's principal, corporate veil did not shield principal from legal consequences of his acts, regardless of any showing that principal was alter ego of marketer; principal was marketer's only agent, thus marketer's contacts with Texas and its acts allegedly constituting products liability and fraud were attributable to principal individually. Restatement (Third) of Agency § 7.01.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Experts. Treating neurologist's specific-causation opinion in toxic-tort products liability action was admissible expert testimony.

Title: Town Hall Estates-Whitney, Inc. v. Winters
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Waco.
Headnote: To make the parent liable for the subsidiary's tort, the corporate entity of the subsidiary must have been used to bring about results which are condemned by the general statements of public policy which are enunciated by the courts as rules which determine whether the courts will recognize their own child.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Wrongful Discharge. Nursing home would not have terminated employee but for her report concerning resident's abuse allegation.

Title: Pico v. Capriccio Italian Restaurant, Inc.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Willard v. Fairfield Southern Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate parent was not the alter ego of private rail carrier under Alabama law, and therefore was not the employer of private carrier's employee for Federal Employer's Liability Act (FELA) purposes; the companies were financially independent, their employees were represented by different unions, and their train operations were regulated by different agencies. Federal Employers' Liability Act, § 1, 45 U.S.C.A. § 51.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Transportation Workers. Employer was not a common carrier by railroad subject to Federal Employer's Liability Act.

Title: d'Elia v. Rice Development, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Utah.
Headnote: Owner of California corporation that was general partner in California real estate development limited partnership was personally liable for general partner's breach of fiduciary duty to limited partner; owner exclusively controlled and directed the affairs of corporation, general partner failed to account for payments for option upgrades, failed to account for money missing from sale of homes, failed to account for missing utility deposits, and owner authorized and directed practice of making undocumented loans to and from limited partnership from entities related to general partner.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. The owner of a limited liability company was personally liable for tortious acts of the company in which he participated.

Title: Zempel v. Liberty
Court: Supreme Court of Montana.
Headnote: Fact that shareholder was tavern's sole shareholder was not, by itself, enough to warrant piercing the corporate veil concerning claim arising from personal injuries that underage patron allegedly sustained in automobile accident after bartenders allegedly served patron and continued to serve patron after he was visibly intoxicated.

Title: Verni ex rel. Burstein v. Harry M. Stevens, Inc.

Title: Verni ex rel. Burstein v. Harry M. Stevens, Inc.
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division.
Headnote: Evidence did not establish that parent corporation of subsidiaries, one of which acted as concessions contractor for professional football stadium and the other of which leased employees to contractor, abused the privilege of incorporation, as element for piercing the veil of corporate parent, in action brought under Alcoholic Beverage Server Fair Liability Act by passengers in vehicle that collided with intoxicated motorist's vehicle after motorist left the stadium; while subsidiaries did not engage in businesses of their own, parent generally formed contracting subsidiaries to enable it to operate in various states, and defendant subsidiaries were not undercapitalized. Title: Tamko Roofing Products, Inc. v. Smith Engineering Co.

Title: Tamko Roofing Products, Inc. v. Smith Engineering Co.

Title: Martinez v. Plaza Prospect Apt., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Alter ego of company that contracted to perform renovation work on building was obligated to indemnify building owner for injuries sustained by worker at site, after contracting company defaulted on third-party claim; rather than being two companies whose ownership and management were merely interrelated, their separate existence was completely ignored as they were run solely by the same brothers, out of the same office, with the assistance of one secretary, who, like other employees, was indiscriminately paid out of the accounts of any one of the several business entities.

Headnote: Corporation whose subsidiary employed truck driver who collided with motorist's car was not liable to motorist for his injuries sustained in the accident, where there was no evidence that driver was employed by corporation, rather than by subsidiary, and motorist's complaint did not allege that corporate veil should be pierced to hold corporation liable for subsidiary's debts.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Bailey v. Handee Hugo's, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Neither sister corporation of entity that leased the premises and operated the store at which patron slipped and fell nor other party named as defendant could be held responsible in patron's action for damages, precluding patron's recovery; there was no evidence that sister corporation had complete domination and control over entity that leased the premises and operated the store.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Parties. Principles of equitable estoppel did not apply to permit patron to amend pleadings to join responsible party.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Ramirez v. Hariri
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: In a tort case, the financial strength or weakness of a corporation is an important factor in deciding whether to disregard the corporate fiction; however, the mere existence of undercapitalization is not determinative.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporation's contacts could not be imputed to corporation's shareholders as basis for personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Montes Serrano v. New York Times Co., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: A parent company will not be held liable for the torts of its subsidiary unless it can be shown that the parent exercises complete dominion and control over the subsidiary.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Parent corporation did not control subsidiary's operations as to warrant holding parent liable for subsidiary's negligence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Secrest v. Gibbs
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eleventh District, Lake County.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to support jury's finding to pierce the corporate veil of corporations involved in property development and hold corporations' president personally liable for damages caused to property owners, where evidence indicated that president exercised significant if not absolute control over the general functions of both corporations, he could draw on the cash of the corporations whenever he needed, and he used both corporations to file an invalid mechanics' lien against property owners, which injured them to the extent that they were unable to refinance their property.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Shareholder's wife, who was corporate president, was not personally liable for actions of corporations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Bishop Eddie Long Ministries, Inc. v. Dillard
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to establish that corporate status of lower riparian landowner was a sham to avoid tort and statutory responsibility for dam so as to justify piercing corporate veil, in nuisance and trespass action arising out of lower riparian landowner's attempt to breach deteriorating dam and drain lake and upper riparian landowners' efforts to refill lake by plugging dam's drainage pipe; lower riparian landowner never opened or maintained a bank account, rather individual shareholders wrote checks out of personal accounts to pay lower riparian landowner's bills, no corporate stock was issued, no directors' or shareholders' meetings were held, no tax returns were file, and lower riparian landowner argued before the Department of Natural Resources and in litigation that it did not own the dam and therefor had no responsibility for its maintenance.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Nuisance. Finding that both sets of landowners created a nuisance concerning dam-created lake was not irreconcilably inconsistent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Aspex Eyewear, Inc. v. Altair Eyewear, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Unless there is at least specific intent to escape liability for a specific tort, the cause of justice does not require disregarding the corporate entity.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Parties. Absent any basis to pierce the corporate veil, principal would not be added as defendant in infringement suit against subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Cementos de Chihuahua, S.A. de C.V. v. Intermodal Sales Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, El Paso.
Headnote: There must be something more than mere unity of financial interest, ownership and control for a court to treat the subsidiary as the alter ego of the parent corporation and make the parent liable for the subsidiary's tort.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Evidence was legally insufficient to establish that sister corporation was liable to shipping corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Cementos de Chihuahua, S.A. de C.V. v. Intermodal Sales Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, El Paso.
Headnote: In order to make the parent corporation liable for the subsidiary's tort the corporate entity of the subsidiary must have been used to bring about results which are condemned by the general statements of public policy which are enunciated by the courts as rules which determine whether the courts will recognize their own child.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Evidence was legally insufficient to establish that sister corporation was liable to shipping corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Cementos de Chihuahua, S.A. de C.V. v. Intermodal Sales Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, El Paso.
Headnote: In order to make the parent corporation liable for the subsidiary's tort the plaintiff must prove that he has fallen victim to a basically unfair device by which a corporate entity has been used to achieve an inequitable result.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Evidence was legally insufficient to establish that sister corporation was liable to shipping corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: VFP VC v. Dakota Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Idaho, Boise, December 2004 Term.
Headnote: Real estate development corporation's owner could be personally liable under corporate veil theory for intentional interference with contract based on failure to turnover two progress payments and check to other developer, even if money taken benefited the corporation and not owner exclusively, as jury could have disregarded the corporate entity and held owner personally liable for the corporation's actions.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Developer committed fraud by submitting change order for change in general conditions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: In re White
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Nebraska.
Headnote: Under Nebraska law, when tort action is brought against corporate officer or director, there is no need to pierce corporate veil; rather, liability will be imposed if elements of tort are satisfied.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. State court judgment was entitled to preclusive effect.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: National Plan Administrators, Inc. v. National Health Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: Evidence supported conclusions that third-party administrator of insurance policies and its parent corporation operated as a single business enterprise and that corporate veil could be pierced to make corporation liable for administrator's breach of fiduciary duty to underwriter for involvement in transfer of policies to different insurer; the corporations shared offices in common, owned common computer systems, and maintained common accounting systems, their arrangement formed the basis for part of the corporation's marketing strategy since the common remitter system allowed insurers to sell more policies and leave the corporations to manage administration for the insurer and the employer for all types of policies underwritten by one insurer, and the parent corporation's shareholder did not distinguish the functions of the companies.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Agents and Brokers. Third-party administrator and parent corporation were liable to health insurer for breach of fiduciary duty.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: National Plan Administrators, Inc. v. National Health Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: Punitive damages award against parent and subsidiary corporations operating as single business enterprise was not barred by the statute making each defendant liable only for punitive damages award made against that defendant; the corporations operated as single entity. V.T.C.A., Civil Practice & Remedies Code § 41.006.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Agents and Brokers. Third-party administrator and parent corporation were liable to health insurer for breach of fiduciary duty.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Hunting v. Elders
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: Corporation that operated bar that served driver who was already intoxicated did not keep sufficient records, thereby supporting piercing corporate veil to impose damages in motorist's personal injury case on dominant shareholder as alter ego of corporation; corporation did not have adequate records of income from bars or video poker machines, and did not have records of cash receipts, cash expenses, sales, inventory, or other profit and loss statements that would normally be expected.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Dominant shareholder was responsible for judgment against corporation under alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Hunting v. Elders
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: Lack of activity by niece of dominant shareholder in corporation that operated bar that served driver who was already intoxicated warranted piercing the corporate veil and imposing liability in motorist's personal injury case directly on dominant shareholder; niece did not know that she was an officer of the corporation, and did not attend corporate meetings.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Dominant shareholder was responsible for judgment against corporation under alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Hunting v. Elders
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: Undercapitalization of corporation that operated bar that served driver who was already intoxicated supported piercing corporate veil to impose liability in motorist's personal injury case directly on dominant shareholder as alter ego of company; capitalization of $1,000 each was not sufficient for continuing operation of bars, with their inherent risks.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Dominant shareholder was responsible for judgment against corporation under alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Hunting v. Elders
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: Dominant shareholder's siphoning of funds from corporation that operated bar that served driver who was already intoxicated supported piercing corporate veil to impose personal liability in motorist's personal injury case on shareholder, as alter ego of corporation; shareholder siphoned off $400,000 to $800,000 over a three-year period, and shareholder left in the till only so much as was needed to pay basic expenses.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Dominant shareholder was responsible for judgment against corporation under alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Hunting v. Elders
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: Factors of injustice and fundamental unfairness supported piercing corporate veil of corporation that operated bar that served driver who was already intoxicated, to impose liability in motorist's personal injury suit on dominant shareholder; shareholder knew of claim against corporation, but acted in a self-serving and unfair manner by siphoning off substantial sums of money, commingling and transferring assets which he held in his own name to different entities, transferring stock in the corporation to other individuals without a valuable consideration, and then finally dissolving the corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Dominant shareholder was responsible for judgment against corporation under alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Hunting v. Elders
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: Dominant shareholder of corporation that operated bar that served driver who was already intoxicated was liable for post-judgment interest in motorist's personal injury case; when corporate veil was pierced, debts of corporation became shareholder's individual debts.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Dominant shareholder was responsible for judgment against corporation under alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Parkinson v. Guidant Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Absent evidence that parent corporation controlled its subsidiary to such a degree that subsidiary was a mere instrumentality or alter ego of parent, parent could not be held liable under Pennsylvania law on products liability claims based on acts of subsidiary.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Unavoidably Unsafe Products. Prescription medical device was unavoidably unsafe product.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Richmond v. Indalex Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. North Carolina.
Headnote: Fraud or inequity that will support piercing corporate veil under Delaware law must be distinct from tort alleged in complaint.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent companies' alleged control of an employer would not permit piercing corporate veil for employee's injury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Matheson v. Virgin Islands Community Bank, Corp.
Court: District Court of the Virgin Islands, Division of St. Croix, Appellate Division.
Headnote: Contract, tort and ERISA claims may be leveled against corporate shareholder or officer if it can be shown that shareholder or officer is doing business in his or her individual capacity without regard to corporate formality,that is, if it is appropriate to "pierce the corporate veil." Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, § 2 et seq., 29 U.S.C.A. § 1001 et seq.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Wrongful Discharge. Virgin Islands bank officer's wrongful discharge cause of action accrued before statutory amendment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Whetstone Candy Co., Inc. v. Kraft Foods, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Florida law, neither fact that letter sent by competitor's subsidiary to third party was on letterhead that shared common elements with competitor's letterhead, nor fact that initial public offering (IPO) of competitor's parent corporation stated that competitor owned product manufactured by subsidiary, warranted piercing subsidiary's corporate veil to hold competitor liable in action brought by chocolate manufacturer alleging interference with business relationships.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Settlements. Settlement agreement was not binding on settling party's subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Orloff v. Saipem, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas.
Headnote: Texas subsidiary of Italian corporation was not liable for injuries sustained by worker from Louisiana on drilling rig in Saudi Arabia operated by Italian corporation's Saudi subsidiary; Texas subsidiary had no connection to worker's injuries, and worker had shown no facts that under Texas law would permit corporate distinction between Texas subsidiary and Italian parent to be disregarded.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Texas subsidiary of Italian corporation was not liable for injuries on drilling rig in Saudi Arabia.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Galactic Employer Services, Inc. v. McDorman
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Alabama.
Headnote: Corporate veil of corporation would not be pierced in order to hold chairman of corporation's board of directors and vice-president of corporation personally liable for corporate officer's misuse of corporation's funds which damaged business, which had contracted with corporation to provide payroll services for corporation; chairman and vice president both stated during their depositions that officer had control and use of credit card that had been issued in vice president's name and that vice president had no knowledge that card had been issued, this evidence was not contradicted by business, other payments made by company check were made solely for benefit of officer, and officer had control of corporation's day-to-day operations, including check-writing authority.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil of corporation would not be pierced to hold chairman personally liable for officer's misuse of funds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Mill Run Associates v. Locke Property Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: "Participation theory" of tort liability differs from "piercing corporate veil" under Pennsylvania law, since purpose of latter is to hold owner liable because his corporation is something less than bona fide independent entity.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Vendor and Purchaser. Subdivision purchaser stated fraudulent inducement claim against vendor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Schlueter v. Carey
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Fort Worth.
Headnote: In a tort case, the financial strength of the corporate tort-feasor is an important consideration in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil; if the corporation sued is not reasonably capitalized in light of the nature and risk of its business, the need might arise to attempt to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Shareholder was liable as corporation's alter ego for injury caused to customer by corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: In re Ski Train Fire In Kaprun, Austria on Nov. 11, 2000
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Grandparents and parents stated claim for piercing corporate veil under Colorado law, in lawsuit against Austrian holding company and other Austrian corporations following death of their children and grandchildren in ski train accident, on allegations that parent corporation and its subsidiaries acted as single enterprise, that holding company drained assets of subsidiary to avoid paying judgment to plaintiffs, and that failure to hold parent and subsidiaries responsible for actions of other subsidiary would have created inequitable result.
Document Preview: TORTS - Jurisdiction. Interests of justice required transfer of wrongful death lawsuit to Colorado federal court.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Hoang v. Arbess
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. III.
Headnote: The corporate veil need not be pierced where a tort action is brought against an officer or director and the elements of the tort are proved.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Contractors and Developers. Building company's manager was potentially individually liable for alleged construction defects.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Strawbridge v. Sugar Mountain Resort, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. North Carolina, Asheville Division.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, district courts disregard the corporate entity and hold an individual liable for the corporation's torts when an individual exercises actual control over a corporation, operating it as a mere instrumentality or tool.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Claim to pierce corporate veil could be filed for first time in recommenced complaint.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: U.S. v. Union Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Where the conduct of a dominant corporation is deliberate, with the specific intent to escape liability for a specific tort or class of torts, corporate veil piercing is justified.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Past and current owners of contaminated site were responsible parties under CERCLA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Carbo v. City of Slidell
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Property owners failed to establish any basis for piercing corporate veil with regard to contractor which, with consent of city, gratuitously restored berm on side of drainage canal to its original condition, for purposes of action seeking damages for flooding of property.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Aviation Leasing Group v. Hyatt Corp.
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Hotel developer failed to show that hotel management corporation was alter ego of its international subsidiary, in order to be held liable for subsidiary's acts, in suit alleging that subsidiary interfered with contractual relations and prospective economic advantage by contracting directly with developer's agent to manage hotels abroad, and thus, hotel corporation was entitled to judgment as matter of law; there was no evidence that hotel corporation itself engaged in transactions complained of, there was no evidence of "manipulative conduct" between corporation and subsidiary, corporations did not own each other's stock, and entities functioned as separate corporations.

Title: Old Republic Nat. Title Ins. Co. v. Moskowitz
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: No basis existed for title insurer to pierce corporate veil as against wife of one of the principals in corporation liable to insurer for conversion of funds collected at real estate closings; wife was not an owner, director or shareholder in corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Williams v. REP Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: United States distributor that did not sell machine which allegedly caused worker's injuries could not be held strictly liable on public policy grounds, under theory that distributor was wholly-owned subsidiary of foreign parent company that owned foreign manufacturer of allegedly defective machine; contrary to worker's contentions, fundamental fairness did not require holding corporation liable for injury caused by product it did not sell simply because corporation that did sell product was also owned by same parent company, and court could not ignore language of Indiana products liability statute precluding distributor's strict liability. I.C. 33–1–1.5–3(a) (1996 Ed.).
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Persons Liable. Distributor was not strictly liable under Indiana law for allegedly defective machine it did not sell.

Title: Jenkins v. Anderson Machine Sales
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division.
Headnote: Major shareholder of prior manufacturer of capping machine was not liable to employee in her product liability action for injuries sustained when her arm was crushed by the machine, even though shareholder maintained a relationship with the successor manufacturers; holding shareholder liable required that employee allege fraud, but employee had not done so.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Ramirez v. Misson Peak Development Co.
Court: Court of Appeal, First District, Division 4, California.
Headnote: Builder's president did not participate in alleged tortious conduct in marketing and construction of homes, nor did he control corporations to extent he was alter ego to hold him personally liable for alleged corporate conduct, where president testified that he did not approve or know of any tortious conduct, and homeowners failed to show piercing the corporate veil was necessary to avoid inequitable result.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: In re Kentuckiana Truck & Trailer Repair, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Kentucky.
Headnote: Former shareholders of Chapter 7 debtor failed to show that creditor, either directly or indirectly through turnaround specialist, used debtor as its instrumentality or "alter ego"; there was no evidence that creditor directly so used debtor, and debtor's turnaround specialist did not act as creditor's agent, did not exercise dominion and control over debtor, and did not commit tortious or wrongful acts, causing unjust damage.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: United Feature Syndicate, Inc. v. Miller Features Syndicate, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.

Document Preview: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY - Computers and Online Services. Unauthorized Internet display was potential copyright violation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Keener Lumber Co., Inc. v. Perry
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil of a corporation allows a plaintiff to impose legal liability for a corporation's obligations, or for torts committed by the corporation, upon some other company or individual that controls and dominates the corporation.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Creditor's filing of proof of claim in bankruptcy action did not deprive trial court of jurisdiction.

Title: McGregor v. Vela
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: Corporate agents who knowingly direct or participate in a tortious act may be held individually liable without piercing the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Beswick v. City Of Philadelphia
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Although limitation of liability is a legitimate benefit of incorporation, that benefit is lost where the corporate form is resorted to deliberately, with specific intent to escape liability for a specific tort or class of torts.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - Public Safety. City was not liable for heart attack victim's death arising from 911 call-taker's improper private ambulance referral.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Kern v. Oesterreichische Elektrizitaetswirtschaft Ag
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Surviving family members of Americans who died in ski train accident could not pierce corporate veil to hold Austrian holding company liable for any tort committed by its subsidiaries, absent a showing that holding company acted as the alter ego of any of its subsidiaries.

Title: Shoemaker v. Giacalone
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Patron seeking to impose personal liability on sole shareholder of tavern corporation, in action for personal injuries arising out of tavern brawl, failed to show that tavern was alter ego of sole shareholder, where shareholder did not deliberately undercapitalize tavern or deplete its assets, and shareholder keep tavern account separate from his personal account. LSA-R.S. 12:93, subd. B.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Patron injured in brawl did not establish that tavern corporation was sole shareholder's alter ego.

Title: Fiumetto v. Garrett Enterprises, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Second District.
Headnote: When a party enters into a contractual relationship with a corporation, a relevant consideration in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil is whether the party is misled into believing a shareholder or director is also a party; however, tort victims do not choose to become victims of particular tortfeasors or rely upon the tortfeasor's ability to compensate them.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Unemployment Compensation. Private right of action for retaliatory discharge for claiming unemployment compensation could be implied.

Title: Fiumetto v. Garrett Enterprises, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Second District.
Headnote: Whether former employee had relied on corporate employer's president to satisfy the corporation's obligations was irrelevant to determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, in former employee's action for tortious interference with a business advantage, relating to corporation's termination of her employment in alleged retaliation for filing a claim for temporary unemployment benefits.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Unemployment Compensation. Private right of action for retaliatory discharge for claiming unemployment compensation could be implied.

Title: McFarland v. Brier
Court: Supreme Court of Rhode Island.
Headnote: Corporation wholly owned by accountant was liable as alter ego to industrial supplier for damages caused by accountant's use of confidential information obtained from supplier to compete with supplier; supplier had hired the corporation itself to provide accounting services, the accountant and his secretary were the only employees of the corporation, and corporation financed the competitor formed by accountant.

Title: Brito v. DILP Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: An owner and shareholder of a corporation is not individually liable for the torts of that corporation unless it is established that complete domination was exerted by the owner or shareholder to commit a wrong against the one seeking to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. That corporation had insufficient assets was not basis to impose liability on shareholder.

Title: Roll v. Tracor, Inc.

Headnote: Parent corporation could not be held liable for torts of subsidiary, where only involvement parent had in subsidiary was to merely exercise type of control that derived from stock ownership, e.g., electing directors and making by-laws.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: King v. Modern Music Co.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 4.
Headnote: Motorists, who were injured in vehicular accident with intoxicated driver and who subsequently obtained default judgment against driver and tavern, did not establish grounds to disregard the corporate shield so as to hold company, which subleased premises to tavern and provided tavern with vending and amusement machines, and company's owner responsible for motorists' injuries; neither owner nor company directly operated tavern or supplied beer to patrons of tavern, including driver, and they did not receive any proceeds directly from the sale of items.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate shield would not be disregarded so as to hold company, which leased premises to tavern, responsible for motorists' injuries.

Title: King v. Modern Music Co.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 4.
Headnote: Relationship between tavern and company, which subleased premises to tavern and had an oral agreement with tavern to provide the vending and amusement machines in consideration of a payment of the proceeds from the machines, was that of landlord and tenant, as opposed to that of partner or joint venturer, and this landlord-tenant relationship, without more, did not justify disregarding the corporate shield so as to hold company and its owner responsible for injuries that motorists sustained in vehicular accident with intoxicated driver who was served by tavern.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate shield would not be disregarded so as to hold company, which leased premises to tavern, responsible for motorists' injuries.

Title: Limited, Inc. v. Air Cargo, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Consignee on air waybill could not be held liable for damages caused by sister corporation, absent evidence that consignee had contract with shipper or had contact with goods, or that consignee and sister corporation were in fact single entity.

Title: Rodriguez v. Riddell Sports, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas products liability law, there must be something more than mere unity of financial interest, ownership and control for a court to treat a corporate subsidiary as the alter ego of its parent and make the parent liable for the subsidiary's tort.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Melanson v. Town of West Hartford
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Alter ego theory of corporate responsibility permits access to tort remedies only if person committing intentional tort can be characterized as alter ego of corporation.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Exclusivity provision of Workers' Compensation Act barred police officer's personal injury claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: McMahon v. 42nd St. Development Project, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Bronx County, New York.
Headnote: Contractor's parent corporation was not liable for contractor's alleged violation of scaffold law, absent evidence that parent exercised control over contractor in connection with the construction project on which construction worker was injured. McKinney's Labor Law § 240.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Contractors and Developers. Worker who was injured when he fell from platform without railing established violation of scaffold law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Dews v. Ratterree
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Concept of piercing the corporate veil is applied in Georgia to remedy injustices which arise where a party has over extended his privilege in the use of a corporate entity in order to defeat justice, perpetuate fraud, or to evade contractual or tort responsibility.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Question of whether corporate veil of garage door company should be pierced in tort action was for jury.

Title: Texas-Ohio Gas, Inc. v. Mecom
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Corporate creditor's claims against shareholders for fraud, fraudulent inducement, negligent misrepresentation, and tortious interference with a contract, based on alleged misrepresentations regarding nature of corporate acquisition to induce sale of natural gas to insolvent corporations on credit, were based on contractual obligation of the corporations and thus were governed exclusively by the shareholder liability provision of the Texas Business Corporation Act, which limited recovery to certain fraud-based claims, where there was no allegation that shareholders agreed to be personally liable or were liable under another statute. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Sanctions. Rule 13 sanctions were not warranted in corporate creditor's suit against shareholders.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Texas-Ohio Gas, Inc. v. Mecom
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Corporate creditor's claim against shareholders for tortious interference with a contract, for allegedly mischaracterizing nature of corporate acquisition of existing customer to induce sale of natural gas to insolvent corporations on credit, was not barred by the shareholder liability provision of the Texas Business Corporation Act, which limited recovery to certain fraud-based claims, where fraud was alleged as means of interference. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Sanctions. Rule 13 sanctions were not warranted in corporate creditor's suit against shareholders.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Sullivan v. Wallace
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Co-owner of wooded tract could not pierce the corporate veil and recover against corporate officer of timber company for trespass, conversion, or negligence in the removal of timber, absent any showing that officer committed fraud, personally trespassed, or physically removed timber, or that he failed to follow the statutory requirements for transacting corporate affairs, such as maintaining corporate bank accounts and filing corporate tax returns.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Timber. Whether timber company should have known that tree removal was without consent of one co-owner presented fact issue.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: In re Computer Engineering Associates, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Corporate veil could not be pierced, in order to holder subcontractor's shareholders liable for subcontractor's alleged conversion and other misconduct in connection with government contract, where one of these officers, while owning 55% of stock of subcontractor, was not shown to have exercised complete domination and control over subcontractor, and neither officer was shown to have exercised the type of control required for veil-piercing under either New York or Massachusetts law; majority stock ownership, without more, did not suffice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Joint deposit arrangement was not absolute transfer of debtor-contractor's interest in payments.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Holbrook v. Lobdell-Emery Mfg. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Indiana law, to impute tortious intent to an employer that is a legal entity or artificial person, employee seeking to assert intentional tort claim against employer must show either that (1) corporation is tortfeasor's alter ego, or (2) corporation has substituted its will for that of the individual who committed the tortious acts; to prevail under alter ego theory, employee must show that both ownership and control of corporation are in tortfeasor's hands, while to succeed under the other theory, employee must show that individual who committed the tort was acting pursuant to policy or decision made through corporation's regular decision-making channels by those with authority to do so.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Employer's Liability. Employer not liable on emotional distress claim based on co-workers' alleged abuse of mentally ill employee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: McConkey v. McGhan Medical Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Tennessee.
Headnote: Breast implant recipient failed to make a showing that former parent company controlled former subsidiary at time subsidiary manufactured recipient's implants, despite loan made by parent company to subsidiary, and therefore could not pierce the corporate veil, as prerequisite to imposing liability under Tennessee law on theories of instrumentality, alter ego, or parent/subsidiary.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Breast implant recipient failed to make showing that former parent company controlled former subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Yarbrough v. Ledford
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Alabama.
Headnote: Property owners failed to establish that corporate officer acted in a negligent manner or misused his official capacity in the operation of two corporate entities which he solely owned, so as to justify piercing corporate veil, and thus property owners could not maintain trespass and private and public nuisance actions against corporate officer, in his individual capacity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Officers and Directors. Corporate officer was not personally liable on claims of trespass and nuisance.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Lipsig v. Ramlawi
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Headnote: Corporate veil could not be pierced to subject shareholders to vicarious liability for a corporate employee's allegedly defamatory statement about a shareholder's partner; nothing indicated that the corporation was either formed or utilized for an illegal, unethical, or improper purpose.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Filet Menu, Inc. v. C.C.L. & G., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: The alter ego doctrine does not immunize officers, directors, or shareholders of a corporation from tortious conduct that they themselves committed in the course of acting for the corporation, because anyone who participates in the commission of a tort is liable for that the damages resulting from that tort.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Simon v. Philip Morris, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, knowledge of subsidiary corporation involved in research into addictiveness of nicotine and adverse health consequences of tobacco smoking was properly imputed to parent holding corporation in smokers' class action against parent, even in absence of agency relationship or basis for piercing corporate veil; subsidiary conducted tobacco research for hundreds of parent's predecessor's subsidiaries for decades before its acquisition by parent, boards of both corporations were essentially identical, and parent's chairmen were former subsidiary chairmen.

Title: Autrey v. 22 Texas Services Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Galveston Division.
Headnote: In wrongful death action against corporations that owned and managed nursing home, filed in federal court on diversity grounds, district court applied Pennsylvania law in determining whether it should disregard the corporate entity and impute corporation's acts to its principals, where both corporate defendants were incorporated under the laws of Pennsylvania. 28 U.S.C.A. § 1332.

Title: Autrey v. 22 Texas Services Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Galveston Division.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, fact that limited partnerships which managed nursing homes were solvent was insufficient to establish that partnership's corporate general partners, which were solely liable for all debts of nursing home, were adequately capitalized, for purposes of avoiding piercing of corporate veil in wrongful death action against individual principals of corporate general partners.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Triable issues regarding capitalization precluded summary judgment against corporate principals.

Title: Retzler v. Pratt and Whitney Co.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Fifth Division.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, parent corporation and its wholly owned subsidiary, which had manufactured aircraft engine, were operated as separate and distinct corporations, so that flight attendant who was injured during emergency landing allegedly caused by defect in engine could not pierce corporate veil and recover against parent for her injuries; while parent was subsidiary's sole shareholder, and corporations had one member of their boards of directors in common, both corporations conformed with corporate formalities, funds were not commingled and places of headquarters and incorporation were completely separate, and there was no evidence of fraud.

Title: Thibodeau v. Cole
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Maine.
Headnote: Named defendant who did not own any stock in corporation that operated store could not be held liable for injuries allegedly sustained on ramp attached to store, even assuming corporate veil could be pierced.
Document Preview: TORTS - Negligence. Pedestrian could not maintain personal injury suit in which he named the wrong party.

Title: Florida Specialty, Inc. v. H 2 Ology, Inc.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, First District.
Headnote: Concept of piercing the corporate veil does not apply in the case of a tort, even where an intentional tort has not been alleged.

Title: Roberson v. PaineWebber, Inc.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 1.
Headnote: If one corporation is simply the instrumentality of another corporation, the separation between the two may be disregarded and treated as one for the purpose of tort law.

Title: Townsends, Inc. v. Beaupre
Court: Appeals Court of Massachusetts, Suffolk.
Headnote: Corporate veil need not be pierced for a corporate officer to be personally liable for a tort committed by the corporation if he personally participated in the tort by, for example, directing, controlling, approving, or ratifying the act that injured the aggrieved party.

Title: Kopec v. Hempstead Gardens, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Piercing of the corporate veil was not warranted in connection with purchasers' action to recover damages in connection with water drainage problems, where there was no evidence that principal of contractor and owner of real property exercised complete domination of contractor and owner to commit a wrong against purchasers which allegedly resulted in their injury from water drainage problems, or that he abused privilege of doing business in corporate form so as to perpetrate a wrong or injustice against them.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Gardemal v. Westin Hotel Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, parent corporation was not "alter ego" of subsidiary, for purposes of potential liability for drowning death of guest at beachfront hotel managed by subsidiary; while corporations were closely tied through stock ownership and shared officers, subsidiary was incorporated in Mexico while parent was incorporated in Delaware, subsidiary banked in Mexico and deposited all revenue from its six hotels in Mexican account, subsidiary had its own staff, assets, and insurance policies, and there was insufficient evidence that subsidiary was undercapitalized.
Document Preview: Guest at hotel in Mexico sued corporate manager and its parent corporation for negligence in connection with drowning death of her husband. In accordance with recommendations of magistrate judge, the United States District Court for the Western District of Texas, Orlando L. Garcia, J., dismissed action. Appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals, DeMoss, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) liability was not imputable to parent corporation under either the alter ego or single business enterprise doctrine, and (2) district court had neither specific nor general jurisdiction over hotel's corporate manager. Affirmed.

Title: Gardemal v. Westin Hotel Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, potential liability for drowning death of guest at beachfront hotel managed by subsidiary was not imputable to parent corporation pursuant to the single business enterprise doctrine; while subsidiary used parent corporation's trademark, its operations manuals, and its reservation system, those facts merely demonstrated a typical working relationship between a parent and subsidiary, and there was no evidence that separate corporate identities would result in harm or injustice in action to recover for guest's death.
Document Preview: Guest at hotel in Mexico sued corporate manager and its parent corporation for negligence in connection with drowning death of her husband. The Court of Appeals, DeMoss, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) liability was not imputable to parent corporation under either the alter ego or single business enterprise doctrine, and (2) district court had neither specific nor general jurisdiction over hotel's corporate manager. Title: Webber v. Inland Empire Investments
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Equitable considerations prevented use of the alter ego doctrine to bar the holder of a junior lien on real property from recovering, under a theory of conspiracy to interfere with contract, against the corporation which had given the lien, the corporation's principal, and other entities controlled by the principal based on allegations that they had joined together to eliminate the junior lien through a series of transactions which culminated in a sham foreclosure on the senior lien, even though there was a clear unity of ownership and interest among the defendants which otherwise would have supported application of the doctrine and precluded conspiracy liability. Title: Kaczor v. Vanchem, Inc.

Title: Davenport v. Quinn
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Bar patron who had obtained judgment against bar was entitled to pierce corporate veil under instrumentality rule and recover judgment from bar's sole shareholder and another corporation owned by shareholder, since shareholder had exercised complete control over bar with respect to finances, policy, and business practices, the control was used to avoid paying the judgment, and the breach of this positive legal duty proximately caused the patron's loss and injury.

Title: Davenport v. Quinn
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Bar patron who had obtained judgment against bar was entitled to pierce corporate veil under identity rule and recover judgment from bar's sole shareholder and another corporation owned by shareholder, given complete lack of corporate formality and shareholder's use of corporate funds to pay his personal bills.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Injured bar patron was entitled to pierce corporate veil and recover from bar's sole shareholder.

Title: Hefner v. Dausmann
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Southern District. Division One.
Headnote: The control that incorporated hospital had over an affiliated corporation, a regional medical clinic, was insufficient to establish that clinic was actual agent of hospital for purposes of joining hospital as defendant to parents' action against clinic for death of newborn child, even though hospital had authority to choose members of clinic's board of directors, could participate in the selection of clinic's key administrative personnel, and had a right to review quality-of-care procedures at clinic, where hospital did not have right to control hiring of mother's physician or to implement its own care procedures and require clinic to follow them.

Title: Hefner v. Dausmann
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Southern District. Division One.
Headnote: Parents failed to show that they changed their position in reliance on regional medical clinic's billboard advertising clinic's affiliation with hospital, as required to establish the apparent authority of clinic to act as agent for hospital, and thus, hospital was not liable to parents for wrongful death of child under theory of apparent agency, even though mother testified that she chose clinic for birth of her twins because she thought it was affiliated with hospital, where she also testified that she chose clinic because it was the facility for which her insurance would provide the most coverage.

Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.

Title: Townley v. Emerson Elec. Co.
Court: Supreme Court, Monroe County, New York.
Headnote: Parent corporation whose subsidiary had manufactured gear puller did not exercise complete domination and control over subsidiary, as required to pierce corporate veil and hold parent liable for acts of subsidiary in products liability action; evidence indicated only a fairly high degree between subsidiary and parent, which audited subsidiary, performed claims review, and maintained centralized banking for its subsidiaries, parent did not market subsidiary's products or exercise direct control in marketing, and transfers of employees were not so common as to create single employment unit.

Title: Seminole Pipeline Co. v. Broad Leaf Partners, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Parent corporation generally is not liable for torts committed by its subsidiaries, but the corporate fiction will be disregarded if: (1) the fiction is used as a means of perpetrating fraud; (2) a corporation is organized and operated as a mere tool or business conduit of another corporation; (3) the corporate fiction is resorted to as a means of evading an existing legal obligation; (4) the corporate fiction is employed to achieve or perpetrate a monopoly; (5) the corporate fiction is used to circumvent a statute; or (6) the corporate fiction is relied upon as a protection of crime or to justify wrong.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Damages. Statute capped award of punitive damages against each defendant rather than total punitive damages.
