Title: Air India v. Pennsylvania Woven Carpet Mills, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, mere fact that principal of insolvent carpet supplier was supplier's sole stockholder, sole director, president, and chief executive officer was insufficient to establish purchaser's claim that corporate veil should be pierced to hold principal liable for alleged conversion of carpet paid for but not delivered; purchaser did not establish that principal dominated and controlled supplier or used any such power to convert undelivered carpet.
Document Preview: Purchaser brought action against principal of insolvent carpet supplier, alleging claims including fraud, conversion, and directorial negligence under New York and Pennsylvania law.  Purchaser moved for summary judgment, and principal filed cross-motion for summary judgment.  The District Court, Kaplan, J., held that: (1) purchaser could not recover damages against principal under New York statute allowing action against directors and officers of corporation for negligence in management and disposition of corporate assets; (2) purchaser failed to establish conversion claim or claim that corporate veil should be pierced; (3) purchaser could not establish directorial negligence claim under Pennsylvania law; and (4) purchaser could not establish that any false representations were made by principal. Plaintiff's motion for summary judgment denied; defendant's cross-motion for summary judgment granted.

Court: Court of Appeals of New Mexico.
Headnote: Corporate veil could be pierced to allow patient of corporation providing chiropractic services to bring direct suit against principal for injuries resulting from furnishing and charging for excessive services; there was showing of dominion of principal over corporation, use of corporation for improper purpose, and injury in form of excessive fees and charges.

The Court of Appeals, Flores, J., held that: (1) patient could pierce corporate veil and recover directly from chiropractor; (2) patient could not recover for both breach of fiduciary duty and fraudulent misrepresentation; (3) punitive damages were recoverable; and (4) attorney fees were recoverable. Title: Joiner v. Ryder System Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. Illinois.
Headnote: Fact that holding company owned 100% of stock in subsidiary which in turn owned 100% of stock of company that manufactured allegedly defective automobile transport trailer, and that the three corporations had common officers and directors, did not indicate improper control by holding company over subsidiaries, so as to support a finding that holding company was alter ego of trailer manufacturer.
Document Preview: Worker brought strict products liability and negligence action to recover for injuries sustained when he attempted to remove skids located at rear of automobile transport trailer.  Parent company of trailer's manufacturer moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Richard Mills, J., held that: (1) parent company did not exert improper control over subsidiaries so as to support argument that parent was alter ego of trailer manufacturer; (2) parent company did not hold itself out as manufacturer of trailer, for purposes of liability under apparent manufacturer doctrine; and (3) assuming parent company was aware prior to injuries in question that trailer was unsafe, parent did not have duty to order subsidiary to redesign trailer. Motion for summary judgment allowed.

Headnote: Under Minnesota law, successor corporation was not liable for alleged defects in product produced by predecessor under "instrumentality doctrine" as applied in parent-subsidiary setting; predecessor was dissolved and its statutory liability expired prior to plaintiff's claim, and there was no evidence that plaintiff was victim of constructive fraud or injustice.

Title: Perry v. Stitzer Buick GMC, Inc.

Headnote: Tortious intent will be imputed to corporate employer where corporation is tort-feasor's alter ego, or corporation has substituted its will for that of tort-feasor.
Document Preview: Discharged African-American salesperson brought action against employer and co-workers alleging civil rights violations and torts.  The Johnson Circuit Court, Jeffrey C. Eggers, J., granted employer summary judgment on all claims, and salesperson appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Baker, J., affirmed summary judgment of civil rights claims but reversed on tort claims. Both parties sought transfer.  The Supreme Court, Shepard, C.J., held that: (1) trial court properly disposed of civil rights claims; (2) salesperson failed to establish jurisdiction on ground that his injuries were intentionally inflicted by employer; but (3) Worker's Compensation Act was not exclusive remedy for employee's nonphysical injuries. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded. Dickson, J., concurred with separate opinion in which DeBruler, J., joined. Opinion, 604 N.E.2d 613, vacated in part.

Title: Cooper v. Lakewood Engineering and Mfg. Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota, Third Division.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, no "injustice" existed as would warrant imposition of liability under instrumentality doctrine, and manufacturing corporation which purchased and dissolved fan manufacturer was not liable for tort claim asserted against fan manufacturer, where there was nothing which established that manufacturing corporation had operated fan manufacturer as constructive fraud or in unjust manner, or that failing to impose liability on manufacturing corporation would result in injustice.

Title: U.S. Fire Ins. Co. v. Allied Towing Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Identity of officers and directors of barge owner and owner of tugboat was not alone sufficient to permit piercing of corporate veil so as to find the barge owner partially at fault for collision involving the tug, the barge, and a Navy ship, and, thus, denial of prejudgment interest based on that finding of fault was an abuse of discretion.
Document Preview: In an action arising out of collision involving a tug, a tow, and a Navy ship, owner of tow and its insurance company filed suit against owner of tug and United States.  The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia, Robert G. Doumar, J., found both tug and Navy ship at fault for collision and apportioned liability equally between owner of tug and United States, awarded damages, but declined to award prejudgment interest.  Appeals were taken.  The Court of Appeals, Luttig, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) remand was required to enable district court to make more specific determinations for purposes of determining whether to rely on tow's insured value as measure of value, and (2) identity of officers and directors of tug owner and tow owner was not alone sufficient to permit piercing of corporate veil, and, thus, denial of prejudgment interest was an abuse of discretion. Affirmed in part, vacated in part, and remanded.

Title: Fitzgerald v. Pratt
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, Fifth District.
Headnote: Professional corporation's successor did not assume predecessor's liability, under "alter ego" theory, for intentional torts committed by corporate employee that were not in furtherance of predecessor's business. S.H.A. ch. 48, ¶ 138.5(a); ch. 32, ¶ 415-8.

Affirmed in part; reversed in part and remanded. Goldenhersh, P.J., filed opinion concurring in part and dissenting in part.

Headnote: Soft-drink franchisee was not mere "instrumentality" or "alter ego" of franchisor, such that franchisor could be held vicariously liable for torts of franchisee's driver, notwithstanding that franchisee was prohibited from selling any soft drinks other than those of franchisor and was required to prominently display franchisor's trademark on all of its delivery trucks.

Title: Gidwitz v. Stirco, Inc.

Headnote: Officer and director was not liable for corporation's alleged wrongdoing, in absence of evidence that he exercised dominant control over that corporation so as to be its "alter ego," that recognition of corporation as separate entity would promote either fraud or injustice, or that he had been actively involved in alleged wrongdoing; only relevant involvement centered around recommendation of market study that was made in exercise of his business judgment on behalf of corporation.
Document Preview: Buyer of feed mixer line brought action alleging violation of Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organization Act, breach of contract, conversion, and wrongful interference with contractual relation by sellers, who counterclaimed for breach of contract, fraud, appropriation of trade secrets, and interference with business relations.  On various motions, the District Court, Leighton, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) sellers were not entitled to summary judgment based on lack of racketeering activity, but buyers' failure to establish pattern of that activity under ongoing multiple episodes test warranted summary judgment for sellers; (2) buyer corporation's officer and director was not liable as corporation's alter ego or active participant in alleged corporate wrongdoing; and (3) buyer corporation's parent was alter ego and could be joined as counterdefendant. Motions granted.

Title: Duff v. Southern Ry. Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Where one corporation controls and dominates another corporation to extent that second corporation becomes a mere instrumentality of first, the dominant corporation becomes liable for those debts or torts of subservient corporation attributable to an abuse of that control.
Document Preview: Employee of alleged instrumentality of railroad brought action under Federal Employers' Liability Act to recover for injuries allegedly sustained during course of employment.  The Circuit Court, Jefferson County, C. W. Callaway, J., granted railroad's motion for summary judgment, and employee appealed. The Supreme Court, Shores, J., held that question whether employer was an instrumentality of railroad so as to make injured individual an employee of railroad for purposes of Federal Employers Liability Act because railroad owned all of employer's stock and paid salaries of its workers and because employer did over 99 percent of its business with railroad and had a director who was an officer of railroad was a question of fact precluding summary judgment. Reversed and remanded.

Headnote: Corporation did not own, operate, manage, possess, or control vessel, and thus could not be held liable under Jones Act for accidental death of diver performing underwater maintenance work thereon, despite contrary conclusions suggested by maintenance invoices and disbursement vouchers, where vessel's certificate of registry listed subsidiary corporation as owner. Title: Colby v. St. Paul Fire and Marine Ins. Co.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Insurer of lessee of truck involved in accident could not be held liable to satisfy judgment which injured driver had obtained against lessor of truck; although there were business connections between lessor and lessee, they were two separate corporations, which had lawfully changed their names, and there was no evidence of fraud so as to justify disregard of separate corporate entities. McKinney's Business Corporation Law § 805.
Document Preview: Driver injured in truck accident, after obtaining judgment against truck lessor, brought action for declaratory judgment that insurer of truck's lessee was liable on judgment.  The Supreme Court, Essex County, White, J., entered judgment in favor of insurer, and driver appealed.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Mikoll, J., held that lessee was separate corporation from lessor, and lessee's insurer could not be held liable on judgment, absent any showing of fraud to justify disregard of corporate entities. Affirmed.

Title: Alexander & Alexander of New York Inc. v. Fritzen
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Whether employer was second-tier subsidiary of corporation, or corporation and employer were both subsidiaries of a parent corporation, corporation did not have standing to assert tortious interference with employment relationship claim against employer's employee, where employer and corporation were separate and distinct entities, with neither exercising complete dominion and control over the other.
Document Preview: Corporation, which was either parent corporation or affiliate of employer, brought action against former employee and other defendants for conspiracy, unfair competition and tortious and malicious interference with its business relationships.  The Supreme Court, New York County, Clifford A. Scott, J., denied former employee's motion for summary judgment and granted corporation's cross motion to consolidate with action brought by employer, and former employee appealed.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that: (1) corporation did not have standing to bring action against former employee for conspiracy to divert contracts or for tortious interference with employer's employment relationship; (2) corporation failed to state causes of action for prima facie tort and injurious falsehood; but (3) interest of justice would be best served by joint trial of action brought by corporation and action brought by employer. Reversed.

Title: Nelson v. International Paint Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Paint company's wholly owned subsidiary, which manufactured allegedly defective paint which injured plaintiff, was not, under Texas law, alter ego of paint company so as to render that company liable to plaintiff, where company and subsidiary did not file consolidated income tax returns, company did not provide subsidiary's operating capital, subsidiary had never borrowed money from company, subsidiary kept its financial records separate from that of company's, each had its own account managers, treasurers, and controllers, each maintained their own headquarters, had separate board of directors meetings, there were no mutual employees and they shared no ownership of property.
Document Preview: Plaintiff, who was injured using allegedly defective paint, and his wife, brought products liability action against paint company.  The United States District Court for the Western District of Texas, H.F. Garcia, J., granted company's motion for summary judgment, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Randall, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) there was no evidence that paint company was manufacturer of paint in question; (2) even if paint company's wholly owned subsidiary was selling paint in question as a paint company product, paint company was not liable for plaintiff's injuries as manufacturer; (3) paint company was not estopped from denying liability on basis of mislabeling; and (4) subsidiary was not alter ego of paint company so as to render latter liable to plaintiff. Affirmed.

Title: Hogan v. Mayor & Aldermen of Savannah
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Concept of piercing the corporate veil is applied to remedy injustices which arise where a party has over extended his privilege in use of a corporate entity in order to defeat justice, perpetuate fraud or to evade contractual or tort responsibility.
Document Preview: Person who was corporate officer and shareholder brought action against the corporation's uninsured motorist insurer to recover damages for injuries sustained in accident which occurred while he was riding in police car to retrieve apparently impounded company vehicle.  The Superior Court, Chatham County, Oliver, J., granted summary judgment in favor of the insurer, and the corporate officer and shareholder appealed.  The Court of Appeals, McMurray, C.J., held that: (1) the policy did not provide coverage for the plaintiff, who was not a named insured under the policy; (2) corporate veil could not be pierced to view plaintiff as the named insured; and (3) statutory definition of insured as including the personal representative of any of the above did not provide coverage for the corporate officer and shareholder. Affirmed.

Title: Giuffria v. Red River Barge Lines, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: It was proper to pierce the corporate veil and hold parent corporation responsible for torts of subsidiary, in case in which parent owned 72% of subsidiary's stock, both had the same president, no corporate minutes were taken or meetings held for subsidiary after certain date, no tax return was filed for subsidiary in recent year, parent made over $200,000 in loans to subsidiary, president of parent worked as president of subsidiary for no salary, and personal liability was not being imposed on any individual shareholders.
Document Preview: Following vehicular collision, injured party brought action against owner of other vehicle and its parent company and against his uninsured motorist carrier.  The Civil District Court, Parish of Orleans, Richard J. Garvey, J., entered judgment in favor of plaintiff against owner of other vehicle and against his uninsured motorist carrier, and in favor of the carrier on his third-party demand against both vehicle owner and its parent corporation, and defendants appealed.  The Court of Appeal, Garrison, J., held that: (1) trial judge was correct in piercing the corporate veil in holding parent corporation responsible to the uninsured motorist carrier for the torts of the subsidiary; (2) uninsured motorist coverage was applicable; and (3) award of $25,000 damages to plaintiff, who sustained soft tissue injuries to the neck and back, was not an abuse of discretion. Affirmed.

Title: Potlatch Corp. v. Superior Court
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: Successor in interest to manufacturer of allegedly defective glue-laminated wood beam was not liable for damages caused by the beam on theory of alter ego, despite claim of injured victim's insurer, which was seeking subrogation, that it had not yet completed discovery with respect to issue of alter ego, where extensive discovery on the issue was reflected in the record, insurer had not identified any specific further discovery procedures it should be permitted to pursue, and successor was not liable, as matter of law, for damages on a theory of successor liability.
Document Preview: Insurer of automobile dealership, which suffered extensive damage when a roof supporting beam collapsed, commenced subrogation action against successor in interest to manufacturer of the beam.  Insurer moved for a determination that successor's liability for any damages for which manufacturer might have been liable was an issue without substantial controversy, and successor moved for summary judgment on ground that, as a matter of law, it was not liable.  The Superior Court, County of Riverside, granted insurer's motion.  Successor petitioned for a writ of mandate to review the matter.  After issuing an alternative writ of mandate, the Court of Appeal, Kaufman, Acting P.J., held that successor was not liable on either theory of alter ego or successor liability for damages caused by the allegedly defective beam. Writ issued.

Title: Landry v. St. Charles Inn, Inc.

Headnote: Hotel guest who was assaulted and robbed in hotel parking lot was not entitled to pierce the corporate veil of corporation which operated hotel to hold its four stockholders and their partnership liable, merely because those four individuals were the same persons who comprised the partnership which owned the parking lot.

The Court of Appeal, Augustine, J., held that: (1) hotel premises included hotel parking lot on which hotel guest was assaulted and robbed; (2) innkeeper's failure to provide security in hotel parking lot was a breach of its special duty to guest who was robbed on such lot, in view of repeated instances of assault that had taken place within the previous year in or around such parking lot; (3) landowner which leased parking lot to innkeeper owed no duty to protect guest of innkeeper from assault by third persons; thus, landowner was not liable for injury sustained by innkeeper's guest; (4) guest was not entitled to pierce the corporate veil of innkeeper to hold its four stockholders and their...

Title: Amarillo Oil Co. v. Mapco, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Amarillo Division.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce corporate veil in tort or contract context, no single factor is determinative: not complete stock ownership, not filing of joint tax returns, not interlocking directors and officers, and not loans between parent and subsidiary.
Document Preview: Plaintiffs filed suit seeking declaration that they were entitled to extract certain liquid hydrocarbons from natural gas delivered to them pursuant to contract, and defendant corporation moved to dismiss, alleging that its subsidiary was current owner of rights to liquid hydrocarbons in dispute, and therefore, was party whose joinder was needed for just adjudication. The District Court, Mary Lou Robinson, J., held that: (1) subsidiary's separate corporate existence could not be disregarded for purposes of jurisdiction, and (2) subsidiary was indispensable party to action. Dismissed.

Title: Miles v. American Tel. & Tel. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: As traditionally applied in parent-subsidiary context, alter ego doctrine permits imposition of liability upon parent company for torts and contractual obligations of its subsidiary where parent exercises actual control over subsidiary and operates it as a mere instrumentality or tool; under these circumstances, subsidiary is merely a conduit through which parent conducts its business.
Document Preview: Appeal was taken from summary judgment dismissal by the United States District Court for the Northern District of Texas, Robert W. Porter, J., of tortious invasion of privacy suit against a corporation.  The Court of Appeals, Politz, Circuit Judge, held that defendant was not liable as alter ego of its wholly-owned subsidiaries. Affirmed.

Title: Miles v. American Tel. & Tel. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Factors to be evaluated in determining whether a subsidiary corporation is nothing more than a mere adjunct of its parent such as to permit imposition of liability upon parent for torts and contractual obligations of subsidiary include whether: distinct and adequately capitalized financial units are incorporated and maintained; daily operations of the two corporations are separate; formal barriers between management of the two entities are erected, with each functioning in its own best interests; those with whom corporations come in contact are apprised of their separate identity; common stock ownership; method and degree of financing of subsidiary by parent; common directors or officers; separate books and accounts; common business departments; extent to which contracts between parent and subsidiary favor one over the other; and connection of parent's employee, officer or director to subsidiary's tort or contract giving rise to suit.
Document Preview: Appeal was taken from summary judgment dismissal by the United States District Court for the Northern District of Texas, Robert W. Porter, J., of tortious invasion of privacy suit against a corporation.  The Court of Appeals, Politz, Circuit Judge, held that defendant was not liable as alter ego of its wholly-owned subsidiaries. Affirmed.

Title: Jones v. First Union Bancorporation
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: In plaintiff's action brought against finance company and its parent alleging conversion of her automobile by defendants' alleged wrongful repossession, no liability could be found on the part of parent since there was no adequate basis on which separate corporate entities of parent and its wholly-owned subsidiary should be disregarded.
Document Preview: Plaintiff appealed from a judgment of the Circuit Court of Jackson County, Forest W. Hanna, J., in favor of defendants in plaintiff's action for the alleged conversion of her automobile by defendants' alleged wrongful repossession.  The Court of Appeals, Wasserstrom, J., held that: (1) evidence was insufficient to establish liability on the part of defendant parent corporation of defendant finance company, and (2) evidence that plaintiff neglected and failed to complete the correct forms for submission to insurer on her claim for health benefits under the policy purchased as part of the retail sale installment contract was sufficient to establish that plaintiff did not have a right of action for conversion. Affirmed.

Title: Kinetics, Inc. v. El Paso Products Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of New Mexico.
Headnote: Where wholly owned subsidiary of defendant was found to be alter ego, or mere instrumentality, of defendant, and, plaintiff in breach of warranty and negligence action had released subsidiary from liability by releasing partnership in which subsidiary was partner, liability could not be imputed to defendant.
Document Preview: Plaintiff brought action based on negligence, and breach of express and implied warranties against defendants for allegedly supplying defective resins plaintiff used to manufacture filament-wound polyester pipe.  The District Court, Eddy County, Fort, J., directed verdict for defendant, and plaintiff appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Lopez, J., held that: (1) dismissal of partnership from liability also released partner, which was wholly owned subsidiary of defendant; (2) dismissal of defendant's wholly owned subsidiary, which was found to be alter ego, or mere instrumentality, of defendant, also released defendant of liability; and (3) Uniform Contribution Among Tortfeasors Act was not applicable. Affirmed.

Title: Meisel v. M & N Modern Hydraulic Press Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Washington, En Banc.
Headnote: Separate identities of corporate defendant and corporation which manufactured trim press which injured plaintiff and had been dissolved would not be disregarded, in absence of corporate misconduct or demonstration of defendant's domination or control over corporation which manufactured trim press.

Title: Schmid v. Roehm GmbH
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Corporation was not liable to plaintiff for injuries sustained allegedly as a result of defective safety devices on a gun where corporation was not in chain of distribution and was, in fact, not in existence at time gun was manufactured and imported into United States, corporation was not alter ego of manufacturer of gun and plaintiffs had failed to show essential element under alter ego theory that liability of corporation arose from fraud or injustice perpetrated on third parties dealing with corporation.
Document Preview: Action was brought to recover damages for injuries sustained allegedly as a result of defective safety devices on gun. Plaintiff moved to strike defenses of defendants, one defendant moved for summary judgment and another defendant moved to dismiss and plaintiff cross moved for summary judgment. The District Court, O'Connor, Chief Judge, held that: (1) corporation was not liable to plaintiff as corporation was not in chain of distribution and was, in fact, not in existence at time gun was manufactured and imported into United States and was not alter ego of manufacturer, and (2) where plaintiff failed to serve process on defendant within 90 days as provided by Kansas law, action was barred by two-year statute of limitations. Ordered accordingly.

Title: Missouri Portland Cement Co. v. Walker Barge Fleeting Service, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Kentucky, Paducah Division. .
Headnote: Any liability placed upon licensor of fleeting area for sinking of a barge did not have to ultimately be borne by a fleeting service, which purchased services of licensor in operating fleet sites, on basis of piercing the corporate veil as there was no indication that either fleeting service or licensor dominated the other.
Document Preview: Admiralty action was brought for damages against fleeting service and licensor of fleeting site incurred due to sinking of plaintiff's cement transport barge. The District Court, Johnstone, J., held that: (1) sinking of barge was caused by combination of failure to exercise ordinary care during maneuver of another barge and failure of owners of barge itself to maintain it in a seaworthy condition; thus, damages would be allocated; (2) negligent act of licensor in allowing barge to collide with owners' vessel was in breach of duty owed by licensor while acting independently and not while acting on behalf of fleeting service, which purchased services of licensor in operating fleet site; (3) defendants failed to establish that plaintiff did not mitigate damages; and (4) although sum plaintiff expended in repairing vessel exceeded value of barge, liability was not limited to the value of the vessel. Ordered accordingly.

Title: Marron v. H. O. Penn Machinery Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Where assignee of forklift lease was a wholly owned subsidiary of the assignor, where assignee was located in the same place of business as the assignor, where the corporate officers of the two corporations were identical, where the assignee had no employees of its own, and where the sole commercial functioning of the assignee was to serve as a tax shelter device for the assignor and the assignor did not derive any profit from the lease assignment except to the extent that tax benefits were realized, court would pierce the corporate veil so that the assignment was not legally effective to relieve the assignor of its possible vicarious liability in tort as the lessor of the forklift, which injured lessee's worker.
Document Preview: Injured workman brought action against lessor of forklift. Workman's employer sought to recover workmen's compensation benefits paid to the lessor. Following jury verdict in favor of the workman on his claim against the lessor, his employer sought judgment on lessor's counterclaim for indemnity. The District Court, Zampano, J., held that: (1) corporate veil of assignee of lease would be pierced; (2) original lessor could assert indemnification clause in the agreement; and (3) sanctions for failure to make adequate response to discovery request were not warranted. Ordered accordingly.

Title: Parrillo v. Giroux Co., Inc.

The Court of Appeals, James Dickson Phillips, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) the evidence demonstrated that there had been a sale of a business opportunity; (2) the Act was violated notwithstanding disavowal of the profit guarantee contained in the actual sales contract; (3) it was error to grant summary judgment imposing personal liability on shareholders of the seller; and (4) attorney fees were properly denied. Title: Abraham v. Beatrice Foods Co.

Motions denied.

The Supreme Court, Zenoff, J., held that employees of financing company were, in effect, employees of financing company's sole shareholder rendering him liable for their actions, that conduct of employees in wrongfully appropriating truck, compelling truck owner to pay additional cash and not returning truck constituted malice in fact justifying punitive damages, and that court would not question amounts of awards. Affirmed.

Headnote: The corporation form could not be disregarded merely because the assets of corporate owner of a taxicab together with mandatory insurance coverage on the taxicab which struck plaintiff were insufficient to assure plaintiff recovery sought.

The Supreme Court, Edward G. Baker, J., granted motion of an individual defendant who was claimed to be a stockholder of ten corporations, including corporation in name of which taxicab was registered, to dismiss the complaint as to him for failure to state a cause of action, and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, 24 A.D.2d 582, 262 N.Y.S.2d 334, reversed and denied the motion and individual defendant appealed by leave of the Appellate Division on a certified question. The Court of Appeals, Fuld, J., held that complaint containing allegations that individual defendant organized, managed, dominated and controlled a fragmented corporate entity and that fleet ownership of taxicabs had...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Whayne v. Transportation Management Service, Inc.
Court: United States District Court E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Where management corporation owned no stock in corporate owner of vessel on which plaintiff was injured while employed as cook, the two corporations had only one common director and officer, owner regularly paid management corporation for its services, and management corporation did not direct movement of vessel or hire or fire personnel on board, owner was not mere instrumentality of management corporation and management corporation was not liable for cook's injuries. Jones Act, 46 U.S.C.A. § 688.
Document Preview: Action for injuries sustained by cook aboard vessel owned by one corporation trict Court, on defendant's motion to disagainst a second corporation. The Dismiss, Van Dusen, J., held that where defendant corporation owned no stock in corporate owner of vessel, the two corporations had only one common director and officer, corporate vessel owner regularly paid defendant for bookkeeping and other services that defendant performed, directors meetings of corporations were held at different times and in different places, defendant did not direct movement of vessel, purchase any equipment or supplies used on it, finance building of it or hire or fire personnel on board, corporate vessel owner was not mere instrumentality of defendant and defendant was not liable for cook's injuries. Action dismissed with prejudice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Stauffer v. Isaly Dairy Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Seventh District, Mahoning County.
Headnote: When two or more corporations are so intermingled that person with tort claim against one has difficulty in identifying specific corporation liable for tort, justice is not done by saying, in effect, that court cannot penetrate corporate veil and that plaintiff must act at his peril.
Document Preview: Tort action. The Court of Common Pleas overruled plaintiff's motion to substitute proper name of party defendant, and plaintiff appealed on questions of law. The Court of Appeals, Lynch, J., held that under circumstances, plaintiff could amend, after expiration of limitations, to substitute name The Isaly Dairy Company for The Isaly Dairy Company of Pittsburgh as defendant in action for injuries sustained when struck by dairy truck, where, although named corporations were separate, they maintained same office with same officer for service, plaintiff and her attorney exercised reasonable diligence in attempting to ascertain identity of tortfeasor and mistake was caused or induced by officers of corporation, and plaintiff would have been informed of her mistake had originally-named defendant filed its answers to interrogatories within time originally allowed. Reversed. Jones, J., dissented.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Colarusso v. Mills
Court: Supreme Court of Rhode Island.
Headnote: Defendant motorist was not exempt from liability for injuries sustained by fellow employee whom she was transporting at time of accident on any theory of identity between motorist and corporate employer of which she was assertedly an officer, agent and servant. Gen.Laws 1956, § 28-29-20.
Document Preview: Actions to recover husband's consequential damages and wife's damages for personal injuries she sustained when a passenger in an automobile operated by the defendant. The Superior Court, Providence and Bristol Counties, Perkins, J., overruled a demurrer to the defendant's plea, and exceptions were taken. The Supreme Court, Joslin, J., held that a prior recovery of workmen's compensation benefits by the injured wife passenger would not prohibit a suit against the defendant if the wife could establish either that she had agreed with her employer to reimburse him out of any recovery or that her employer had refused to enter into any such agreement, but in the letter event, any ultimate recovery should be reduced by the amount of compensation benefits received. Exceptions overruled, and cases remitted for further proceedings.

Title: Wrigley v. Nottingham
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia, Division No. 3.
Headnote: One sued in his personal capacity, who is otherwise alter ego, officer or agent of corporation, may not escape personal liability for his tortious misconduct damaging employees or third persons by hiding behind corporate veil, even in situations where corporation might also be proper party to action.
Document Preview: Action by discharged employee against corporate officers in their personal capacities for allegedly having maliciously procured breach of his oral employment contract with corporation. The Civil Court, Fulton County, Osgood O. Williams, J., entered judgment against the officers on jury verdict, and they brought error. The Court of Appeals, Bell, P. J., held that pleadings and evidence supported jury's verdict that corporate president and owner of all voting stock in corporation had maliciously procured breach of employee's contract in which employee, who had allegedly made loans to corporation, had valuable interest; and further held that evidence was insufficient to support judgment against another corporate director. Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: American Optical Co. v. Philadelphia Elec. Co.
Court: United States District Court E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Fiction of corporate entity cannot be used by real owners of property to escape liability for injuries caused by them.
Document Preview: Action by tenant in building damaged by fire against corporate record owner of building at time of fire, corporation's president and trustees to whom it was alleged premises had been conveyed. Defendants moved for dismissal. The District Court, Grim, J., held, in part, that evidence raised presumption that nonresident president was user of building within Pennsylvania Non-Resident Owner of Real Estate Act and therefore subject to jurisdiction of federal court and president was not entitled to dismissal prior to development of evidence concerning control, maintenance and use of building at time of fire, and that complaint stated cause of action against trustees, but that where service of process was effected more than two years after corporation had been dissolved, corporation was entitled to dismissal. Order accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1057 Particular Occasions for Determining Corporate Entity > 101k1073 Torts in general >
Title: Irving Serwer Advertising, Inc. v. Salit
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Corporate defendant, in action for conspiracy, was entity which was separate and distinct from alleged individual conspirators, and, therefore, corporate liability could not be fastened upon it merely on basis of benefits received by corporation as result of predetermined course of action on parts of alleged individual conspirators.
Document Preview: An action for conspiracy. The trial court denied a motion to dismiss the complaint as to a corporate defendant for legal insufficiency, and the corporate defendant appealed. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that allegations that individual defendants, while in plaintiff's employ, acquired confidential information as to plaintiff's accounts and conspired with corporate defendant, formed after termination of individual defendants' employment by plaintiff, to destroy plaintiff's business failed to state cause of action for conspiracy as against corporate defendant, in absence of factual allegations that corporate defendant was alter ego of individual defendants, or that corporate defendant was constructive trustee with respect to particular benefits received. Order reversed, and motion granted with leave to replead.

Title: McSparran v. Bethlehem Minerals Co.
Court: United States District Court E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Subsidiaries of same parent corporation had to be considered as separate corporate entities in determining whether complaint, in action under Wrongful Death and Survival Acts, could be amended to include one subsidiary as additional defendant where one subsidiary was western hemisphere trade corporation for federal tax purposes and performed no functions in United States, and other subsidiary operated many projects in United States, and there was no showing that subsidiaries were not operated as separate entities. 12 P.S.Pa. § 1601 et seq.; 20 P.S.Pa. § 320.601 et seq.; 26 U.S.C.A. (I.R.C.1954) §§ 921, 922.
Document Preview: Action under the Wrongful Death Act and the Survival Act. Upon a motion to file after the statute of limitations has run, a second amended complaint against a defendant not previously named, the District Court, Van Dusen, J., held, inter alia, that the motion had to be denied where statute of limitations would have run even without counting delays involved when original defendant failed to answer plaintiff's interrogatories. Motion denied. See also D.C., 26 F.R.D. 619.

Title: Minton v. Cavaney
Court: Supreme Court of California, In Bank.
Headnote: The "alter ego" doctrine applies to tort claims against a corporation, as well as to contractual debts.
Document Preview: Action to hold a corporate director personally liable upon a judgment recovered against a corporation. Subsequent to commencement of the action, the director died and executrix of his estate was substituted as defendant. The Superior Court, Los Angeles County, Frederick F. Houser, J., entered judgment adverse to defendant and she appealed. The Supreme Court, Traynor, J., held that corporate director could not be held personally liable upon a judgment against the corporation for negligence, without an opportunity to relitigate issues of corporation's negligence and amount of damages, where director was not a party to action against the corporation and did not control the litigation leading to the judgment against the corporation. Judgment reversed. Schauer and McComb, JJ., dissented in part. Opinion, 12 Cal.Rptr. 86, vacated.

Title: Westwood Development Co. v. Esponge

Title: Mull v. Colt Co.
Court: United States District Court S.D. New York.
Headnote: Even if an individual, either alone or with two others, adopted plan consisting of formation of a series of corporations, each of which would be registered owner of two taxicabs, for purpose of limiting any liability in case of suit by injured parties, resulting from owning and operating taxicabs where there was no showing of fraud or illegality in the activities or in use of corporate form for doing business, corporate veil could not be pierced to allow such individuals to be held personally liable in action for injuries received in taxicab accident.
Document Preview: Action for injuries sustained in taxicab accident, against taxicab corporation, against one alleged, either individually or with two others, to own the stock in the corporation, and against others. On motion of such asserted shareholder to dismiss complaint as to him on grounds that it failed to state complaint on which relief could be granted, the District Court, Metzner, J., held that, even if an individual, either alone or with two others, adopted plan consisting of formation of a series of corporations, each of which would be registered owner of two taxicabs, for purpose of limiting any liability in case of suit by injured parties, resulting from owning and operating taxicabs, where there was no showing of fraud or illegality in the activities of such corporations or in use of corporate form for doing business, corporate veil could not be pierced to allow such individuals to be held personally liable. Motion granted.

Title: Noah v. L. Daitch & Co.

Headnote: Where third party, which allegedly induced dairy products supplier to terminate its distributorship or supplier-agency contract with retail dairy store owners, acted within scope of its authority and did not commit any separate and independent tort, no liability could be imposed on third party because of identity of interest based on claim that supplier and third party were "inter-related corporations".

Title: Wolf v. S. H. Wintman Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Rhode Island.
Headnote: Where husband and wife were sole owners of corporation to which wholesale distributor of beer sold beer, a bottle of which exploded causing injuries to wife, court would not, in action of assumpsit by husband and wife against wholesale distributor and bottler of beer for breach of alleged implied warranty, pierce the corporate veil and look upon husband and wife as real parties in interest.
Document Preview: Actions for breach of alleged implied warranty. From adverse judgments of the Superior Court, Providence and Bristol Counties, the plaintiffs excepted. The Supreme Court, Condon, C. J., held that husband and wife could not, without establishing privity with bottler or wholesale distributor of beer, recover in assumpsit for breach of alleged implied warranty for injuries sustained by wife by explosion of bottle of beer, which had not been sold to husband and wife individually but which had been sold by distributor to corporation owned solely by husband and wife. Exceptions overruled and case remitted.

Title: Thoni Trucking Co. v. Foster
Court: United States Court of Appeals Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Where corporation vehicle was involved in serious accident resulting in injuries to plaintiffs and immediately after accident stockholder who was in dominant control of corporation took steps to strip corporation of all assets, under Tennessee law court could disregard corporate entity and hold such stockholder personally liable for default judgment entered in Illinois court against corporation.
Document Preview: Action by plaintiffs to recover against stockholder personally for default judgment taken against corporation in state court. The United States District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee, Nashville Division, William E. Miller, J., entered judgment for plaintiffs and stockholder appealed. Affirmed.

Title: Powder Power Tool Corp. v. Powder Actuated Tool Co.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Where corporation and an individual were, for practical purposes, one and same and individual controlled the corporation, and where corporation, after terminating its distributorship for patent owner had no business or purpose other than that of infringing and practicing unfair competition, individual was personally liable as well as corporation.

Title: Green v. Equitable Powder Mfg. Co.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Arkansas, Fort Smith Division.
Headnote: Where corporate manufacturer and corporate seller are in truth and fact, one and the same organization, at least insofar as claim of plaintiff is concerned, and an interference with public convenience or a wrong and a fraud would result from a denial of plaintiff's right to proceed against both seller and manufacturer, plaintiff may disregard corporate entity and proceed against the seller.

Title: Mueller v. Seaboard Commercial Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of New Jersey.
Headnote: Mere stock ownership by one corporation in another corporation is insufficient to render former liable for torts of latter, but where affairs of latter corporation are so organized and conducted as to make it a mere instrumentality of former, corporate entity will be disregarded if corporate form is used as a shield behind which injustice is sought to be done by those who have control of it.
Document Preview: Attachment proceeding by Chester Mueller against Seaboard Commercial Corporation, a corporation of Delaware. The Essex County Court, Law Division, made an order denying defendant's motion to vacate an order authorizing the issuance of a writ of attachment and to quash the writ, and the defendant appealed to the Superior Court, Appellate Division. Thereafter the Supreme Court certified the appeal on its own motion. The Supreme Court, Burling, J., held that plaintiff's affidavits prima facie established a cause of action for conversion, and hence the writ was properly issued. Order affirmed.

Court: Supreme Court of California
Headnote: Where all corporate assets were transferred to partnership to reduce income tax liability, but firm name remained the same, members of partnership were identical with stockholders of corporation, and partnership carried on beer manufacturing business of corporation without interruption and used same plant, corporation was the alter ego of partnership as regards liability for purchaser's injuries sustained when beer bottle sold by partnership exploded.
Document Preview: EDMONDS, J., dissenting. TRAYNOR, J., dissenting in part.

Court: Supreme Court, Queens County, New York, Special Term, Part I.

Judgment modified by reducing the verdict to $20,000, and, as modified, affirmed.

Title: Johannsen v. Mid-Continent Petroleum Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Iowa.
Headnote: A corporation exercising actual control over another corporation and operating it as mere instrumentality or tool is liable for torts of corporation thus controlled.
Document Preview: Appeal from District Court, Crawford County; M. E. Hutchison, Judge. This is an action at law brought by the plaintiff against the Mid-Continent Petroleum Corporation of Delaware on the ground that the Mid-Continent Petroleum Corporation of Kentucky was acting as an instrumentality of the Delaware corporation in the operation of a bulk station and plant at Denison, Iowa, and against Thomas Lorenzen, who was in the employ of the oil company at the time the injuries were received. Separate answers were filed by the defendants. There was a trial in which evidence was offered. At the close of the evidence on the part of the plaintiff, defendants made a motion for a directed verdict which was renewed at the close of all of the evidence. The motion was overruled and the case submitted to the jury, which returned a verdict for the plaintiff. The defendants, being dissatisfied, have appealed. The opinion states the facts. Affirmed.

Title: Southeastern Greyhound Lines v. Harden's Adm'x

Headnote: A bus company, owning stock in bus terminal company operating passenger station for such bus company and other such companies having separate employees, is not liable for death of one assaulted by terminal company's ticket agent at such station on grounds of interlocking ownership and operation of two corporations and such agent's agency for bus company in selling tickets for transportation over its lines, as terminal company is not mere alter ego of bus company or conduit through which it operates, but each is separate corporate entity operating independently.
